text.headline: Joshua Sharpless's Journal Into Indian Country, 1798
text.text:
The manuscript of Joshua Sharpless’s “Journal into Indian Country, (1798) is
                    housed at Friends Historical Library, on the campus of Swarthmore College. In
                    the spring semester of 2012, Swarthmore students enrolled in English 57A (“Early
                    American Literature Through A Traveler’s Eyes”) transcribed Sharpless’s
                    manuscript as part of a larger project to make the library’s rich store of
                    Quaker journal writings more accessible to researchers. The project was designed
                    by Christopher Densmore, curator of Friends Historical Library, and Keat Murray,
                    Visiting Associate Professor of English. Transcribers included: Kara Stoever
                    (3-38), Kari Olmon (39-74), Zach Wunrow (75-87, 153-174), Margaret Duszyk
                    (88-104), Roberto Conreras (105-123), and David Fialkow (124-152). Students’
                    transcriptions were compiled and edited in the present form by Professor Murray.

text.headline: April 30, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Feeling an engagement of Mind to <ns0:lb /> Join <ns0:persName key="jpier1">John                        Pierce</ns0:persName> in a Visit to the Indian <ns0:lb /> natives of this Land, after                    some close exer-<ns0:lb /> -cise of Mind on the Occasion, I gave up:<ns0:lb /> and on the                        <ns0:date when="1798-04-30">30th day of the 4th Mo 1798</ns0:date>, after <ns0:lb /> a                    comfortable Opportunity in my fami-<ns0:lb /> -ly, several friends being present, I                    took<ns0:lb /> an Affectionate farewell of them, and a-<ns0:lb /> -bout one O clock in the                    afternoon set<ns0:lb /> of in Company with <ns0:persName key="jpier1">John                        Pierce</ns0:persName>, and<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="hsimm1">Henry Simmons</ns0:persName>, in order to pursue a<ns0:lb />                    Journey to the Northwest parts of this,<ns0:lb /> and <ns0:placeName key="newyo">New York                        State</ns0:placeName>, to assist in form-<ns0:lb /> -ing a Settlement among the                    Indians, for<ns0:lb /> their improvement in Agriculture, and<ns0:lb /> more of a Civilized                    Live, we stopped and<ns0:lb /> took some refreshment at <ns0:persName key="jtrum1">John                        Truman</ns0:persName>’s,<ns0:lb /> and Lodged at <ns0:persName key="itayl1">Isaac                        Taylor</ns0:persName>s. 22 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 01, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> A fine day for traveling, tho<ns0:lb /> warm, went to <ns0:persName key="agibb1">Abraham                        Gibbons</ns0:persName>’s<ns0:lb /> 11 miles, here by appointment we met<ns0:lb /> with                        <ns0:persName key="jswai1">Joel Swayne</ns0:persName>, and <ns0:persName key="hjack1">Halladay Jack-<ns0:lb /> -son</ns0:persName>, two young Men who with <ns0:persName key="hsimm1">Henry<ns0:lb /> Simmons</ns0:persName> had given up to reside some<ns0:lb />                    time among the Indians for their<ns0:lb /> religious and temporal benefit, took<ns0:lb />                    dinner here, then went 7 miles to <ns0:placeName key="lanca">Lan-<ns0:lb />                        -caster</ns0:placeName>, where stopping and doing some<ns0:lb /> business, we went on                    12 miles to <ns0:placeName key="wrigh">Wrights<ns0:lb /> ferry</ns0:placeName> on <ns0:geogName key="susqu">Susquehanna</ns0:geogName>, where there is<ns0:lb /> a pretty Town lately                    laid out, it con-<ns0:lb /> -tains 20 or more good buildings, beauti-<ns0:lb /> -fully                    situated on an elevation above<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="susqu">River</ns0:geogName>,                    the shore of which was lined<ns0:lb /> with many thousand feet of White<ns0:lb /> Pine                    boards and other Lumber which had been down that <ns0:geogName key="susqu">River</ns0:geogName> for<ns0:lb /> near half a Mile. most of this days<ns0:lb /> ride                        <ns0:del>has been</ns0:del> was through a fruitful well<ns0:lb /> improved Country, with                    good Stone <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_005" n="3" /> Houses and Barns, a large proportion<ns0:lb />                    of the land was sown with Rye; some of<ns0:lb /> the Wheat fields looked pretty well,                    but<ns0:lb /> in general Poor; Clover not so forward<ns0:lb /> as in my neighborhood; some                    beauti-<ns0:lb /> -ful Meadows, between <ns0:placeName key="lanca">Lancaster</ns0:placeName>                    and<ns0:lb /> this place, 30 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 02, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> a rainy Morning, stayed under shelter until<ns0:lb /> 8 O Clock, <ns0:del>and</ns0:del> then                    Crossed the <ns0:geogName key="susqu">River</ns0:geogName> in the Rain <ns0:lb /> it is one                    Mile and 12 perches wide, which<ns0:lb /> a Man and horse crosses for 6d; a cheap                    ferry,<ns0:lb /> thence to <ns0:placeName key="yorkt">York Town</ns0:placeName> 12 miles                    mostly through<ns0:lb /> a Valley, perhaps 10 or more miles wide, some<ns0:lb /> beautiful                    Meadows made their appear-<ns0:lb /> -ance, more particularly within a few miles<ns0:lb />                    of the <ns0:geogName key="susqu">River</ns0:geogName>, and this Town, the Winter<ns0:lb />                    Grain mostly Poor, though the Land appeared<ns0:lb /> to be of a good quality, and                    well farmed,<ns0:lb /> The town of <ns0:placeName key="yorkt">York</ns0:placeName> has an                    agreeable ap-<ns0:lb />- pearance, in which there are a number<ns0:lb /> good Buildings;                    it is beautified by a large<ns0:lb /> stream of Water called <ns0:geogName key="codor">Codoras</ns0:geogName> which runs<ns0:lb /> through the <ns0:placeName key="yorkt">Town</ns0:placeName>, we dined here at a Public <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_006" n="4" /> House,— then set of for <ns0:persName key="iever1">Isaac Everet</ns0:persName>s.<ns0:lb /> in 2 or 3 miles after we left                    the Town<ns0:lb /> we got out of the Limestone Valley, and<ns0:lb /> passed through a                    Country diversified<ns0:lb /> with gentle Assents, and descents, pretty<ns0:lb /> clear of                    stones, the Land in places<ns0:lb /> thin, though well watered by the Branches<ns0:lb />                    of the <ns0:geogName key="concr">Canowagoe</ns0:geogName>, the main stream of<ns0:lb /> which                    was nearly as large as <ns0:geogName key="brand">Brandy-<ns0:lb /> -wine</ns0:geogName>, the                    Winter grain much affected<ns0:lb /> with the fly, this has been a pleasant af-<ns0:lb />                    -ternoon to ride, the Wind at Northwest<ns0:lb /> and pretty Cool, Stopped at                        <ns0:persName key="jgarr1">John Garison</ns0:persName>’s<ns0:lb /> 17 miles where we fed                    our horses and got<ns0:lb /> some refreshment, then some of us went<ns0:lb /> to <ns0:persName key="iever1">Isaac Everett</ns0:persName>’s 3 miles, where we lodged,<ns0:lb />                    leaving the others at <ns0:persName key="jgarr1">John Garrisons</ns0:persName>. 32                    miles.</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 04, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Set of early, we immediately asscened<ns0:lb /> another Mountain much like our                    last,<ns0:lb /> when we arrived at its Summit we had<ns0:lb /> a delightful View of a well                    improved<ns0:lb /> Valley <ns0:del>three</ns0:del> two or more miles in weadth, with<ns0:lb /> a                    lofty Mountain beyond, Just as we ente-<ns0:lb /> -red this Valley, we Crossed the                        <ns0:geogName key="conoc">Conacocheague<ns0:lb /> Creek</ns0:geogName> a beautiful                    stream, in about half<ns0:lb /> a Mile we passed through <ns0:placeName key="fanne">Phanetts-Burgh</ns0:placeName>                    <ns0:lb /> a Village of perhaps 30 Loghouses, shortly af-<ns0:lb /> -ter we                        <ns0:del>crossed</ns0:del> passed this Town we ascend-<ns0:lb /> -ed a third Mountain                    much like the two<ns0:lb /> last discribed, from thence to Birds at <ns0:placeName key="flitt">fort<ns0:lb /> Littleton</ns0:placeName> 5 miles, through a rough                    Country, <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_009" n="7" /> Surrounded with lofty Mountains, some<ns0:lb />                    pretty good improvements in places made<ns0:lb /> there appearance, and the Roads                    consider<ns0:lb /> -ing the Roughness of the Country not to be<ns0:lb /> complained of,                    here we got our Breakfast<ns0:lb /> 12 miles. from thence to <ns0:persName key="gskin1">Skinners</ns0:persName> on the<ns0:lb /> top of <ns0:geogName key="sidel">Sidling                        hill</ns0:geogName> 11 miles, through a rough,<ns0:lb /> Broken, poor Country, very                    little inhabited.<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="sidel">Sidling hill</ns0:geogName> a lofty Mountain; 7 miles                    carried<ns0:lb /> us over, we made near four miles on its<ns0:lb /> Summit, which was very                    high, but our<ns0:lb /> prospect not extensive by reason of some<ns0:lb /> mountains which                    was nearby on each<ns0:lb /> hand, as we began to descend a noble<ns0:lb /> view                    presented, as far as the Eye could<ns0:lb /> reach, having the <ns0:geogName key="allmo">Allegeny Mountain</ns0:geogName> in<ns0:lb /> full view at 20 or more miles distant,                    the<ns0:lb /> extensive prospect between, looked like<ns0:lb /> a delightful plain,                    Chequered with a few<ns0:lb /> plantations, but when we came to tra-<ns0:lb /> -verse it,                    we found many lofty hills, or<ns0:lb /> Mountains, particularly about the <ns0:geogName key="junia">Juni-<ns0:lb /> -atta River</ns0:geogName>, one Branch of which we<ns0:lb />                    Crossed, which was some 50 or so yards wide<ns0:lb /> and more than Belly deep;                    directly upon <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_010" n="8" /> Crossing this stream we ascended the<ns0:lb />                    Steepest hill we have met with since we<ns0:lb /> left home, it is admirable that so                    many<ns0:lb /> Wagons which pass this road, should be able to get<ns0:lb /> up it, I                    suppose we have passed by 20 this<ns0:lb /> this day, mostly with families going to                    new<ns0:lb /> Countries, a number of which were Crowded<ns0:lb /> with Children; 17 people                    of different descrip-<ns0:lb /> -tions belonged to one wagon. — when I view-<ns0:lb /> -ed                    the hills and mountains about this River,<ns0:lb /> I was struck with admiration that                    it ever found<ns0:lb /> a way through them to the <ns0:geogName key="susqu">Susquehanna</ns0:geogName>, but<ns0:lb /> I will assure my readers <ns0:del>that</ns0:del>                    its meanders<ns0:lb /> are very various, and serpentine, some 5 or 6 miles after                    we<ns0:lb /> Crossed <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> this stream we had the River nearby on each<ns0:lb />                    hand perhaps not more than half a mile a-<ns0:lb /> -part. we took up our Quarters at one<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName>Hartley</ns0:persName>’s near the <ns0:del>its</ns0:del> banks, of said river, he                    has a valuable<ns0:lb /> plantation, and pretily situated. most<ns0:lb /> of this days                    ride has been through a<ns0:lb /> very broken, poor, and thinly settled Coun-<ns0:lb />                    -try. — 38 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 04, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Went 6 miles up the <ns0:geogName key="junia">Juniatta</ns0:geogName>, through<ns0:lb /> a                    rough, Mountainous Country to <ns0:placeName key="bedfo">Bedford</ns0:placeName>,<ns0:lb />                    having about one mile back crossed the <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_011" n="9" /> River on a Bridge, the Town stands in<ns0:lb />                    a Valley Surrounded by high Mountains, it is<ns0:lb /> a pretty pleasant situation,                    being seated on an<ns0:lb /> elevated Spot near a branch of the River, the Town                        <ns0:del>it</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> contains a number of good Stone buildings<ns0:lb /> among                    which are a Courthouse, Jail, &c: here<ns0:lb /> we got our breakfast, and then                    passed over<ns0:lb /> a very Mountainous, poor Country, and but<ns0:lb /> thinly settled                    to the <ns0:geogName key="allmo">Allegenies</ns0:geogName>, which Moun-<ns0:lb /> -tain tho                    high, was not difficult ascending,<ns0:lb /> being rather a succession of Mountains                    than<ns0:lb /> one huge pile, we had several very steep As-<ns0:lb /> -scents and                    descents, while on this Mountain,<ns0:lb /> yet our road went much of the way on the                    top<ns0:lb /> of very high ridges, when we arrived at its<ns0:lb /> greatest eminence, we                    stoped at an Inn and<ns0:lb /> refreshed ourselves, here we met with a fine<ns0:lb />                    Spring of Water near the door. we here turned to the left taking the glade road,                    the descent from<ns0:lb /> this Mountain was gradual, the Land arable<ns0:lb /> tho stony,                    it is called 10 miles across, —We now<ns0:lb /> entered what is called the Glades,                        <ns0:del>we</ns0:del> having understood<ns0:lb /> in places there were flats or openings                    where<ns0:lb /> much Grass was Cut, Yet where we went throug[h]<ns0:lb /> was heavy                    Timbered, some of which <ns0:del>was</ns0:del> were sugar<ns0:lb /> Maple being the first we                    had seen, the Land<ns0:lb /> appeared good, was pretty thick settled, and <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_012" n="10" /> productive, we arrived at a Dutch<ns0:lb />                    Town called <ns0:placeName key="berli">Berlin</ns0:placeName>, containing upwards<ns0:lb />                    of 50 Houses, Mostly of Logs, and Frame, when<ns0:lb /> at the sign of the Black                    House we got good<ns0:lb /> entertainment. 36 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 06, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We started early this Morning with some hopes<ns0:lb /> of reaching a friend’s House                    this evening, which<ns0:lb /> was very desirably, for 2 or more miles the<ns0:lb /> Land                    was good, and considerably Settled, tho<ns0:lb /> Hilly. thence we entered a Chesnutt                    Country,<ns0:lb /> the Soil thin, and in a while we came among<ns0:lb /> abundance of                    Laurel, the road very Stony,<ns0:lb /> Rocky, & Muddy, thence entered a Pine                    forrest<ns0:lb /> being the first White Pines of note <ns0:del>since</ns0:del> we<ns0:lb /> have                    met with; here they grew in abun-<ns0:lb /> -dance, tho not very large, but few                    settlement<ns0:lb /> the greatest part of this stage, stoped and got<ns0:lb /> our                    Breakfast at <ns0:persName key="jthus1">John Thusier</ns0:persName>s 13 miles.<ns0:lb /> from                    thence to <ns0:persName key="gbach1">Geo: Batchaler</ns0:persName>’s 14 miles, the<ns0:lb />                    whole of this stage remarkable rough, the first<ns0:lb /> 3 or 4 miles the Land                    appeared pretty good tho<ns0:lb /> very hilly, one hill more steep and long than<ns0:lb />                    any we have hitherto met with, was as we went<ns0:lb /> down to <ns0:geogName key="laucr">Laurell—hill—Creek</ns0:geogName>, a smart stream<ns0:lb /> from thence to near this                    place called <ns0:geogName key="laure">Laurell<ns0:lb /> Hill</ns0:geogName>, the whole of                    this stage very heavy Timbered<ns0:lb /> so that the Hill comparatively speaking                    groan <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_013" n="11" /> ed under their great Load, abundance                    of<ns0:lb /> which was beautiful Chesnut, the finest I <ns0:del>reme</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> remember                    to have seen, with a large Quan-<ns0:lb /> -tity of Oak of various kinds, some                    Sugar<ns0:lb /> Maple &c: much of this stage the road was very<ns0:lb /> Rocky and                    Stony. From thence to <ns0:placeName key="conne">Conalds—<ns0:lb /> -Ville</ns0:placeName> a                    small Town on the <ns0:geogName key="yough">Yoxhiogeny</ns0:geogName> 14 miles<ns0:lb /> the                    most of this stage was poor, rough, and<ns0:lb /> Mountainous, and but thinly                    settled, except<ns0:lb /> within 3 or 4 miles of the <ns0:geogName key="yough">River</ns0:geogName> after we left<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="cheri">Chesnut                        Ridge</ns0:geogName>. — We all took notice<ns0:lb /> when on the <ns0:geogName key="allmo">Allegenies</ns0:geogName> and for many Miles<ns0:lb /> on this side, how                    very backward the Trees<ns0:lb /> were, when we left home they were putting<ns0:lb /> out                    fast, and the Weather being very warm<ns0:lb /> they made rapid progress; yet this                    morning<ns0:lb /> we remarked the buds of the Chesnut and<ns0:lb /> White Oak were not                    formed into leaves so<ns0:lb /> as to make an appearance, yet the same<ns0:lb /> day as we                    descended from the <ns0:geogName key="cheri">Chesnut Ridge</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> the Trees                    were all green, the sight was<ns0:lb /> so Curious, and different from our late                    pros-<ns0:lb /> -pect, that I measured some Chesnutt leaves<ns0:lb /> and found them to be                    3 Inches wide, and<ns0:lb /> Six long, and sprouts of 8 or 9 Inches growth.<ns0:lb /> So                    that I think there is at least, in three miles <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_014" n="   12" /> Riding two Weeks difference in the                    Season.<ns0:lb /> When on the Chesnut hill there is one of the most<ns0:lb /> extensive                    prospects that is to be met with<ns0:lb /> in traveling, both to the North, to                    the<ns0:lb /> West, and to the South, I had no doubt but the View<ns0:lb /> was of 50                    miles extent, it was not so de-<ns0:lb /> lightful as some I have seen, for want of                    a<ns0:lb /> lofty mountain rising 10 or more miles in<ns0:lb /> front, but it was                    Chequered with many Plan-<ns0:lb /> -tations: in every direction, the View look<ns0:lb />                    -ed like an extensive plain, but when<ns0:lb /> we came to the traverse it, we found                    many<ns0:lb /> Steep Hills, <ns0:del>but</ns0:del> tho no Mountain; neither is<ns0:lb /> there any                    to the Westward in the United<ns0:lb /> States equal to those we have Crossed.                    We<ns0:lb /> lodged with our kind friend <ns0:persName key="tgibs1">Thomas                        Gibson</ns0:persName><ns0:lb /> on the Bank of the <ns0:geogName key="yough">River</ns0:geogName>. 41 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 07, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> a pleasant day, went to my Kinsman’s<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="rcadw1">Reese Cadwalader</ns0:persName>s, near <ns0:placeName key="brown">BrownsVille</ns0:placeName> on<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="monon">Monongahala</ns0:geogName>, we Crossed the <ns0:del>Yoxge</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="yough">Yoxhiogeny</ns0:geogName> in a boat it was about 6 feet<ns0:lb />                    deep and perhaps 150 yards wide, in about<ns0:lb /> half a mile after we crossed the                    River, we<ns0:lb /> passed by a Merchant Mill erected on a<ns0:lb /> very Curious Seat,                    the stream was small,<ns0:lb /> but had a natural perpendicular fall over <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_015" n="   13" /> a broad Rock which lay Horizontal                    of<ns0:lb /> 28 feet, the Mill was erected close to this<ns0:lb /> Rock which formed a                    level Yard to the<ns0:lb /> upper Road; under sd Rock was a Cavity<ns0:lb /> or hollow                    place 12 feet high, and nearly<ns0:lb /> as far back, which ran all across the<ns0:lb />                    Stream, over which the Water beautifully<ns0:lb /> descended. From thence to the                        <ns0:geogName key="monon">Mononga-<ns0:lb /> -haly</ns0:geogName> a continual succession                    of high hills<ns0:lb /> and low Vales, the Very little bottom land<ns0:lb /> fit for                    Meadow, the land is pretty clear of<ns0:lb /> Stones, the soil in general good, and                    thick<ns0:lb /> settled, yet some of the fields which had been<ns0:lb /> a good while                    under Culture looked poor; I saw<ns0:lb /> several fields of good Wheat, but more that<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>looked</ns0:del> were light.</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 08, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Went 12 miles this Morning to see my Cousin<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="bshar1">Benjamin Sharples</ns0:persName>, he lives on the West<ns0:lb />                    Branch of 10 mile Creek near Green Furnace.<ns0:lb /> I crossed the <ns0:geogName key="monon">Monongahala</ns0:geogName> at <ns0:placeName key="bridg">Bridge<ns0:del>Town</ns0:del>port</ns0:placeName> a<ns0:lb /> Village containing near 50                    houses, the place<ns0:lb /> whereon the town stands was four years<ns0:lb /> ago a fine                    Meadow. the <ns0:geogName key="monon">River</ns0:geogName> is a<ns0:lb /> beautiful Stream,                    flows along with a<ns0:lb /> very gentle Current, is 340 Yards wide<ns0:lb /> and 10 or 12                    feet deep, it has very high <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_016" n="   14" /> Banks, yet last fall they were                    overflown<ns0:lb /> the River as I was informed rose 42 feet<ns0:lb /> Perpendicular. The                    people here were very<ns0:lb /> busy building flat bottomed Boats, they are<ns0:lb /> made                    out of green timber, about 12 feet wide,<ns0:lb /> and from 20 to 30 feet long,                    boarded up, on<ns0:lb /> each side, 5 or 6 feet high, and roofed over<ns0:lb /> more than                    half way, I was informed many<ns0:lb /> boats of this kind was built on this                        <ns0:geogName key="monon">River</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> and its neighboring Waters, they                    are<ns0:lb /> sold at the rate of 11/3 per foot, for every<ns0:lb /> foot they are in                    length, to people who come<ns0:lb /> with families to these Waters, to take                    their<ns0:lb /> departure Westward, and <ns0:del>Sail</ns0:del> Southwest,<ns0:lb /> to new                    Countries, they put on board, horse<ns0:lb /> Waggon, farming Utensels, Cowkind,                    hosehold<ns0:lb /> furniture &c: and so great if the Spirit of emi-<ns0:lb /> -gration                    down the Waters of the <ns0:geogName key="ohior">Ohio</ns0:geogName> to dif-<ns0:lb />                    -firent places, that we were informed when<ns0:lb /> at <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName> by a very reputable Character<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> for 30 days past upon an average he<ns0:lb /> thought there had been                    from 10 to 12 of these<ns0:lb /> boats, containing from 20 to 50 persons so<ns0:lb />                    loaded, passing by that Town each day. they<ns0:lb /> gently move down with the                    Current, and when<ns0:lb /> they come to the mouth of the <ns0:geogName key="sciot">Scioto</ns0:geogName> and other <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_017" n="   15" /> rivers their Boats are of no further                    use, for<ns0:lb /> their Construction is such they cannot be taken<ns0:lb /> up the                    Stream, and are therefore often sold<ns0:lb /> for a trifle, or turned adrift. — I                    went<ns0:lb /> up the West side of the <ns0:geogName key="monon">River</ns0:geogName> and in                    about<ns0:lb /> 6 miles passed through a small Village called<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="frede">Fredricks Town</ns0:placeName>, then up the <ns0:geogName key="monon">River</ns0:geogName> to <ns0:geogName key="tenmi">10<ns0:lb /> mile                        Creek</ns0:geogName> I passed over some very<ns0:lb /> Rich bottoms on sd <ns0:geogName key="monon">River</ns0:geogName> and <ns0:geogName key="tenmi">Creek</ns0:geogName>;<ns0:lb /> also hillsides very good, abounding with<ns0:lb /> Black and                    White Walnut, Locust, Sugar<ns0:lb /> Maple &c: as far as I have seen, if it                    was<ns0:lb /> not for the Hills, <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> this would be a desirable<ns0:lb />                    Country, but they will ever be in the Way<ns0:lb /> of farming, and conveying                    produce<ns0:lb /> to Market, but its Vicinity with Water<ns0:lb /> Cariage will very much                    facilitate the lat<ns0:lb /> -ter, their best meadows are often to be found<ns0:lb /> on                    the tops of high hills, which are often<ns0:lb /> inclinable to be wet, and Springy,                    the<ns0:lb /> land is inclinable to grass, yet Clover<ns0:lb /> is not much propagated.                    the price of<ns0:lb /> produce pretty good, Wheat 7/6 Rye 4/6<ns0:lb /> Corn 3/9, Oates                    3/9, Bacon 1/, Butter 1/61/3,<ns0:lb /> Cheap <ns0:del>1/</ns0:del> 9 d home made sugar from                    1/ to<ns0:lb /> to one ¼ of which with Industry came the<ns0:lb /> Country may always be                    supplyed 24 miles </ns0:p>

text.headline: May 09, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Attended <ns0:orgName key="">Redstone Meeting</ns0:orgName>, dined at<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="rcadw1">Reese Cadwaladers</ns0:persName>, where we have made<ns0:lb /> our                    home since our arrival here, it is a good<ns0:lb /> place for man and beast, Our                    horses have<ns0:lb /> had very good Pasture, and been well<ns0:lb /> fed with Grain, so                    that they recruited.<ns0:lb /> Set of this afternoon for <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName>, crossed<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="monon">Monongalela</ns0:geogName> at <ns0:placeName key="bridg">Bridge<ns0:del>town</ns0:del>port</ns0:placeName>, went<ns0:lb /> down the west side of                        <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> said <ns0:geogName key="monon">River</ns0:geogName> to <ns0:persName key="abogg1">Alexander Bogg</ns0:persName>s<ns0:lb /> on <ns0:geogName key="pigeo">Pigeon                        Creek</ns0:geogName> where we lodged 11 m<ns0:lb /> having a few miles back crossed                        <ns0:geogName key="trout">Trout Run</ns0:geogName></ns0:p>

text.headline: May 10, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Set of early this Morning, Stopped at <ns0:persName>Par-<ns0:lb /> -kers</ns0:persName>, fed                    our horses and got our Break-<ns0:lb /> -fast, a number of curious falls pre-<ns0:lb />                    -sented on small streams in this last stage,<ns0:lb /> at a Certain depth much of                    this Country<ns0:lb /> appears to be covered with broad Rocks<ns0:lb /> lying                    Horizontally, which about the<ns0:lb /> streams is washed bare, over the edges<ns0:lb />                    of these Rocks the Water often falls, from<ns0:lb /> 2 to 12, or 15 feet, in many                    places the Rock<ns0:lb /> is hollow, so that there are large Cavities<ns0:lb /> under                    where the water falls, quite dry.<ns0:lb /> from hence to <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName> 16 miles, from <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_019" n="   17" />                    <ns0:placeName key="bridg">Bridgeport</ns0:placeName> to <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> said place, the                    face of the Coun<ns0:lb /> -try has no remarkable variation, <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> is<ns0:lb />                    all the way a continual succession of hills<ns0:lb /> tho not so high and steep as                    about <ns0:placeName key="bridg">Bridge-<ns0:lb /> -port</ns0:placeName>, the Land gradually                    decreased in<ns0:lb /> its fertility, is all the way settled tho thinly, some<ns0:lb />                    fields of Wheat and rye looked very well, yet <ns0:lb />many others were poor, was                    generally heavy<ns0:lb /> Loaded with timber; the greatest body of<ns0:lb /> which was                    White Oak, Some Sugar Maple<ns0:lb /> along the low ground, yet the further to-<ns0:lb />                    -wards <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName> the scarcer, I have seen                    next<ns0:lb /> to no pine since I came over the Moun-<ns0:lb /> -tains; some Chesnut in                    places; but rails<ns0:lb /> are mostly made of White Oak; as are<ns0:lb /> there houses, —                    We had every little prospect<ns0:lb /> of <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName>, until we arrived near by,<ns0:lb /> the Town stands in a                    beautiful plain<ns0:lb /> surrounded by very high hills, just<ns0:lb /> about the Junktion                    of the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">Allegeny</ns0:geogName> and<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="monon">Monongahely Rivers</ns0:geogName>, Which Rivers when<ns0:lb />                    united make the <ns0:geogName key="ohior">Ohio</ns0:geogName>, we descended a very<ns0:lb />                    steep hill or Mountain to the <ns0:geogName key="monon">Mononga-<ns0:lb />                        -hela</ns0:geogName>, not fit for any Wagon to go up, or down,<ns0:lb /> though they                    often pass it, the river flows gently along <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_020" n="18" /> at the foot of this Mountain, where we                    Crossed<ns0:lb /> it, being half a mile wide and 10 or 12 feet<ns0:lb /> deep, this                        <ns0:geogName key="monon">River</ns0:geogName> is most in View from the<ns0:lb /> Town,                    and the greatest place of trading,<ns0:lb /> the Street next to sd River is                    beautifully<ns0:lb /> Situated, being level; 50 or 60 feet wide,<ns0:lb /> and elevated                    perhaps 50 feet above<ns0:lb /> the Water, there are places for Waggons<ns0:lb /> to go                    down, and a fine gravelly mar-<ns0:lb /> -gin to drive on, the town when we<ns0:lb /> were                    there was a place of great Concourse<ns0:lb /> abundance of People take their                    depar-<ns0:lb /> -ture from here to various parts of the<ns0:lb /> Western, and                    Southwestern Territories,<ns0:lb /> And up the <ns0:geogName key="beavr">big                        Bever</ns0:geogName>, the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">Allegeny<ns0:lb /> River</ns0:geogName>,                        <ns0:del>Friench</ns0:del>                    <ns0:geogName key="french">French Creek</ns0:geogName> to <ns0:placeName key="cusse">Casa-<ns0:lb /> -waga</ns0:placeName>, <ns0:placeName key="presq">Presqueisle</ns0:placeName> &c. — It was the time of<ns0:lb /> the supreme Court                    when we arrived here,<ns0:lb /> and we had some fears whether we should<ns0:lb /> get                    accommodations for ourselves and horses,<ns0:lb /> but having before we Crossed the                        <ns0:geogName key="monon">River</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> enquired for the best Tavern; we                    were<ns0:lb /> recommended to the Greentree near the<ns0:lb /> River, where upon our                    arrival after some <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_021" n="19" /> hesitation we were taken in, where                    we<ns0:lb /> found good accommodations. Some discou-<ns0:lb /> -ragements attended my mind                    on my way<ns0:lb /> thither, concerning the business we were<ns0:lb /> going on, it being                    in its self important,<ns0:lb /> to be transacted among a people of<ns0:lb /> a Strange                    language, in an unknown<ns0:lb /> and Wilderness Country, and a great un-<ns0:lb />                    -certainty how we should be able to get<ns0:lb /> the goods we have in care to our                    desir-<ns0:lb /> -ed port; but upon our arrival here,<ns0:lb /> and being introduced to                    some for whom<ns0:lb /> we had letters of Credit; we met with a<ns0:lb /> very kind                    reception, and they appear-<ns0:lb /> -ed hearty in assisting us, and <ns0:del>they</ns0:del>                    in-<ns0:lb /> -formed, that the goods sent from <ns0:placeName key="phila">Phila-<ns0:lb />                        -delphia</ns0:placeName> where safely arrived a few<ns0:lb /> days ago, and were in                    the Public Store.<ns0:lb /> The <ns0:figure>                        <ns0:figDesc>[drawing of a sun]</ns0:figDesc>                    </ns0:figure>                    <ns0:persName key="icrag1">Deputy Quarter Master</ns0:persName> informed us<ns0:lb /> that he                    would send them up to <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Cornplan-<ns0:lb /> -ter's                        Village</ns0:placeName>, which was at least 140 miles<ns0:lb /> by land, and                    abundantly more by Water.<ns0:lb /> that it was a very lucky time for them<ns0:lb /> to                    go, the River being neither to low nor <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_022" n="20" /> too high, so that the prospect of                    things<ns0:lb /> looks a little more lightsome.</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 11, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Had an interview with <ns0:persName key="gwilk2">General Wilken-<ns0:lb />                        -son</ns0:persName> this Morning, he recieved us very<ns0:lb /> respectfully,                    appeared well satisfied with<ns0:lb /> the business we were going on, and cheer-<ns0:lb />                    -fully disposed to Assist us in our undertak-<ns0:lb /> -ing, he gave us the                        <ns0:persName key="icrag1">Deputy Quarter Master</ns0:persName>,<ns0:lb /> who bore us                    company, direction in our<ns0:lb /> hearing to forward our goods to <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Cornplan-<ns0:lb /> -ter’s Settlement</ns0:placeName>, he kindly invited                    us to<ns0:lb /> come and take Dinner with him, which<ns0:lb /> kindness we acknowledged,                    but excused<ns0:lb /> ourselves on account of our Business.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> All hands were now employed in procuring<ns0:lb /> the necessary articles to be sent                    into the Indian<ns0:lb /> Country, <ns0:persName key="icrag">Isaac Crage</ns0:persName> the                    Deputy Quarter<ns0:lb /> Master, was very assistant, he provided<ns0:lb /> a Boat, Sent a                    Wagon to take our goods<ns0:lb /> from the Public Store, which was in the<ns0:lb /> Fort,                    and went with us there; he also sent<ns0:lb /> the Wagon to convey those we had                    pro-<ns0:lb /> -cured in different parts of the Town; we<ns0:lb /> got all our goods to                    the <ns0:del>Warf</ns0:del> Wharf,<ns0:lb /> Weighed, and put on board before evening, <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_023" n="21" /> the whole of those sent from <ns0:placeName key="phila">Philadelphia</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb /> and procured in this Town Weighed about<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>4</ns0:del>700, for which the Boatman was to have<ns0:lb /> 20/ Per £ for taking                    them up to <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Cornplanter’s<ns0:lb /> Village</ns0:placeName>, which                    we afterwards understood<ns0:lb /> from him was 270 miles by Water. He<ns0:lb /> agreed to                    set of with them in two or three<ns0:lb /> days, & let us know it would take him                    18 days<ns0:lb /> to go up the River to the Settlement.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">We expect to set off in the Morning, but<ns0:lb />have first to wait on <ns0:persName key="gwilk2">General Wilkinson</ns0:persName><ns0:lb /> on a particular occation                    before we Start.<ns0:lb /> This Town consists of a number of Streets, cross-<ns0:lb />                    -ing each other at right angles, and contains<ns0:lb /> more than 200 Houses, many of                        <ns0:del>whom</ns0:del> which are<ns0:lb /> large Brick and Stone Buildings, —I have<ns0:lb />                    observed since I came to this place, that Stone<ns0:lb /> Coal is the common fuel for                    Firing, our<ns0:lb /> landlord informed us it was the Cheapest,<ns0:lb /> though the                    neighborhood abounds with Wood,<ns0:lb /> it comes to the fire in large, hard                    pieces,<ns0:lb /> looks black and shining, and makes a<ns0:lb /> strong hot fire. I have                    frequently <ns0:del>saw</ns0:del> seen for 10 miles b<ns0:unclear>ack</ns0:unclear> at the                    sides<ns0:lb /> of Creeks &c where the Edges of the Rocks were<ns0:lb /> washed bare,                    stratums of Coal mixed with <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_024" n="22" /> Stratas of Slate.</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 13, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We were stiring betimes this morning, as our<ns0:lb /> bed was not inviting to                    indulge nature, and in<ns0:lb /> 7 ½ Miles we came to a poor Cabbin, here we<ns0:lb /> got                    some Oates for our horses, and let them<ns0:lb /> pick a little in the Woods, but we                    found<ns0:lb /> a great Change since we left Redstone, the<ns0:lb /> Season is abundantly                    backwards; the<ns0:lb /> leaves are but Just putting out, and there<ns0:lb /> is next to                    no picking of any kind in the<ns0:lb /> Woods, that it looks likely our horses will                    even <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_028" n="26" /> much Suffer when we get among the                    In-<ns0:lb /> -dians, if not before, We took breakfast of our own<ns0:lb /> provision, and                    proceeded on 12 miles fur-<ns0:lb /> -ther, where after feeding our horses, we took                    din-<ns0:lb /> -ner in like Manner, and got to <ns0:placeName key="ffran">Fort                            <ns0:del>Fr</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> Franklin</ns0:placeName> before <ns0:del>sunset</ns0:del> four O                    Clock, 14 ½ miles<ns0:lb /> pretty much fatigued, part of our road being<ns0:lb /> tedious                    and rough, and we sensibly felt the effect<ns0:lb /> of our poor nights rest. we met                    with but<ns0:lb /> few houses in this days ride, the Country<ns0:lb /> has been pretty                    level except about <ns0:geogName key="sandy">Sandy Creek</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> and since,                    which Creek we Crossed 3 miles<ns0:lb /> back, most of the Land in this days ride                    that<ns0:lb /> presented in view was of a thin Quality, and<ns0:lb /> in places very                    Stony, White Oak has been the<ns0:lb /> Principal Timber, with a large Quanty of<ns0:lb />                    Chesnut as we drew on this way, the greatest<ns0:lb /> part of which was bloom down                    for miles to-<ns0:lb /> -gether. — The town of <ns0:placeName key="frank">Franklin</ns0:placeName> is situated<ns0:lb /> close on the South Side of <ns0:geogName key="french">French Creek</ns0:geogName>,<ns0:lb /> it contains perhaps 10 or 12 log                    houses, they<ns0:lb /> were built under the Cover of an Old fort,<ns0:lb /> which is now                    demolished, and a new one<ns0:lb /> erected ½ a mile lower down the Creek Just<ns0:lb />                    above its Junction with the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">Allegeny                    River</ns0:geogName>.<ns0:lb /> after feeding our horses, and getting our dinner <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_029" n="27" /> two of us waited on <ns0:persName key="cfowl1">Captain Fowler</ns0:persName>, and<ns0:lb /> presented <ns0:persName key="gwilk2">General Wilkinson’s</ns0:persName> letter, which<ns0:lb /> upon his                    reading, he manifested great respect<ns0:lb /> and a full disposition to comply with                    its<ns0:lb /> contents, he kindly invited us to come<ns0:lb /> and take breakfast with him                    tomorrow<ns0:lb /> morning 35 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 14, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> This morning we breakfasted with the <ns0:persName key="cfowl1">Cap-<ns0:lb />                        -tain</ns0:persName> agreeably to his request, and got of<ns0:lb /> him 4 Bushels of                    Corn ½ a £ of flour and 2<ns0:lb /> Quarts of Salt, the Corn to feed our horses                    with,<ns0:lb /> through the Wildnerness, and the flour &c:<ns0:lb /> to take to the                        <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Indian Village</ns0:placeName>, and <ns0:persName key="jjohn1">Joseph<ns0:lb /> Johnson</ns0:persName> a Surveyor to the                        <ns0:orgName>Holland Company</ns0:orgName><ns0:lb /> who was going to the mouth of                        <ns0:geogName key="conew">Conowanga</ns0:geogName>, within<ns0:lb /> 15 miles of                        <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Cornplanter’s Village</ns0:placeName>, <ns0:del>he</ns0:del>                    agreed<ns0:lb /> to pilot us thither, and procure us a guide <ns0:del>we</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> from                    that place to the Village. after getting<ns0:lb /> our dinner at the Tavern where we                    put up<ns0:lb /> last evening, we took our departure, being<ns0:lb /> willing to leave                    this dear place, having had<ns0:lb /> to pay 3/ a meal for Victuals, 4/ a night<ns0:lb />                    for each of our horses <ns0:del>for</ns0:del> at very Coarse hay<ns0:lb /> 15/ a bushel for                    Corn, and Yesterday we had<ns0:lb /> to pay as high as 15/ a bushel for Oates.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We Crossed <ns0:geogName key="french">French Creek</ns0:geogName> close <ns0:del>creek</ns0:del>                    by the town I thoug[ht]<ns0:lb /> it was as large as three of <ns0:geogName key="brand">Brandywine</ns0:geogName>,<ns0:lb /> in 2 or more miles we turned to our right<ns0:lb />                    leaving the main road that leads to<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="cusse">Casawaga</ns0:placeName>, <ns0:placeName key="flebo">La                        Boeuf</ns0:placeName>, and <ns0:placeName key="presq">Preaque isle</ns0:placeName> to                    our left,<ns0:lb /> we had stones with a rough country for<ns0:lb /> a while, in places                    very poor, in about<ns0:lb /> 12 miles we crossed a rich bottom on a<ns0:lb /> small                    stream, here was plenty of pasture, being<ns0:lb /> the first we had seen in the                    Woods since<ns0:lb /> we left home, from thence to <ns0:geogName key="oilcr">Oyl                        Creek</ns0:geogName>                    <ns0:lb /> through level Rich land, 6 miles, here<ns0:lb /> we met with an house, being                    the second<ns0:lb /> we have seen since we left <ns0:placeName key="frank">franklin</ns0:placeName>,<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>here we</ns0:del> and took up our <ns0:del>horses</ns0:del> quarters, and<ns0:lb /> after                    feeding our horses with some Corn<ns0:lb /> turned them for the first time into                    the<ns0:lb /> Open Woods, there being plenty of Grass<ns0:lb /> and other luxuriant                    growths. This is the<ns0:lb /> most desirable place <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> I have seen                    for<ns0:lb /> many miles back, a fine fertile bottom on the <ns0:geogName key="oilcr">Creek</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> with plenty of level plough land adjoining,                    which<ns0:lb /> appeared good, a large stream of Water<ns0:lb /> not far of, and a noble                    Spring Just by the<ns0:lb /> door large enough to turn a Mill, yet it is not<ns0:lb />                    known that there is any limestone in this neigh <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_031" n="29" /> -bourhood, neither have I seen any since                    we<ns0:lb /> left <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName>. <ns0:geogName key="oilcr">Oyl Creek</ns0:geogName> is so named from<ns0:lb /> an Oyly substance                    that is gathered of its water<ns0:lb /> either from Springs that rises near its                    mar<ns0:lb /> -gin, or from off the stream in different pla-<ns0:lb /> -ces, we were                    informed that one man gather<ns0:lb /> -ed three Barrels last year, <ns0:del>and</ns0:del>                    which he sold <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> at<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pitts-Burgh</ns0:placeName> for four dollars Per Gallon, it                    is<ns0:lb /> called Seneca Oyl, and is in great demand<ns0:lb /> as medicine.</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 15, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> A large White frost which has been the si-<ns0:lb /> -tuation of the last 5 or 6                    mornings, set of for<ns0:lb /> Broken Straw a large water. about two miles<ns0:lb /> of                    very good land down the waters of <ns0:geogName key="oilcr">Oyl                    Creek</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> we then entered a White Pine Forrest, being<ns0:lb /> the first                    worth noting since we Crossed the<ns0:lb /> Mountains. here the <ns0:del>the</ns0:del>                    <ns0:orgName>Holland Company</ns0:orgName><ns0:lb /> is erecting a Grist Mill, a Sawmill                    being<ns0:lb /> already put up, though there are but few houses<ns0:lb /> within 20 miles.                    we have had a cut road ever<ns0:lb /> since we left <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName> to this place, which<ns0:lb /> now ending, we entered the                    Wilderness with<ns0:lb /> -out any path, a number of trees being <ns0:del>mar</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    marked last fall, they were now to be our<ns0:lb /> guide; it was a thick wood we had                    to pass<ns0:lb /> through, with a great quantity of brush, and<ns0:lb /> young stuff in                    the way, our Journey this day<ns0:lb /> was truly wild and romantic, having a <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_032" n="30" /> continual succession of Logs to Cross,                    sometime<ns0:lb /> three in a pearch, divers of which we had to<ns0:lb /> Jump our horses                    over, and with difficulty got<ns0:lb /> round others; in places such a <ns0:del>a                        large</ns0:del> Jumble<ns0:lb /> of large stone or Rocks, that we were in con<ns0:lb />                    -tinual danger of getting over Horses legs<ns0:lb /> fast, or broke in the Cavities                    between the Stones<ns0:lb /> presently we would have to descend banks<ns0:lb /> almost                    Perpendicular in Swamps, and<ns0:lb /> then out again as difficult, and there                        g<ns0:unclear>u</ns0:unclear>tts<ns0:lb /> were very frequent, the roots of the Pine<ns0:lb />                    and Hemlock trees were also very trou-<ns0:lb /> -blesome, the ground in many places                    being <ns0:del>was</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> laced over with them in a Rough Condi-<ns0:lb /> -tion, the                    underbrush and limbs of the<ns0:lb /> Trees were another very great difficulty,<ns0:lb />                    as were some very steep hills in the latter par[t]<ns0:lb /> of this stage, it was                    called 24 miles which<ns0:lb /> we thought were very long ones, for it<ns0:lb /> took us                    12 hours industrious traveling<ns0:lb /> including about an hour we turned our<ns0:lb />                    horses out to try to pick a little grass tho <ns0:del>but</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> next to none                    was to be seen in this days<ns0:lb /> ride, nor one house for 20 miles, the land<ns0:lb />                    was heavy timbered but not a kindly<ns0:lb /> soil, and I think will not be settled                    for many<ns0:lb /> years to come. many natural curiosities<ns0:lb /> presented in this                    days ride, one of which <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_033" n="31" /> was the large quantities of green                    moss<ns0:lb /> which covered all the Rocks, the Stones<ns0:lb /> the Old Logs and the                    whole surface of<ns0:lb /> the ground, under the thick forest of<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>the</ns0:del> Pine trees, I thought the Coat of<ns0:lb /> moss for thickness and                    length resembled<ns0:lb /> a fleece of Wool, some large rocks 12 or<ns0:lb /> more feet                    high, thus shielded over, and<ns0:lb /> receiving seed from the neighboring<ns0:lb />                    trees, which <ns0:del><ns0:unclear>the</ns0:unclear></ns0:del> seed haveing sprouted, took                    root,<ns0:lb /> and grew to be large trees, of 2 or 3<ns0:lb /> feet over, 3 or 4 such                    trees I have seen on one<ns0:lb /> Rock, and their Roots have spread down its<ns0:lb />                    sides 10 or more feet until they <ns0:del>underfeed</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> have joined the                    ground and grown firm there-<ns0:lb /> -in, so that the sides of the Rocks                        <ns0:del>has</ns0:del>                    <ns0:del>was</ns0:del> were bound<ns0:lb /> with them like so many large Ropes. We<ns0:lb />                    arrived on Broken Straw in the evening<ns0:lb /> where we found plenty of pasture for                    our<ns0:lb /> Horses, and a Cabbin, that was erected last<ns0:lb /> summer, the Owners of                    which kindly let<ns0:lb /> us have Quarters, and directed where the<ns0:lb /> best pasture                    on the Creek was, to turn<ns0:lb /> our horses too, we had provision with us                    which<ns0:lb /> after partaking of, we Spread ourselves<ns0:lb /> on the floor, to take                    some rest, which we<ns0:lb /> found Small enough for us and the family <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_034" n="32" />                    <ns0:del>and</ns0:del> the night being cold, and the Cabin<ns0:lb /> very open, we often had                    to rise to mend<ns0:lb /> our fire. 24 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 16, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Set of for the Mouth of <ns0:geogName key="conew">Conowango</ns0:geogName>, went<ns0:lb /> 7                    miles down the Eastside of <ns0:geogName key="broke">Brokenstraw</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> to                    the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">Allegeny River</ns0:geogName>, the bottoms on the<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="broke">Creek</ns0:geogName> was rich, and beautifully coated<ns0:lb />                    over with a luxuriant vegetation, and<ns0:lb /> loaded with lofty Pines, Sugar trees,                    White<ns0:lb /> Walnut, Buttonwood &c, here we saw several<ns0:lb /> Sugar Camps                    erected by the Indians, where<ns0:lb /> they come in the Season to make Sugar,                    tho<ns0:lb /> more than 20 miles from their Village, but<ns0:lb /> we found when amongst                    them that they have<ns0:lb /> plenty of good Canoes, so that the could with<ns0:lb />                    great facility convey their Kettles &c for<ns0:lb /> making Sugar, down the                        <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> and up this<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="broke">Creek</ns0:geogName>, we passed by two or more Cabins                        <ns0:del>Settlements</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>as</ns0:del> of white people as as we went down this <ns0:geogName key="broke">Creek</ns0:geogName>                    <ns0:del>to the River</ns0:del>,<ns0:lb /> but saw none after we turned up the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> to the mouth of <ns0:geogName key="conew">Conowanga</ns0:geogName>, where we arrived<ns0:lb /> about noon, it is called 18                    miles from this plac[e]<ns0:lb /> to <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Cornplanter’s                        Village</ns0:placeName>, and a very rough<ns0:lb /> road, so that we agreed to stay                    here until<ns0:lb /> morning, there being pretty plenty of<ns0:lb /> pasture for our                    horses, and a good house<ns0:lb /> for ourselves to Quarter in, though we had to find                    our own provision and sleep on the floor near the mouth <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_035" n="33" /> of this Creek on a beautiful dry plain                    there<ns0:lb /> is a Town laid out by the State of Pennsyl-<ns0:lb /> -vania, it is called                        <ns0:placeName key="warre">Warrentown</ns0:placeName>, the <ns0:orgName>Hol-<ns0:lb /> -land                        Company</ns0:orgName> owns a large body of land<ns0:lb /> adjoining this place which                    they are Surveying<ns0:lb /> into Townships &c. and settling, they have<ns0:lb />                    built a good house on a lot in sd Town, where<ns0:lb /> they keep a store to supply                    their Survey-<ns0:lb /> -ers and Settlers with Provision &c. <ns0:persName key="jjohn1">Joseph<ns0:lb /> Johnson</ns0:persName> our Pilot <ns0:del>have</ns0:del> had                    the charge of this<ns0:lb /> Store, and this was as far as he designed<ns0:lb /> going                    with us. When we arrived here we<ns0:lb /> met with perhaps 20 or more Indians,                    many<ns0:lb /> of whom were drunk, having obtained<ns0:lb /> liquor of some settlers that                    were at this<ns0:lb /> House intending in a few days to go up<ns0:lb /> the Creek to their                    destined spot, <ns0:persName key="jjohn1">Joseph John-<ns0:lb /> -son</ns0:persName>                    immediately put a stop to the selling<ns0:lb /> of Liquor, and informed us, that he                    and his<ns0:lb /> men had obtained from the use of <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> distilled spirits in                    there<ns0:lb /> surveying business last summer, as was the<ns0:lb /> practice of other                    surveyors in the <ns0:orgName>Holland</ns0:orgName><ns0:lb /> employ, and found they were                    better without<ns0:lb /> it. he agreed with a Young Indian who<ns0:lb /> was sober, and we                    were informed would not<ns0:lb /> get drunk, to Pilot us tomorrow to <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Cornplan-<ns0:lb /> -ter’s Village</ns0:placeName>, he was a good                    Countenanced lad, <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_036" n="34" /> and appeared pleased with the charge<ns0:lb />                    assigned him 15 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 17, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> A pleasant day, set off with our Indian guide<ns0:lb /> he could not talk English,                    nor understand<ns0:lb /> any that we knew of, in less than 2 miles<ns0:lb /> we Crossed                    the <ns0:geogName key="conew">Conowanga</ns0:geogName> a beautiful<ns0:lb /> Stream, which                    flowed along with a gentle<ns0:lb /> Current, we thought it was nearly as<ns0:lb /> large                    as <ns0:geogName key="french">French Creek</ns0:geogName>, for about two miles<ns0:lb />                    after we crossed this Water, <ns0:del>our</ns0:del> the land was<ns0:lb /> good, but from                    thence to the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">Allegeny Rive[r]</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> perhaps 8                    miles, we had a rough Mountainous<ns0:lb /> Country, and I think much of it a                    poor<ns0:lb /> thin Soil, <ns0:del>we had</ns0:del> with a number of very steep<ns0:lb /> hills to                    Ascend and descend, our road<ns0:lb /> was better Calculated for an Indian                    pat[h]<ns0:lb /> than traveling on horseback. <ns0:del>we had</ns0:del> there was a<ns0:lb />                    great abundance of Windfall timber to<ns0:lb /> cross, we thought on an averidge, one                    or<ns0:lb /> more for every two perch, some we could<ns0:lb /> get round, and others we                    jumped our horses over. When<ns0:lb /> we arrived on the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> we stopped a while<ns0:lb /> to let our horses eat grass, there                    being a great<ns0:lb /> plenty on some of its bottoms, which was<ns0:lb /> a pleasing                    sight, and had a tendency to re-<ns0:lb /> -move some fears, which attended when in                    the naked Woods<ns0:lb /> where no grass was to be seen, that our <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_037" n="35" /> Horses after their hard Journey, when we                    got a-<ns0:lb /> -mong the Indians must suffer for want of<ns0:lb /> provisions. while                    here a number of Indi-<ns0:lb /> -ans came by in Canoes, who stopped to see<ns0:lb /> us,                    Shook hands with us, and looked pleasant.<ns0:lb /> one man came down the Mountain to                    us with<ns0:lb /> a large turkey on his back, which he had<ns0:lb /> Just Shot, we thought                    it would have weigh-<ns0:lb /> -ed more than 20 <ns0:del>Lb</ns0:del>. the sight of this                    convey-<ns0:lb /> -ed an Idea that small game was plenty a-<ns0:lb /> -mongst them, and it                    was likely we should<ns0:lb /> come in for Shares, one of the Canoes also<ns0:lb /> had a                    quantity of fine fish in it. but we<ns0:lb /> found when amongst them that a                    Turkey<ns0:lb /> was very seldom taken, or any other small<ns0:lb /> game, & it is                    rare to see a Squirel in the<ns0:lb /> Wilderness, we saw some pheasants, but no<ns0:lb />                    partridges, <ns0:del>neither did we see fish</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>while amongst them but once</ns0:del>. After<ns0:lb /> a short conference on the                    weighty business<ns0:lb /> we were embarked in, we proceeded up<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>, not without some exercise of<ns0:lb /> Mind, and                    would have been glad <ns0:del>to</ns0:del> we could have<ns0:lb /> sent a messenger forward                    to have inform-<ns0:lb /> -ed the Chiefs of our coming, but this was out<ns0:lb /> of our                    power, for none of the Indians we<ns0:lb /> had met with could talk English, we                    there- <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_038" n="36" /> -fore moved forward with or minds                    atten-<ns0:lb /> -tive to best direction, when we came in<ns0:lb /> sight of the town,                    many Indians appear<ns0:lb /> -ed in view, looking toward <ns0:del>at</ns0:del> us, our                    guide<ns0:lb /> turned into the first Cabin he came to,<ns0:lb /> and would go no further,                    but point-<ns0:lb /> -ed to <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName>’s house, we                    paid him<ns0:lb /> one dollar <ns0:del>for what he had done</ns0:del>, and<ns0:lb /> moved                    forward; we presently saw the<ns0:lb /> Chief with a number of other Indians<ns0:lb />                    coming toward us, upon our riding up<ns0:lb /> to them and alighting, they appeared                    to<ns0:lb /> welcome us with open Countenances.<ns0:lb /> we did not know <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName>, nor could we distin-<ns0:lb /> -guish him by                    his dress, but upon shaking<ns0:lb /> hands with one that stood foremast we                        <ns0:del>as</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> Asked if <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> he was <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName>, he in-<ns0:lb /> -formed us, in his, way that he was                        <ns0:del>the</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>man</ns0:del>, after shaking hands with them<ns0:lb /> all round, we were conducted                    to his house<ns0:lb /> which was not distinguished from the rest, only                    <ns0:del>but</ns0:del>by being<ns0:lb /> larger, <ns0:del>and</ns0:del> after unsaddling our                    horses,<ns0:lb /> and carrying in our Baggage, and be-<ns0:lb /> -ing seated, <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName>, his Son <ns0:persName key="habee1">Henry</ns0:persName><ns0:lb /> and Several others came in & sat down, <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_039" n="37" /> The Chief presently asked us, if we                    would<ns0:lb /> like to see his people in general Council,<ns0:lb /> we let him know                        <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> we would, as soon<ns0:lb /> as it was Convenient, <ns0:del>and</ns0:del>                    tomorrow at<ns0:lb /> 10 OClock was therefore fixed on <ns0:del>for the time</ns0:del>;                    and<ns0:lb /> runners dispatched immediately <ns0:del>for</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>that purpose</ns0:del>. to give notice. It was two O’clock when<ns0:lb /> we arrived                    here, and sometime after the<ns0:lb /> above Conference, <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> came into<ns0:lb /> our apartment, and asked us if we                    could<ns0:lb /> eat in the Indian way, we informed him we ex-<ns0:lb /> -pected we could,                        <ns0:del>and</ns0:del> he presently <ns0:del>we had some</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>Dinner</ns0:del> brought in some dinner in a bark bowl, and<ns0:lb /> a Tin kettle,                    the bowl was placed on the<ns0:lb /> seat beside us, and the kettle on the                    ground<ns0:lb /> before us, and we were invited to eat, we<ns0:lb /> saw the bowl, and the                    kettle, but what<ns0:lb /> was in either of them we knew not, or<ns0:lb /> whether they                    were to be eaten together, or<ns0:lb /> separate, the bowl contained a number of<ns0:lb />                    round lumps of something tied in Corn<ns0:del>hu</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> -husks, two dumplings                    were tyed in one<ns0:lb /> set of husks, with a string at each end<ns0:lb /> and in the                    middle, we let them know that our<ns0:lb /> Ignorance was such, we did not know                    how<ns0:lb /> to begin, which set some of the younger sort <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_040" n="38" /> a laughing, but the Chief took<ns0:lb /> out                    his knife, for they had set neither knives,<ns0:lb /> forks, or spoons, and taking up                    the<ns0:lb /> Dumplins he cut one of them in too,<ns0:lb /> then striping up the                    Cornhusks, <ns0:del>with</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>his knife</ns0:del> he cut off a piece of the dump<ns0:lb /> -lin, and                        <ns0:del>and</ns0:del>                    <ns0:del>which</ns0:del> diped it <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> in the Kettle, which<ns0:lb /> we found                        <ns0:del>after</ns0:del> contained Bears Oyl, and<ns0:lb /> eat it, we followed the                    example, and made<ns0:lb /> a light meal, the Bears Oyl was Cold and<ns0:lb /> not                    grateful to our Pallates, but we have<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>seen</ns0:del> since, seen this way of eating is often prac-<ns0:lb /> -ticed among                    them; the Cold Indian Bread<ns0:lb /> dipped in the Oyl is more frequently used.</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 18, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Last evening after we had lain down to<ns0:lb /> rest, <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> and his son <ns0:persName key="habee1">Henry</ns0:persName><ns0:lb /> came into our apartment , and informed                    <ns0:del>let</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> us <ns0:del>know</ns0:del> he would like to know what we intended to                    say to his<ns0:lb /> people in Council, we <ns0:del>informed</ns0:del> told him we would<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>give him an Opportunity of</ns0:del> inform<ns0:del>ation</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> >him in the                    Morning, which this morning we<ns0:lb /> complied with, <ns0:del>we</ns0:del> and let him                    know we could<ns0:lb /> not tell all <ns0:del>what</ns0:del> that we should say, for we                    be-<ns0:lb /> -lieved on such occasions it was right to<ns0:lb /> wait on the good spirit                    to be directed.<ns0:lb /> We read to him the Certificate sent by<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>us from</ns0:del> the Indian Committee which <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_041" n="39" /> particularly pointed out our                    business,<ns0:lb /> also <ns0:persName key="gwilk2">General Wilkinson</ns0:persName>’s                    Letter, with which<ns0:lb /> he appeared satisfied, his son <ns0:persName key="habee1">Henry</ns0:persName><ns0:lb /> who has had an English Education in<ns0:lb /> and about                    Philadelphia, enterpretted<ns0:lb /> for us, for his Father can neither speak<ns0:lb />                    nor understand English, <ns0:persName key="habee1">Henry</ns0:persName> was our<ns0:lb />                    enterpretter on all occations whilst a-<ns0:lb /> -mongst them, he was not ready, and                    we<ns0:lb /> believe the business we went on suffer-<ns0:lb /> -ed <ns0:del>some</ns0:del> for                        <ns0:del><ns0:gap /></ns0:del> want of one better qualifyed<ns0:lb /> about 12 O’clock between                    30 and 40 of their principal<ns0:lb /> men met in council, which Council <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> open<ns0:lb /> -ed by a short speech,                    expressing his satisfaction<ns0:lb /> on seeing us coming riding through the                    bushes,<ns0:lb /> and that it was the good spirit which preserv-<ns0:lb /> -ed us in our                    long journey, for which they were<ns0:lb /> very glad. He then informed us of their                    Poverty, the<ns0:lb /> poorness of their houses which were covered with<ns0:lb /> bark,                    and their inability to make good ones, we<ns0:lb /> thought the latter part of this                    speech was calculat-<ns0:lb /> -ed to draw our Charity. he then let us know<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> they were all met <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> who were <ns0:del>were</ns0:del>                    likely to attend,<ns0:lb /> that their Women could not come, but the Men<ns0:lb /> would                    let them know what we said to them: we<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>had</ns0:del> having particularly requested their Women might at-<ns0:lb /> -tend.                    We then opened our business by letting <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_042" n="40" /> them know the love of their Old Friends                    the<ns0:lb /> Quakers have for them, and our willingness<ns0:lb /> to take a long Journey                    to see them, some of us<ns0:lb /> having left Loving Wives, and tender Child-<ns0:lb />                    -ren, with Comfortable dwellings, and ex-<ns0:lb /> -posed ourselves to the hardships                    and difficulties of a<ns0:lb /> perilous Journey, with no other view than<ns0:lb /> for                    their improvement. We then read the E-<ns0:lb /> -pistle or instrumental of writing                    the Committee sent,<ns0:lb /> which particularly opened the design, and cause<ns0:lb /> of                    our coming amongst them, it was read by para-<ns0:lb /> -graphs and interpreted with                    some difficulty.<ns0:lb /> We next read <ns0:persName key="gwilk2">General                        Wilkinson</ns0:persName>’s letter, then<ns0:lb /> droped some advice, wishing them,                    when the took<ns0:lb /> our proposals into consideration, they would<ns0:lb /> guard                    against discouragements, that might<ns0:lb /> present, in their looking forward,                    towards<ns0:lb /> a change in their manner, of living for we did not<ns0:lb /> doubt but                    there might be many difficultie<ns0:lb /> in their way, and their progress might be                    slow<ns0:lb /> yet there are accounts in the Writings<ns0:lb /> amongst the White people,                    of a people who<ns0:lb /> lived beyond the great waters, in an-<ns0:lb /> -other Island,                    who a many years ago lived<ns0:lb /> much like they do now, yet were <ns0:del>no</ns0:del> by                    in-<ns0:lb /> -dustry and care <ns0:gap /> become very good<ns0:lb /> Farmers, and Mechanicks                    of all kinds <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_043" n="41" /> and from that people, many of those                    fine<ns0:lb /> Leggons, with the other striped and nice Cloath-<ns0:lb /> -ing they had                    on, came.* upon our letting them<ns0:lb /> know we had nothing more to say                    amongst<ns0:lb /> them at this time, they informed us they would<ns0:lb /> take our                    proposals into consideration and<ns0:lb /> give us an answer tomorrow.</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 19, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">                    <ns0:del>The Indians were this day in Council on<ns0:lb /> the business we had laid                        before them, they<ns0:lb /> divers times sent their deputies for us to<ns0:lb />                        explain some part of the business we had<ns0:lb /> opened to them, one of their                        questions was<ns0:lb /> how they should draw their Plough if the</ns0:del></ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> *We then let them know <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> we had a boat com-<ns0:lb /> -ing up the                        <ns0:geogName key="alleg">Allegeny River</ns0:geogName>, with various<ns0:lb /> kinds of                    goods, among which were a num-<ns0:lb /> -ber of Ploughirons, Hoes, axes, Shovels                    and<ns0:lb /> Spades, with Carpenters, Masons, and Coopers<ns0:lb /> tools, which we                    intended never to take a-<ns0:lb /> -way but leave amongst them, but while<ns0:lb /> our                    Young staid, they should be placed<ns0:lb /> under their care, to lend out to them                    as<ns0:lb /> the wanted, and, when done with them, to be return-<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>them</ns0:del> -ed. </ns0:p>

text.headline: May 19, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> The Indians were this day in Council<ns0:lb /> on the business we laid before them,                        <ns0:del>they</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> they divers times sent their Deputies for<ns0:lb /> us to                    explain some part of the business <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_044" n="42" /> we had opened to them, one of their                    ques-<ns0:lb /> -tions was, how they should draw their<ns0:lb /> Ploughs, seeing they had                    no Oxen, we<ns0:lb /> let them know we had seen two Horses run-<ns0:lb /> -ing about their                    Town, and that was <ns0:del>e</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> enough to draw one Plough, and                        <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> if<ns0:lb /> they would save some of the Money they<ns0:lb /> were to                    get of the White People they might<ns0:lb /> buy a pair of Oxen, and they would                    draw<ns0:lb /> another Plough; and that our young men<ns0:lb /> would lend them there                    Horses sometimes,<ns0:lb /> that we did not expect any great matters from<ns0:lb /> them                    at first, and that these would do to make<ns0:lb /> a beginning, with this answer                    they appear-<ns0:lb /> -ed pretty well satisfyed, tho we thought it<ns0:lb /> was very                    evident it was not such an one<ns0:lb /> as the Question was artfully calculated<ns0:lb />                    for. at another time the told us we must<ns0:lb /> wait with Patience for an answer,                    for<ns0:lb /> it was a great thing, and they were all<ns0:lb /> consulting about it in                    their Houses. About<ns0:lb /> five OClock they informed us they were nearly<ns0:lb />                    ready to give us an answer, and wished to know<ns0:lb /> if it would suit us this                    evening, we let them<ns0:lb /> know <ns0:del>tha</ns0:del> we were waiting their time, but                    as<ns0:lb /> the day was far spent, left it with them to<ns0:lb /> Judge whether this                    evening would be suitable.<ns0:lb /> about Six 30 of them met us, the opportunity <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_045" n="43" /> I thought was owned, a degree of                    solemnity at-<ns0:lb /> -tending, and after a short pause <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName><ns0:lb /> opened the Council, the following being                    the<ns0:lb /> substance of his speech.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We exchanged our satisfaction with their an-<ns0:lb /> -swer and let them know our                    young <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_047" n="45" /> Men would want a house to live in, and                    a<ns0:lb /> piece of good Land to work, that so they<ns0:lb /> may be able to raise their                    bread. For<ns0:lb /> which purpose we <ns0:del>wanted</ns0:del> desired some of their<ns0:lb />                    Chiefs would <ns0:del>to</ns0:del> go with us, to look about their Coun-<ns0:lb /> -try, and                    conclude where would be most ad-<ns0:lb /> -vantageous to the nation for our                    young<ns0:lb /> men to settle <ns0:del>down on</ns0:del>, and that we <ns0:del>would</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    wished to see their nation in general<ns0:lb /> Council once more before we left                    them.<ns0:lb /> Upon our letting them know we had no<ns0:lb /> more to say, <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> desired his<ns0:lb /> People would all come                    and shake hand<ns0:lb /> with us, he himself first setting the ex-<ns0:lb /> -ample, </ns0:p>

text.headline: May 21, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> got up soon this morning to bake some<ns0:lb /> bread, that we might be in readiness                    by 7<ns0:lb /> OClock, to go up the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> about 10                    miles<ns0:lb /> with some of the Chiefs, to see were it would<ns0:lb /> be most suitable                    to make a settlement, we<ns0:lb /> found it a trying Circumstance rightly<ns0:lb /> to                    Judge what was best to do on the Occa-<ns0:lb /> -tion. <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Jeneocatego</ns0:placeName> the Town where we now<ns0:lb /> are, being the place of                        <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanters</ns0:persName> re- <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_049" n="47" /> -sidence, is in the middle of a good                    spot<ns0:lb /> of Land, in <ns0:placeName key="penns">Pennsylvania</ns0:placeName> on the                    West<ns0:lb /> side of the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">Allegeny River</ns0:geogName>, about                    five<ns0:lb /> miles South of the <ns0:placeName key="newyo">New York</ns0:placeName> line,                    the said<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Tract</ns0:placeName> is <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanters</ns0:persName> own privet pro-<ns0:lb /> -perty containing, including                    two Islands,<ns0:lb /> near 800 acres Acres, on this Tract <ns0:del>most</ns0:del> and                    near<ns0:lb /> it, most of the Indians under his superin-<ns0:lb /> -tendency lives,                    which, with the goodness<ns0:lb /> of this Land, being a fine fertile soil,<ns0:lb /> was                    a weighty consideration of making<ns0:lb /> this the place of settlement, there                    are<ns0:lb /> also a large number of Children here<ns0:lb /> fit for schooling, so that                    with much con-<ns0:lb /> -veniency a large school might be<ns0:lb /> made up, but to                    ballance these advan-<ns0:lb /> -tages, we considered the Land was pri-<ns0:lb /> -vet                    property, and if we made improv-<ns0:lb /> -ments , such as building a house and<ns0:lb />                    Barn, and Cleared land, when we left<ns0:lb /> it they would all belong to <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplan-<ns0:lb /> -ter</ns0:persName>, and not to the nation; also if                    the<ns0:lb /> Indians where to clear land and fence<ns0:lb /> lots, they would not
