belong                    to the Nati-<ns0:lb /> -on. this consideration made us believe<ns0:lb /> it would be best                    to look elsewhere. – <ns0:lb /> The Nation owns 42 Square miles on this <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_050" n="48" />                    <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>, beginning at the <ns0:placeName key="penns">Pennsylvania</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb /> Line, the lines of the reservation is<ns0:lb />                    not yet Run, but we found the Indians<ns0:lb /> have a choice that it should ly on the<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>, half a mile wide on each side.<ns0:lb />                    about 9 miles from hence up the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> lat-<ns0:lb />                    -terly stood a Town called <ns0:placeName key="genes1">Genesinguh-<ns0:lb />                        -ta</ns0:placeName>, the Inhabitants of which Village a<ns0:lb /> few years since                    mostly removed here,<ns0:lb /> about 10 miles further up the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> we<ns0:lb /> understood a settlement had latterly<ns0:lb /> been                    made, from the best information<ns0:lb /> we could get, thought somewhere a-<ns0:lb />                    -bout the <ns0:placeName key="genes1">Old Town</ns0:placeName> would be the most<ns0:lb />                    suitable place to fix on, it being about<ns0:lb /> half way between the upper                    settlement and<ns0:lb /> lower Town, according with consider-<ns0:lb /> -able exertion                    about 9 OClock we got <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplan-<ns0:lb /> -ter</ns0:persName>, his                    son <ns0:persName key="habee1">Henry</ns0:persName>, and three other<ns0:lb /> Indians to                    embark with us five in<ns0:lb /> a Canoe, they put us up the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> with<ns0:lb /> setting Poles at the Rate of 3 miles an                    hour.<ns0:lb /> in places the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> was Shallow                    and<ns0:lb /> ran rapid, in other places from two<ns0:lb /> to six feet deep, we pased by                    a num-<ns0:lb /> -ber of Islands, some pretty large, which<ns0:lb /> appeared rich, were                    grown over with grass<ns0:lb /> and other herbage very luxuriant, the <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_051" n="49" /> flats on each side of the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> appeared<ns0:lb /> much of the same quality, tho                    none of them<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>appeared</ns0:del> were wide; in about 6 miles we<ns0:lb /> came to <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanters</ns0:persName> sawmill, we stop-<ns0:lb /> -ed at his                    request and viewed it, the<ns0:lb /> Mill is almost new, built on a Small<ns0:lb />                    Stream, which when we were there<ns0:lb /> was so low that the Mill could do                    very<ns0:lb /> little work, and at the time of Year <ns0:del>that</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> the Stream                    is pretty full, the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> is<ns0:lb /> often so high                    that it hurts the mill with<ns0:lb /> its backwater, in about three miles fur-<ns0:lb />                    -ther up the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> we came to the <ns0:placeName key="genes1">Old<ns0:lb /> Town</ns0:placeName>, three or more families yet re-<ns0:lb />                    -main here, we thought there might be<ns0:lb /> 150 or more acres of a flat that has                    been<ns0:lb /> mostly cleared and worked with Corn,<ns0:lb /> part of which is grown up                    with Hazels<ns0:lb /> &c and part with grass, that in a few <ns0:del>wee</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    weeks would do to mow, and some of the<ns0:lb /> richest sorts of it are put in                    with<ns0:lb /> Corn this Spring; it doth not appear to<ns0:lb /> have ever been fenced,                    and at certain<ns0:lb /> stretches <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> is mostly subject to an overflow.<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> the tract lies on the Northwest side of the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>.<ns0:lb /> the flat is about 40 reaches wide, and then <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_052" n="50" /> commences Timber Land, mostly White<ns0:lb />                    Pine, suitable for building, or Railtim-<ns0:lb /> -ber, which Timberland within 60                    perch-<ns0:lb /> -es of the flat we thought pretty good, lies<ns0:lb /> very well to the                    sun, with a gentle Assent,<ns0:lb /> and clear of stones; when Viewing this<ns0:lb />                    land, and taking its local situation in<ns0:lb /> -to consideration, we were united                    in<ns0:lb /> believing, that somewhere <ns0:del>about</ns0:del> near<ns0:lb /> this place would be                    best to make our<ns0:lb /> settlement; upon informing two of the Chiefs<ns0:lb /> who bore                    us company, that we thought<ns0:lb /> across the upper end of the cleared flat                    from<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> back, taking in part of the                    Wood-<ns0:lb /> -land, would be suitable for our purpose,<ns0:lb /> and that if they liked                    it, to tell us, and if the did not<ns0:lb /> like it, tell us so, and we would look                    farther<ns0:lb /> where it would suit them better, they said the<ns0:lb /> had informed us                        <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> all their Land was be-<ns0:lb /> -fore us and that we might take                    it where we liked <ns0:del>it</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> best, and expressed their full                    satisfaction<ns0:lb /> with our choice, <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName>                    then said, this man,<ns0:lb /> meaning one of the Chiefs that was with us,<ns0:lb /> lives                    in this <ns0:placeName key="genes1">Town</ns0:placeName>, and he is like one of<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>us, he</ns0:del> you, a sober man, & drinks no Whiskey, and he is very<ns0:lb />                    glad <ns0:del>our</ns0:del> the young men are coming to live <ns0:del>a-</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>-mongst them</ns0:del> so near him. We informed the Chiefs that<ns0:lb /> our Young                    men would want timber for <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_053" n="51" /> to build a House, for Rails, and for                    fire-<ns0:lb /> -Wood, to which they readily consented, say-<ns0:lb /> -ing, they would be                    very glad they would cut<ns0:lb /> all the Trees down, and further Liberty<ns0:lb /> they                    would give them, if they saw a Buck<ns0:lb /> swimming across the River, or                    running<ns0:lb /> through the Woods they might shoot him<ns0:lb /> or if they saw any fish                    in the River they<ns0:lb /> might <ns0:del>cath</ns0:del> catch them, we then returned<ns0:lb />                    down the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> with <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> to his <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Village</ns0:placeName>                </ns0:p>

text.headline: May 22, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> This Morning resumed the consideration of what farther pro-<ns0:lb /> -positions we                    should make to these people<ns0:lb /> in order to their additional encourag-<ns0:lb />                    -ment in Civilization and Aggreculture,<ns0:lb /> and mutually agreed upon some,                    which will<ns0:lb /> be inserted in their proper place. –-</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> This afternoon <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> presented us<ns0:lb />                    with several kinds of seed Corn suitable for<ns0:lb /> this Climet; divers kinds of                    beans, and<ns0:lb /> Garden seeds, such as Watermelons, Pump-<ns0:lb /> -kins, Cucumbers                    &c with a quantity of<ns0:lb /> Potatoes for to Plant, these he said had                    been<ns0:lb /> sent in from the different houses as a<ns0:lb /> blessing to begin with, we                    thought the<ns0:lb /> hearty good will with which these were<ns0:lb /> presented                    manifested a full approba-<ns0:lb /> -tion with our undertaking, there were<ns0:lb /> more                    of each sort, except potatoes than we <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_054" n="52" /> wanted to plant, and upon informing<ns0:lb />                    him so we were answered, that we<ns0:lb /> must take them all, for they were<ns0:lb />                    sent in for that purpose. </ns0:p>

text.headline: May 23, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We are now our own Cooks, dishwashers &c<ns0:lb /> Lining on our provisions that                    we brought with us<ns0:lb /> from <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName> and                        <ns0:placeName key="frank">Franklin</ns0:placeName>, <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName>                    <ns0:del>ear-</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>ly</ns0:del> informed us early after our arrival <ns0:del>how</ns0:del> that<ns0:lb /> they                    were scarce of Corn, occationed as he<ns0:lb /> said by an uncommon overflow of the<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> last Spring, sometime after their<ns0:lb />                    Corn was come up, and by an early Frost<ns0:lb /> in the Fall. When enquiring for                        <ns0:del>meat</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> Bacon at <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName>                    to send up in the<ns0:lb /> boat, we were informed that it was unne-<ns0:lb /> -cessary to                    carry <ns0:del>send</ns0:del> meat here, for there<ns0:lb /> was a plenty in this place,                    however<ns0:lb /> we thought <ns0:del>but</ns0:del> not best to trust to an un-<ns0:lb />                    -certainty, and have therefore 120 Lb<ns0:lb /> of Bacon coming up in the Boat.                    upon<ns0:lb /> enquiry since we came here, we find <ns0:del>me</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> meat is not to                    be Obtained, about one<ns0:lb /> pound of dryed meat, and four pounds<ns0:lb /> fresh is                    all we got of the Indians while<ns0:lb /> amongst them, so that the prospect of                    things <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_055" n="53" /> as to provision looked a little gloomy,                        <ns0:del>ou</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> our Boat <ns0:del>is</ns0:del> not being expected up in less                    than<ns0:lb /> 9 or 10 days from this date, but upon <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Corn-<ns0:lb /> -planters</ns0:persName> informing, that he had several                        <ns0:del>three</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> Barrels of flour in his House, that<ns0:lb /> he brought up                    from <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName>, and<ns0:lb /> when ever we got                    out of meat, on lit-<ns0:lb /> -ting him know, he would supply us; we<ns0:lb /> felt                    relieved. We agreed with Cornplan-<ns0:lb /> -ters sister to supply us with three                    Quarts<ns0:lb /> of Milk a day at 8 Per Quart York Cur-<ns0:lb /> -rency, but she presenly                    let us know<ns0:lb /> two quarts was as much as she could<ns0:lb /> spare. We also got one                    pound of but-<ns0:lb /> -ter, such as it was, of her, at 2/. The Chief gave us<ns0:lb />                    some Sugar, and some we purchased of<ns0:lb /> the Indians at 1/6 Per Lb. we have a                    pret-<ns0:lb /> -ty Comfortable House much to ourselves, <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Corn-<ns0:lb /> -planter</ns0:persName> has two Houses they stand about<ns0:lb /> 10 feet                    apart, tho Roofed over between as the <ns0:del>o</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> other parts of the House                    which is with<ns0:lb /> Bark, this Space between the Houses serves<ns0:lb /> for an entry,                    and a place to pound their<ns0:lb /> Corn <ns0:del>under</ns0:del> put their Wood &c. out                    of<ns0:lb /> this entry a door opens into each <ns0:del>apart</ns0:del>                    <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_056" n="54" /> apartment, that asigned us 30 feet<ns0:lb />                    long, the other 24, and each 16 feet wide.<ns0:lb /> they are built of Round Logs, or                    Poles,<ns0:lb /> let in close together, the net Chunked<ns0:lb /> or plaistered, so that                    we found our<ns0:lb /> end pretty open and cold enough before<ns0:lb /> morning, upon our                    informing the Chief<ns0:lb /> they had better make their Houses titeer,<ns0:lb />                    plaistering up the Cracks, he replyed<ns0:lb /> if they made their Houses too                    warm,<ns0:lb /> they would not like to leave them when<ns0:lb /> Winter came to go a                    hunting. along<ns0:lb /> each side of these Houses, from the door<ns0:lb /> to the                    opposite end, ran Births, or<ns0:lb /> Seats, they were about four feet wide<ns0:lb /> and                    one foot high, they were covered<ns0:lb /> with Boards, and on these Deer-<ns0:lb /> skins                    were spread, and these were<ns0:lb /> their Beds, they also make a pretty<ns0:lb /> good                    Seat, and are always ready,<ns0:lb /> over these Births, about five feet<ns0:lb /> high,                    are Shelves of the same width<ns0:lb /> of <ns0:del>those</ns0:del> the births                        <ns0:del>beneath</ns0:del>, which serve to put <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_057" n="55" /> their Kitchen furniture, Corn &c                    upon,<ns0:lb /> the fire is built on the ground in the<ns0:lb /> Middle of the House, this                    part between<ns0:lb /> the births not being floored; there is a large<ns0:lb /> hole left                    in the Top of the Roof for<ns0:lb /> the Smoke to go out at, which hole<ns0:lb /> makes a                    pretty good Window. -– As<ns0:lb /> far as I have observed the above descrip-<ns0:lb />                    -tion answers for most of their Houses, tho<ns0:lb /> they are not so large, nor                    double, like this, they<ns0:lb /> are mostly from 12 to 15 feet Square,<ns0:lb /> with a                    shed before the door, there<ns0:lb /> are perhaps 30 such houses in this <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Village</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb /> and a number more down the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> out of Sight, and some above, the<ns0:lb />                    Houses are beautifully situated on<ns0:lb /> the West side of the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>, which<ns0:lb /> is about 150 Yards wide and                    glides<ns0:lb /> along by the <ns0:placeName key="cornp">town</ns0:placeName> with a gentle                    current.<ns0:lb /> the bank of the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> is low, tho                    gra-<ns0:lb /> -dually asscends to there Houses, which are<ns0:lb /> mostly within 6 or 7                    pearchs so that they<ns0:lb /> readily supply themselves with Water <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_058" n="56" /> there being no springs on the flat                    where<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Town</ns0:placeName> stands, which flat is a                    Sandy<ns0:lb /> loam, easily tilled , and if well managed<ns0:lb /> would be very                    productive. there are 50<ns0:lb /> or 60 Acres of Land adjoining the <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Town</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb /> nearly cleared, the most of                        <ns0:del>this</ns0:del> which is put<ns0:lb /> in Yearly with Corn, Beans, and                    Potatoes.<ns0:lb /> the Work is all done by the Women with<ns0:lb /> Hoes, they were very                    busy while we were<ns0:lb /> here, much of the Land was grown up<ns0:lb /> with Grass,                    with Weeds &c, they go round<ns0:lb /> the Old Cornhills, which were very high,                    as<ns0:lb /> I have observed it is the general practice<ns0:lb /> to have a hill when                    finished near one foot<ns0:lb /> high, and hoe the grass and weeds clean<ns0:lb /> away,                    then dig a hole where the hill stood<ns0:lb /> and plant in the same place, and                    sometime after<ns0:lb /> the Corn comes up, the hoe all the face of<ns0:lb /> the ground                    over, so that it looked very<ns0:lb /> neat. they plant beans with their Corn, also                    a<ns0:lb /> large quantity that they stick poles for,<ns0:lb /> they also plant Squashes                    and Pumpkins among<ns0:lb /> their corn - The Women since we came here worked<ns0:lb />                    hard, they found all their Corn, for homi-<ns0:lb /> -ny, and for Bread, sift and                    prepare it,<ns0:lb /> Cut and Split all their Wood, and Carry<ns0:lb /> it home on their                    backs near a Quarter of <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_059" n="57" /> a Mile, make all there fires, and                    all<ns0:lb /> other Kitchen Business, plant and take<ns0:lb /> care of their corn, and                    gather it when ready,<ns0:lb /> Plant their Beans and stick them, and<ns0:lb /> as far as                    I can learn all other out<ns0:lb /> doors work, except building their houses<ns0:lb /> and                    Splitting the Rails that the Corn<ns0:lb /> Land is enclosed with. It has been a<ns0:lb />                    busy time since we came here, the Wo-<ns0:lb /> -men have rose early, gone out                    with<ns0:lb /> their hoes to the Cornfield 4 or 5 in a<ns0:lb /> Company, some of whom                    where Old Gray<ns0:lb /> Headed Women, and some young ones of<ns0:lb /> 8, 10, or 12 Years                    of age, stuck pretty<ns0:lb /> Close to their Work, returned in the even-<ns0:lb /> -ing                    weary, and go early to Bed. one<ns0:lb /> old Gray Headed Woman I have seen<ns0:lb />                    steadily on the move, she has had both<ns0:lb /> her feet so froze that she goes                    altogether<ns0:lb /> on her knees, I have seen her carrying<ns0:lb /> in wood and making                    the fire, going to the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">Ri-<ns0:lb /> -ver</ns0:geogName> and                    Bringing up water, I have seen<ns0:lb /> take her hoe and go 40 pearches out to <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_060" n="58" /> the Cornfield, and return in the                    Even-<ns0:lb /> -ing with the Labourers, and put her<ns0:lb /> hoe by, and all this while                    the Men are<ns0:lb /> spending their time in Idleness, such as<ns0:lb /> shooting with                    their bows and Arrows at a<ns0:lb /> mark which is a very great recreation<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>with them,</ns0:del> pitching of Queats, Jumping,<ns0:lb /> playing at some kind of                    Games, and on<ns0:lb /> Musical Instruments, and loitering about<ns0:lb /> so that I have                    not while in this <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Village</ns0:placeName> seen<ns0:lb /> either                    Man or Boy at any kind of Work,<ns0:lb /> to se little Girls, and Old Women                    working<ns0:lb /> hard with the hoe, and boys of 12, 14, or 16<ns0:lb /> just by them all                    day a playing, looked<ns0:lb /> unnatural, hard, and to me very grevi-<ns0:lb /> -ous. The                    Men at seasons go a hunting, and<ns0:lb /> at times a Fishing, and they Work the                    Canoe,<ns0:lb /> at which they are very handy, there is very<ns0:lb /> little game of any                    kind at this season of<ns0:lb /> the year brought in, I have seen but one<ns0:lb /> deer                    all the time we were among them<ns0:lb /> and, I have seen no kind of any small<ns0:lb />                    Game, except the Turkey heretofore noted.<ns0:lb /> the Catch a few fish, yet but                    little was<ns0:lb /> done at it while we were there, <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_061" n="59" /> so that they live poor, their chief                    subsistence<ns0:lb /> at this season was Corn, beans, and Bears<ns0:lb /> Oyl, in                    different preparations, much of their<ns0:lb /> Corn and Beans, were pounded into an                    ho-<ns0:lb /> -miny, and Boiled, this I thought was<ns0:lb /> their Chief dependence, they                    also pound<ns0:lb /> Corn and Beans in to a flour, and make bread<ns0:lb /> of it, they                    also boyl it in dumplins, which<ns0:lb /> they eat with Bear Oyl by dipping it                    in,<ns0:lb /> as they do also with their Bread, they<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>also</ns0:del> sometimes put Oyl in there ho-<ns0:lb /> -miny, <ns0:del>they</ns0:del> also                    at times puts sugar in<ns0:lb /> it, with which it eats very well, but<ns0:lb /> from my                    observation they eat much less <ns0:del>than</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> than we do, a small piece of                    Bread or dum-<ns0:lb /> -plin dipped in the Oyl seemed to satisfy<ns0:lb /> nature, and                    there seated meals I thought<ns0:lb /> were not more than two a day about<ns0:lb /> 10 or                    11 OClock, and in the Evening, if any<ns0:lb /> of their friends came to see them,                    the Visit was<ns0:lb /> not interrupted with Cookery, or much<ns0:lb /> Cerimony in laying                    the table &c. if their hominy<ns0:lb /> was boiled, which was generally the case                    af-<ns0:lb /> -ter 11 OClock, the day through, and it was<ns0:lb /> not material whether                    Cold or Warm, and<ns0:lb /> some of their acquaintance came in, the <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_062" n="60" /> Births always made a seat ready,                    wheren<ns0:lb /> they were presently engaged in smoak-<ns0:lb /> -ing and talking, and                    while thus busily<ns0:lb /> employed, a kettle of hominy with<ns0:lb /> a large Wooden                    spoon, is brought and<ns0:lb /> set down on the Ground before them, he<ns0:lb /> that is                    most handy to it lays by his<ns0:lb /> Pipe, and in a few minutes appears to be<ns0:lb />                    satisfyed with his repast, and moves it on<ns0:lb /> to the next, while the rest of                    the Company<ns0:lb /> are engaged as if no Victuals were<ns0:lb /> near them, thus the                    Kettle passes <ns0:del>th</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> through the Company in a little time,<ns0:lb /> and                    when done with, hung up, until some<ns0:lb /> -body else comes in, if they have                    no<ns0:lb /> hominy, the Bread, or dumplin, goes<ns0:lb /> round in like manner; there is                    no<ns0:lb /> trouble of laying, or clearing the ta-<ns0:lb /> -ble, or placing of Chairs,                    Wiping the knives<ns0:lb /> and Forks, or Changing of plates, but in<ns0:lb /> a simple                    and easy manner all that<ns0:lb /> cerimony is avoided. </ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> In their Cloathing and Dress their turn<ns0:lb /> is for something tawdry; such as a                    gay hand-<ns0:lb /> -kerchief, Calico shirt, Scarlet Leggons,<ns0:lb /> Blue Coat, or                    petticoat, a belt of lively<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>coo</ns0:del> colours <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_063" n="61" /> decorated with Beads tyed round their                    mid-<ns0:lb /> -dles, or knees, with long ends hanging<ns0:lb /> down, the are very fond                    of trinkets of<ns0:lb /> various kinds in there noses, and Ears,<ns0:lb /> the Men more                    particularly. I have seen bobs<ns0:lb /> of various kinds hanging there noses<ns0:lb /> to                    the weight of an Ounce, or more, coming<ns0:lb /> down over their Mouth. the                    Warriors<ns0:lb /> have the rim of their Ears cut round,<ns0:lb /> and loaded with                    different kinds of<ns0:lb /> Toys, until the hang down several<ns0:lb /> Inches. I saw one                    man with two padlocks<ns0:lb /> in one Year, such as are used for Saddle-<ns0:lb /> bags,                    another with a Watch, such as<ns0:lb /> Children use. large silver Crosses are<ns0:lb />                    also made use of. their Calico shirts are<ns0:lb /> short <ns0:del>and</ns0:del> & have                    ruffles to their sleeves<ns0:lb /> & Bosoms. the Men and Womens are both                    made<ns0:lb /> in the same form, they come a little lower<ns0:lb /> than their Hips, and                    hangs loose at the<ns0:lb /> lower end, the Women wearing their<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>Petticuts</ns0:del> Petticoats <ns0:del>over</ns0:del> under them, which<ns0:lb />                    petticoats are mostly made of blue<ns0:lb /> Cloath, without any needlework,                    exept<ns0:lb /> the stitching some red Worsted binding <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_064" n="62" /> on about 9 Inches of the upper part;                    their<ns0:lb /> way of making and putting them on is, to take<ns0:lb /> a piece of Cloath                    perhaps 1½ Yards long<ns0:lb /> turn down the upper part as above described,                    which<ns0:lb /> part is spread over with Ribbons,<ns0:lb /> then Wrap it tite round them,                    and<ns0:lb /> tye it with a string, their shift as<ns0:lb /> mentioned, hanging the out                    side, such<ns0:lb /> who suckle lift up their Shirts for the Child<ns0:lb /> to get at the                    pap, which Conduct to those<ns0:lb /> who are unacquainted with it may look<ns0:lb />                    immodest, but it is not the case, for<ns0:lb /> a Child is so suckled, and less of                    the<ns0:lb /> Mothers skin shown than is customa-<ns0:lb /> -ry among our farmers Wives,                    -</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> With all their tawdry and liveliness in<ns0:lb /> dress the go dirty, I thought the                    Women<ns0:lb /> more particularly so than the Men, per-<ns0:lb /> -haps from their working                    harder, and<ns0:lb /> being more among the grease, some of their shirts<ns0:lb /> don’t                    appear to be ever Washed, and<ns0:lb /> about their Sholders the become very<ns0:lb />                    black and greesy, from their greesy<ns0:lb /> heads; their hair I have observed to                    be<ns0:lb /> the Cloath to wipe their greasy fingers <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_065" n="63" /> in, while eating their bread and                    Oyl.<ns0:lb /> thus for want of a change of Cloaths, and<ns0:lb /> living in their dirt,                    they become <ns0:del>very</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> lowsy, which they try to extrecate them<ns0:lb />                    -selves from, by pulling of their shifts,<ns0:lb /> turning them inside                        out<ns0:del>wards</ns0:del>, and<ns0:lb /> hunting the Vermon with as much com-<ns0:lb />                    -possure, and seemingly good grace,<ns0:lb /> as a Mother amongst us would do, in                    <ns0:lb /> combing one of her Children, and this<ns0:lb /> part of their dirt has not been                    one of the<ns0:lb /> least of our trials, neither have we any<ns0:lb /> expectation of                    leaving them, without<ns0:lb /> carrying away some breeders. </ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> For more than two weeks past the weather<ns0:lb /> has been very dry, part of the                    time a Cold<ns0:lb /> north wind, we had frost for ten Mornings<ns0:lb /> successively,                    during which time we slept<ns0:lb /> in open Cabins, in our blankets, so that<ns0:lb /> we                    sensible felt the want of more cover-<ns0:lb /> -ing, and a better Bed before                    morning.<ns0:lb /> for two or three days past the weather has<ns0:lb /> been warm, with a                    strong South wind.<ns0:lb /> the Woods has been much on fire dur-<ns0:lb /> -ing this dry                    weather, Clouds of smoke <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_066" n="64" /> have frequently covered us, so that                    the<ns0:lb /> Sun has been hid. A curious Sight present-<ns0:lb /> -ed two nights ago, of                    some neighbouring<ns0:lb /> Hills or rather mountains that were on fire,<ns0:lb /> perhaps                    the had not been burnt for seve-<ns0:lb /> -ral Years, and the great quantity of                    dead<ns0:lb /> timber, both standing and laying down,<ns0:lb /> having taken fire as it                    passed along,<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>which</ns0:del> made a very lively appearance in<ns0:lb /> the night, looking as if                    the whole Mountain<ns0:lb /> was on fire. – We have been under<ns0:lb /> some exercise for                    a few days past concern-<ns0:lb /> -ing our goods, which are coming up<ns0:lb /> the                        <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>, <ns0:del>we</ns0:del> hav<ns0:del>e</ns0:del> ing                    very little cause to<ns0:lb /> expect their arrival before the last of<ns0:lb /> this                    Month, and the dry weather has<ns0:lb /> been such for some time past, that the<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> has fallen very fast, which the<ns0:lb />                    Indians remarked to us with some degree<ns0:lb /> of seriousness, saying that it                    would be<ns0:lb /> with difficulty the Boat could be ~<ns0:lb /> brought up some Shallow                    places, but in<ns0:lb /> the midst of our trials we have still<ns0:lb /> been favoured; a                    considerable quantity of<ns0:lb /> rain fell last Evening, tho no diffi-<ns0:lb /> -rence                    yet appears in the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>, there <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_067" n="65" /> is some reason to hope it will rise.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We intended to have set of this Morning<ns0:lb /> by Eight OClock for <ns0:placeName key="genes1">Genesinguhta</ns0:placeName>, <ns0:del>and</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> and agreed with                        <ns0:persName key="habee1">Henry Obeal</ns0:persName> last<ns0:lb /> evening to go with                    us, and be our en-<ns0:lb /> -terpretter; it is now eleven OClock, yet nei-<ns0:lb />                    -ther he, nor his Fathers family have got<ns0:lb /> their breakfast, tho we have been                    hurry-<ns0:lb /> -ing him for two hours past, about 12 two<ns0:lb /> of us set of on horse                    back, the other three<ns0:lb /> having started an hour sooner with<ns0:lb /> one Indian in                    a Canoe; we rode the<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> one mile above the <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Town</ns0:placeName>, and<ns0:lb /> went up the Eastside of it, <ns0:del>to said                            <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Town</ns0:placeName></ns0:del><ns0:lb /> our first 3 or 4                    miles was through an Open bot-<ns0:lb /> -tom, thinly timbered, and good riding,                    then<ns0:lb /> passed through thick Timber, a large quan-<ns0:lb /> -tity of which were                    Sugar Maple, thence<ns0:lb /> through a thick Forrest of Hemlock, and<ns0:lb /> pine, very                    difficult to pass, to the shore<ns0:lb /> opposite the place of destination; here                    we<ns0:lb /> again rode the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> tho wide and<ns0:lb />                    deep, we stoped at the House of a Chief who<ns0:lb /> went with us to our inten ded                    Settlement,<ns0:lb /> here we met with our friends who went <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_068" n="66" /> in the Canoe. We viewed an Empty                    house<ns0:lb /> that <ns0:del>on</ns0:del> stood near our Settlement, <ns0:del>we</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> but                    not liking it, we proceeded to ano-<ns0:lb /> -ther that was on <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> said                    settlement wherein a family<ns0:lb /> lived, we understood they proposed<ns0:lb /> leaving                    it, and would sell their right,<ns0:lb /> upon conferring with the Woman, who<ns0:lb /> we                    understood was the owner of the<ns0:lb /> house, she was willing to part with                    the<ns0:lb /> house but having put in a few spots<ns0:lb /> with Corn and Vines, the whole                    not more<ns0:lb /> than 3 or 4 pearch Square, she <ns0:del>was</ns0:del> appeared<ns0:lb />                    unwilling to relinquish them, and they<ns0:lb /> were so in our way, that we thought                    we<ns0:lb /> had better look elsewhere for a settlement,<ns0:lb /> but upon the Chiefs                    conferring with her,<ns0:lb /> she was willing to part with each of the<ns0:lb /> spots                    except one which was not much in<ns0:lb /> our way, and we understanding she<ns0:lb /> was                    a sober Woman that would be likely<ns0:lb /> to make good use of the Money, we paid                    her 20<ns0:lb /> dollars for her house and previligdges,<ns0:lb /> and with our assistance                    she removed out<ns0:lb /> and in less than an hour we had possission <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_069" n="67" /> our young men gave <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> the                    house a thorough cleaning,<ns0:lb /> and before dark our scanty furniture was<ns0:lb />                    arranged for House-keeping, and having<ns0:lb /> supped on our preparations, which                    admitted<ns0:lb /> of but little change, we prepared for bed in<ns0:lb /> our open house,                    and naked Walls, the Indi-<ns0:lb /> -an Chief at our request sent us three<ns0:lb />                    deerskins with the hair on, which <ns0:del>which</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> we placed for our                    Conveniency, and re-<ns0:lb /> -tired, but we sensibly felt before morn-<ns0:lb /> -ing                    the want of a better bed and more Clothes.<ns0:lb /> the night being cold we were                    under the<ns0:lb /> necessity of rising several times to re-<ns0:lb /> -new our fire. Our                    house is about 20<ns0:lb /> feet long, 14 feet wide, and 6 feet high to the<ns0:lb />                    Square, Covered with bark, and a shed over<ns0:lb /> the door, and finished within as                    is usual<ns0:lb /> in Indian buildings, it stands on an ele-<ns0:lb /> -vated spot within                    five Pearch of the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>,<ns0:lb /> on its Northwest                    side, the soil about<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> said house is of a light sandy quality, easy to be<ns0:lb /> tilled;                    but further from the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> is lower<ns0:lb />                    ground, <ns0:del>which</ns0:del> and appears more fertile.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Our horses since we came among the<ns0:lb /> Indians has run out, without enclosing: <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_070" n="68" /> they have had pretty plenty                        <ns0:del>pretty</ns0:del> of Coarse grass, and<ns0:lb /> other herbages, but here they                    have plen-<ns0:lb /> -ty of grass, and that which is very good.</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 24, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Our young men this morning planted<ns0:lb /> some Potatoes, and they are now                    pre-<ns0:lb /> -paring <ns0:del>some</ns0:del> ground fit for the Plough, for<ns0:lb /> Corn,                    having when we came up borrow-<ns0:lb /> -ed some tools of <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName>. we had<ns0:lb /> a present of fish this morning, on                    which<ns0:lb /> we expect deliciously to dine, - Our<ns0:lb /> Young Men have prepared                        <ns0:del>some</ns0:del> bobs<ns0:lb /> in order to try to catch some Eells<ns0:lb /> this                    evening, set of up the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> with a Canoe,                    but there being a con-<ns0:lb /> -siderable rapid to ascend, which for<ns0:lb /> want of                    more experience in working<ns0:lb /> the vessel, they fail’d getting up, the                    Canoe<ns0:lb /> turning across the Stream in such a<ns0:lb /> manner, that it took in                    Water, and<ns0:lb /> presently turned bottom upwards, so<ns0:lb /> that some of them got                    very wet, which<ns0:lb /> put an end to their Eel catching; shortly<ns0:lb /> after they                    returned we had several very<ns0:lb /> heavy showers, <ns0:del>wich</ns0:del> which                    convinced<ns0:lb /> us our house was not proof against <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_071" n="69" /> Storms, for the rain beat in at the                    end,<ns0:lb /> Roof, and other places. –- </ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We have been keeping house about a<ns0:lb /> week, and experience much                    inconveni-<ns0:lb /> -ency for want of the arrival of our<ns0:lb /> goods, having but five                    Tins, three<ns0:lb /> Spoons, and a Camp kettle, we have a<ns0:lb /> small frying pan                    which we borrowed<ns0:lb /> of the Indians, dish cloths, and towels<ns0:lb /> we are much                    at a loss for, as we are<ns0:lb /> for Soap when we wash our Cloaths,<ns0:lb /> the want                    of something to knead our bread<ns0:lb /> in is sensibly experienced, which                    would<ns0:lb /> not be the case if we had Tools; when<ns0:lb /> we fry our meat, or our                    fritters, we have<ns0:lb /> neither Dish, nor plate to put them on, but oc-<ns0:lb />                    -cupy bark. We brought Bacon with<ns0:lb /> us from <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName>, which we have us-<ns0:lb /> -ed very spareingly, it is                    nearly run<ns0:lb /> out, and our Cheese quite. we have no pros-<ns0:lb /> -pect of                    supplying their place until our<ns0:lb /> goods arrive. we have a little flour                    left<ns0:lb /> that we brought from <ns0:placeName key="frank">Franklin</ns0:placeName>,                    Cho-<ns0:lb /> -colate & Sugar that we brought from <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pitts-<ns0:lb /> Burgh</ns0:placeName>, which are our chief living and depen-<ns0:lb />                    -dance. <ns0:del>as</ns0:del> we have received some Sugar of the <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_072" n="70" /> Indians as a present, and some we                    pur-<ns0:lb /> -chased, which we find a pretty good sub-<ns0:lb /> -stitute for butter,                    and Cheese, by bitting<ns0:lb /> a bit of Sugar, which is in a hand cake,<ns0:lb /> with                    our Bread. – while at the <ns0:placeName key="cornp">lower<ns0:lb /> Town</ns0:placeName> we                    got 2 Quarts of Milk a day,<ns0:lb /> but since we came here we have re-<ns0:lb /> -cieved                    none, nor are there ever a<ns0:lb /> Cow here. –- </ns0:p>

text.headline: May 25, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> several heavy showers last night, still<ns0:lb /> wet this morning, about 10 OClock,                    it clear-<ns0:lb /> -ed away, put up some fence to keep our<ns0:lb /> horses of the                    Indians, Corn, as what<ns0:lb /> little they have put in here, lies unen-<ns0:lb />                    -closed. the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> has been rising all<ns0:lb />                    day, so that there is plenty of water<ns0:lb /> for our Boat to come up. </ns0:p>

text.headline: May 26, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> mostly busy in getting a spot of land<ns0:lb /> fit for the Plough, and some                    other<ns0:lb /> necessary preparations, one of our<ns0:lb /> number has been <ns0:del>busy                        in</ns0:del> plaistering<ns0:lb /> the Cracks of our house, it having<ns0:lb /> cleared up                    from Northwest last even<ns0:lb /> -ing, and our house being very open<ns0:lb /> we                    suffered with the Cold. </ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">I may just note <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> there is a great appear-<ns0:lb /> -ance for                    strawberries here on some part<ns0:lb /> of the Old Indian fields. </ns0:p>

text.headline: May 27, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> I neglected noting in its<ns0:lb /> proper place, that fifth day last about 11<ns0:lb />                    OClock we retired into our humble Cabin,<ns0:lb /> and were favoured to witness the                    over-<ns0:lb /> -shadowing Wing of Consoling goodness,<ns0:lb /> to the Comforting and                    contriting of our<ns0:lb /> Spirits, and this day we had a like Op-<ns0:lb /> -pertunity,                    and were I thought alike<ns0:lb /> favoured, may such seasons be remembred<ns0:lb /> with                    gratitude, and with thankfulness and may<ns0:lb /> our young friends be encouraged                    &<ns0:lb /> strengthened to keep up such religious<ns0:lb /> oppertunities when we are                    far separated, which I<ns0:lb /> trust they will. this is the fifth day since<ns0:lb /> we                    came to this <ns0:placeName key="genes1">Town</ns0:placeName>, we brought but<ns0:lb />                    little provision with us here, having<ns0:lb /> but little to bring, and had a hope                    we<ns0:lb /> should have been able to have got<ns0:lb /> some dryed Venison of the Indians                    here, which has<ns0:lb /> not been the case, we got a little Bears Oyl<ns0:lb /> of them,                    but that article is scarce, and<ns0:lb /> dear, this day intending to have made <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_074" n="72" /> a dinner of some flitters, our Bread<ns0:lb />                    being nearly out, and our flour so re-<ns0:lb /> -duced as to discourage attempting                    to<ns0:lb /> bake; while we were frying our<ns0:lb /> flitters, an Indian man came in<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>in</ns0:del> and presented us with about four Pounds of fresh Ve-<ns0:lb /> -nison                    without any bone in it; part of<ns0:lb /> which we immediately fryed, which<ns0:lb /> with                    our flitters made us the most a-<ns0:lb /> -greeable dinner we have met with<ns0:lb /> in                    the Indian Country, we sat down<ns0:lb /> to it with thankful hearts for so                    unex-<ns0:lb /> -pected a supply. we gave the Indian<ns0:lb /> a Quarter of a dollar, for                    his Venison,<ns0:lb /> which he recieved with an apparant<ns0:lb /> reluctance, but as he                    could not speak <ns0:del>no</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> English, we were altogether at a loss<ns0:lb /> to                    know, whether it proceeded from<ns0:lb /> what we gave him being too much, or<ns0:lb />                    too little, but the same afternoon he took<ns0:lb /> three of us down in a Canoe to                        <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Corn-<ns0:lb /> -planters Village</ns0:placeName> to attend a                    general<ns0:lb /> Council that was to be held there<ns0:lb /> tomorrow, he took the Money                    with him<ns0:lb /> and gave it to <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName>, and                    said<ns0:lb /> something to him in Indian, which <ns0:del>being</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> was, that the                    Venison he brought us was <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_075" n="73" /> a gift, and he wished not to recieve                    any<ns0:lb /> money for it, and the money was handed back<ns0:lb /> to us, which we                    immeadiately presented to<ns0:lb /> him for <ns0:del>his</ns0:del> the <ns0:del>his</ns0:del> trouble                    of bringing<ns0:lb /> us down in his Canoe, which he reciev-<ns0:lb /> -ed with                    Chearfulness. </ns0:p>

text.headline: May 28, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Two of our number whom we left at <ns0:placeName key="genes1">Genesin-<ns0:lb />                        -guhta</ns0:placeName> to take care of our horses, House &c.<ns0:lb /> came down                    this Morning, and a number of<ns0:lb /> Indians being Collected, about 12 we met                    them<ns0:lb /> in Council, there being between 30 and 40, six<ns0:lb /> of whom were there                    most respectable Women, early<ns0:lb /> in the Oppertunity <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> made a pretty<ns0:lb /> length speech, <ns0:del>which</ns0:del>                    it did not appear to be di-<ns0:lb /> -rected to us, which our interpretter                    informed<ns0:lb /> was for an Indian then in the House, who<ns0:lb /> had been charged                    with Murdering a White<ns0:lb /> Man, for which he had been in Jail at<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pitts-burgh</ns0:placeName>, and tryed for his Life, but                    be-<ns0:lb /> -ing acquitted by the Jury, he was now at<ns0:lb /> Liberty; the trial and                    Court expences, we<ns0:lb /> understood had cost <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> more<ns0:lb /> than 200 dollars; tho there was not                    evidence<ns0:lb /> to support the charge, yet there was cause to fear<ns0:lb /> it was too                    true, and the Chiefs speech appear-<ns0:lb /> -ed to be delivered with much earnest,                    and<ns0:lb /> serious expostulation. <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName>                    then <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_076" n="74" /> directed his speech to us, expressing his                    satisfaction in see-<ns0:lb /> -ing us all in good health, then informing, some<ns0:lb />                    of his People were gone out a hunting, &<ns0:lb /> if we had any thing to propose                    to them<ns0:lb /> they were now ready, being all collected<ns0:lb /> that would come.                    After a Short time of<ns0:lb /> silence wherein we felt an earnest tra-<ns0:lb /> -vel, we                    might be renewedly favoured,<ns0:lb /> a suitable introductory speech was made<ns0:lb />                    on our part, and then the following con-<ns0:lb /> -clusions of the 22nd were read,                    and enterpret-<ns0:lb /> -ted</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We then were favoured seriouly to<ns0:lb /> expostulate with them on various                    subjects<ns0:lb /> retative to their Moral, and Civil Con-<ns0:lb /> -duct, particularly                    there excessive use<ns0:lb /> of Strong drink, divers instances of<ns0:lb /> which we had                    been Eye witnesses of,<ns0:lb /> since among them, several of their Wo-<ns0:lb /> -men                        <ns0:del>had</ns0:del> having been thus disguised; some of<ns0:lb /> them appeared Solid,                    and heard us<ns0:lb /> with attention, but as far as I have ob-<ns0:lb /> -served since                    among them, little or no<ns0:lb /> Shame covers an Indian for getting<ns0:lb /> drunk. --                    They informed us they<ns0:lb /> would withdraw a little while into ano-<ns0:lb /> -ther                    Room, and confer on our propos-<ns0:lb /> -als, which doing, in about an hour<ns0:lb />                    they returned, and made us an answer<ns0:lb /> in substance as follows,</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> At the close of this speech we expressed a few words<ns0:lb /> more, representing                    among other things the un-<ns0:lb /> -reasonableness of their present practice,                    of<ns0:lb /> their Mothers, Wives, and Sisters, working<ns0:lb /> all day in the fields,                    and in the Woods, with<ns0:lb /> their hoes, and axes, whilst they themselves<ns0:lb />                    were at the same time playing with their<ns0:lb /> Bows and Arrows &c                    recommending to them<ns0:lb /> to begin our way by early setting their boys<ns0:lb /> to                    business, taking them out to how Corn &c<ns0:lb /> thus by early habitting them                    to Work, their<ns0:lb /> Minds will be turned to it, business will<ns0:lb /> become                    familier, and they will not think<ns0:lb /> hard of it. and as they expressed the                    White<ns0:lb /> People were rich and had plenty, we let them <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_084" n="82" /> know it was by industry it Was                    obtained<ns0:lb /> the men doing their share of business<ns0:lb /> in the fields, &c                    thereby leaving the Wo-<ns0:lb /> -men more time to attend to spinning,<ns0:lb /> sewing,                    darying &c in the house.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We concluded with seriously impressing<ns0:lb /> on their Minds the remembrance,                    that<ns0:lb /> it was from the good Spirit they re-<ns0:lb /> -cieved every good thing,                    and that he<ns0:lb /> could hear every good Word they said,<ns0:lb /> and see every thing                    they did, and if they<ns0:lb /> were good, and industerous, this good<ns0:lb /> Spirit                    would love them, and bless them<ns0:lb /> with many good things. In a few                    minutes<ns0:lb /> after we had concluded, and informed them<ns0:lb /> we had done,                        <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> Observed, now<ns0:lb /> all things                    were done, and settled, we<ns0:lb /> will cover up the Council fire.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We had no provision of our own here,<ns0:lb /> therefore concluded to stay and dine                    with<ns0:lb /> the Chief, about five Oclock we had a<ns0:lb /> loaf of Warm Indian Bread                    with a mix-<ns0:lb /> -ture of Beans that had been boiled till<ns0:lb /> they were softish                        <ns0:del>nea</ns0:del> kneaded up in it<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>the Bread and baked</ns0:del>                    <ns0:del>that was</ns0:del>                    <ns0:del>set before us,</ns0:del> the<ns0:lb /> bread <ns0:del>had been</ns0:del>                    <ns0:del>was</ns0:del> baked in a Dutch Oven <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_085" n="83" /> having a small quantity of Bears Oyl                    put<ns0:lb /> into the oven with it, and when part<ns0:lb /> baked the loaf was turned                    over with a<ns0:lb /> fresh supply of Oyl, <ns0:del>we t</ns0:del> this was all we<ns0:lb /> had                    set before us; they informed us they had no<ns0:lb /> meat, and we had heretofo shewn                    our dislike<ns0:lb /> to bread diped in Oyl; however with a<ns0:lb /> good Appatite it                    went down very well, but<ns0:lb /> before we had fully done a little butter was<ns0:lb />                    set before us <ns0:del>on the Table</ns0:del> that they had obtained some<ns0:lb /> -where in                    the Village. -- We now got half<ns0:lb /> a £ of flour of <ns0:persName key="cornp">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> for which he<ns0:lb /> made no charge, and four Quarts of                    bears<ns0:lb /> Oyl of his wife, which she claiming as her<ns0:lb /> property charged us                    half a dollar a Quart,<ns0:lb /> these our Young men took up this evening with                    them<ns0:lb /> to <ns0:placeName key="genes1">Genesinguhta</ns0:placeName>, together with                    what<ns0:lb /> Chocolate we had, <ns0:del>this evening</ns0:del>; leaving<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="jpier1">John Pierce</ns0:persName> and myself here to wait the<ns0:lb />                    arrival of our goods</ns0:p>

text.headline: May 29, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> In the council yesterday we informed the<ns0:lb /> Indians that <ns0:persName key="jpier1">John Pierce</ns0:persName> and myself expected<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>in a few days</ns0:del> to be at liberty in a few days<ns0:lb /> to leave them, and                    return to our families<ns0:lb /> and Friends; and since the concluding <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_086" n="84" /> of the Council we see nothing but                    what<ns0:lb /> we might set of in a day or two if our<ns0:lb /> goods were                        <ns0:del>arrived</ns0:del> come; we have not<ns0:lb /> heard any <ns0:del>from</ns0:del> of them                    since we left<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pitts-Burgh</ns0:placeName>, but hope they will shortly<ns0:lb />                    arrive, as tomorrow closes the 18th day,<ns0:lb /> being the time stipulated for                    there delivery <ns0:del>coming</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>here</ns0:del>, -- Our situation is diffirent from<ns0:lb /> what it was when we                    were here al-<ns0:lb /> -together, we then had a room much<ns0:lb /> to ourselves, and                    cooked our own<ns0:lb /> Victuals, we now board with <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Corn-<ns0:lb /> -planter</ns0:persName>, who uses us kind, and as<ns0:lb /> well as his                    house will afford, We have<ns0:lb /> >had Tea made of the Root of Sassifras,                    also<ns0:lb /> of an herb like fern, and thin cakes<ns0:lb /> of wheat Bread baked, or                    rather fryed<ns0:lb /> in a pan they eat very well, so that<ns0:lb /> we have no cause to                    complain of our<ns0:lb /> living if it was not for their dirt, <ns0:del>and</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>their lice</ns0:del> &c which try’s us. --- <ns0:del>we enquir-</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>-ed</ns0:del> Our road from <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName> here,                    was<ns0:lb /> pretty much of a Northeast coarse, and <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_087" n="85" /> part of it very rough and tedious, so                    that<ns0:lb /> we have been desirous of finding a <ns0:del><ns0:gap /></ns0:del><ns0:lb /> nearer, and                    better way home, we early en-<ns0:lb /> -quired of <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> if there was any path<ns0:lb /> from this <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Town</ns0:placeName> across the Mountains to<ns0:lb /> the big Island on                        <ns0:geogName key="susqu">Susquehanna</ns0:geogName> at the<ns0:lb /> mouth of <ns0:geogName key="balde">Baldegle Creak</ns0:geogName>, he informed us<ns0:lb /> there was a path,                        <ns0:del>but it</ns0:del> which was but little<ns0:lb /> used, and through a rough                    uninhabited<ns0:lb /> Country, we should have to lay out at nights,<ns0:lb /> carry                    provision for ourselves, and some for<ns0:lb /> our horses, and that it would take us                    five<ns0:lb /> days <ns0:del>to travel it</ns0:del> and it was so Moun-<ns0:lb /> -tainous and                    rough, that it would be with<ns0:lb /> the greatest difficulty we could get our                    hor-<ns0:lb /> -ses along, we then enquired for a way to<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="canan">Canandarque</ns0:placeName>, and how far, he told us it                    was<ns0:lb /> 160 miles, and not a very difficult road,<ns0:lb /> that he and his Son                        <ns0:persName key="habee1">Henry</ns0:persName> were going<ns0:lb /> there in a few days,                    and he would be<ns0:lb /> glad of our Company; we had felt some<ns0:lb /> little draft in                    our Minds to go home by <ns0:placeName key="checkPlace">O-<ns0:lb />-neida</ns0:placeName>, and <ns0:placeName key="canan">Canandarque</ns0:placeName> being in the way which made the Chiefs proposal                        <ns0:del>of the</ns0:del>                    <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_088" n="86" />                    <ns0:del>Chiefs, of bearing us Company to Canandar-</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>-que</ns0:del> feel pleasant, but about this date a<ns0:lb /> runner from the Chiefs                    of <ns0:placeName key="buffa">Buffaloe</ns0:placeName>, arriv-<ns0:lb /> -ed at <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Cornplanters Village</ns0:placeName> with a mes-<ns0:lb /> -sage to him,                    desiring his attendance<ns0:lb /> there as soon as he conveniently could<ns0:lb /> for the                    Surveyers and commissioners from<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="rmorr1">Robert Morris</ns0:persName> and Company were coming<ns0:lb /> to                    run out the land the Indians sold them<ns0:lb /> last fall, and also to run and                    settle the<ns0:lb /> lines of the Indians reservations, they<ns0:lb /> Chief expressed a                    great desire <ns0:persName key="jpier1">John Peirce</ns0:persName><ns0:lb /> and myself                    should go with him to the<ns0:lb /> Council and attend there while the business<ns0:lb />                    was transacting, which upon weighing, we<ns0:lb /> let him know we felt a freedom                    comply to <ns0:del>go</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> with <ns0:del>him</ns0:del>. -- While we were writing<ns0:lb />                    this afternoon we heard an uncommon<ns0:lb /> noise, which caused us to look out                    to<ns0:lb /> see from what it proceeded, where we<ns0:lb /> saw a Man in a frightful                    Dress, we<ns0:lb /> then walked out more fully to view<ns0:lb /> the sight, where we saw                    two Men<ns0:lb /> with naked Arms, Thighs, and legs,<ns0:lb /> they had Bearskins on their                    backs <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_089" n="87" /> which hung down below their hips,                    and<ns0:lb /> tyed <ns0:del>together</ns0:del> across their breasts, and on<ns0:lb /> their head                    they had a grim and Terrible<ns0:lb /> appearance, this false face, for so it                    was<ns0:lb /> called, was made as frightfull as nature<ns0:lb /> could invent, the hair on                    its head hang-<ns0:lb /> -ing forward and over the face; the Mouth <ns0:del>gr</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    grinning, large, and much aside; the<ns0:lb /> nose, and Cheeks Wrinkled and                    very<ns0:lb /> Huge; the Eyes set around with tin to re-<ns0:lb /> -semble the uncommon                    stearing, and the<ns0:lb /> whole face painted red and black, each<ns0:lb /> of these Men                    had in their hands a stick<ns0:lb /> of about 8 Inches in length fastened<ns0:lb /> to a                    <ns0:gap /> shell of a Water Tortise, the <ns0:del>which</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> Shells had some small                    stones or other<ns0:lb /> hand substances in them, which made<ns0:lb /> a great rattleing:                    which noise was much<ns0:lb /> much increased by their reubbing<ns0:lb /> them against the                    Logs of a certain<ns0:lb /> house where they appeared to be sta-<ns0:lb /> -tioned as                    guards the whole conduct of these<ns0:lb /> Men were <ns0:del>appeared to be</ns0:del> truly                    frantick.<ns0:lb /> a large number of spectators at a consider-<ns0:lb /> -able distance                    surrounded the house <ns0:del>where</ns0:del>                    <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_090" n="88" />                    <ns0:del>where the men appeared to be plac-</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>-ed as guards</ns0:del>, many of whom were young<ns0:lb /> Men, who endeavored to                    peep through<ns0:lb /> the Craks of the Logs into the House, and<ns0:lb /> these guards                    used <ns0:del>their</ns0:del> great exertion<ns0:lb /> to keep them off, or to catch them, it                    look-<ns0:lb /> -ed dreadful to fall into their hands, which<ns0:lb /> made the Young men                    use great endeavours<ns0:lb /> to avoid it, I asked our <ns0:del>Young</ns0:del> interpretter                    what<ns0:lb /> would be the Consequence if any of them<ns0:lb /> should be taken, he said                    they would put Ashes<ns0:lb /> on their Heads, and very much dgrade<ns0:lb /> them, we saw                    a number of elderly Women go-<ns0:lb /> -ing into the house, whom these monsters                    quietly let pass<ns0:lb /> from which Circumstance and some others,<ns0:lb /> we were of                    the mind there was a women in<ns0:lb /> Labour in said house, and this Wild                    scene<ns0:lb /> was transacted, as a Ceremony, or rejoic-<ns0:lb /> -ing, at the Birth of                    a Child, or else to<ns0:lb /> keep the Boys and Young Men from com-<ns0:lb /> -ing nigh                    the house or looking in, as there<ns0:lb /> construction was such as not to                    admit<ns0:lb /> of Privacy, Our interpretter was a<ns0:lb /> Young Man and did not seem                    fully to<ns0:lb /> understand, or else did not care to tell <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_091" n="89" /> the cause of the Womens being there:<ns0:lb />                    but said they had met there for a frolic, and<ns0:lb /> to drink Whiskey, but as far                    as we could dis-<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>cover</ns0:del> -cover neither their conduct, nor<ns0:lb /> Countenances answered                    this description. </ns0:p>

text.headline: May 30, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> This day near 12 OClock while I was writing<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>a letter</ns0:del> to my Dear Wife and Family, Corn-<ns0:lb /> -planters wife with                    an expression of Joy on<ns0:lb /> her Countenance came into our appart-<ns0:lb /> -ment,                    and pointing with her hand down<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>                    expressed as plain as she could,<ns0:lb /> Canoe, Canoe, it struck us immeadi-<ns0:lb />                    -ately that our Boat was <ns0:del>a</ns0:del> coming, -- <ns0:lb /> which was agreeable news                        <ns0:del>to us</ns0:del> we went<ns0:lb /> directly to the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> side, but not<ns0:lb /> observing it any where in view,                    she<ns0:lb /> pointed with her hand across a bottom<ns0:lb /> is so sensible a manner,                    that it left no<ns0:lb /> remaining doubt <ns0:del>she</ns0:del> but she had seen<ns0:lb /> it, in                    a little time the Boat came<ns0:lb /> safely along by the side of the <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Town</ns0:placeName>,<ns0:lb /> the arrival of which was heartily<ns0:lb />                    welcomed, both by us, and the Indians<ns0:lb /> many of the latter gathering around                    the Shore, hav-<ns0:lb /> -ing never seen such a boat before, most of them being <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_092" n="90" /> only acquainted with Canoes, the                    Captain<ns0:lb /> informed us he did not leave <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pitts                        burgh</ns0:placeName> until<ns0:lb /> three days later than he <ns0:del>had given</ns0:del>                    expected,<ns0:lb /> that he had been fifteen days a coming, and<ns0:lb /> that it was 270                    miles to follow the Coarse of<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>,                    both he and his Men appear-<ns0:lb /> -ed tired, expressing much satisfaction                    they<ns0:lb /> had gotten here, not expecting we would<ns0:lb /> want them to go further,                    but when we<ns0:lb /> let them know our house was nine miles<ns0:lb /> up the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>, and that we wanted the<ns0:lb /> goods taken there,                    the submitted to com-<ns0:lb /> -ply, with much reluctance, and not until<ns0:lb /> we                    first engaged to give them three dol-<ns0:lb /> -lars extraordinary, and half a                    dollar to<ns0:lb /> an Indian to Pilot them, the Captain<ns0:lb /> saying he was a                    stranger higher up the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We have been entirely unable since our<ns0:lb /> arrival here to have any                    Conversation<ns0:lb /> with the Indians without an interpretter their being very                    few<ns0:lb /> amongst them who understand any English<ns0:lb /> & fewer who can, or                    will express one word,<ns0:lb /> and our interpretter not being ready at the<ns0:lb /> the                    business it was a discouragement to us, to<ns0:lb /> touch on religious subjects. we                    had a <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_093" n="91" /> strong desire to know if they had any                    religius<ns0:lb /> Rites or Ceremonies amongst them, and last<ns0:lb /> evening <ns0:del>we                        ha</ns0:del> having some conversation with <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplan-<ns0:lb />                        -ter</ns0:persName> on the Subject, he informed us, they had<ns0:lb /> two                    Solemnities in a year, when it was the<ns0:lb /> practice for their men and women,                    gene-<ns0:lb /> -rally to meet together in one place; the<ns0:lb /> first was in the                    spring, the other in the<ns0:lb /> fall about the time Corn was ripe; the lat-<ns0:lb />                    -ter as a time or rejoicing, and to re-<ns0:lb /> -turn thanks to the great Spirit                    for this<ns0:lb /> Blessing. the did not keep the first day<ns0:lb /> of the week, but                    every one tryed to think<ns0:lb /> good in his own Mind; and as we could<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>he queried</ns0:del> read the Bible he queried<ns0:lb /> whether there was anything                    said in it<ns0:lb /> about the Indians, we informed him the<ns0:lb /> Bible mentioned all                    nations, kindreds,<ns0:lb /> Tongues, and People, and that included<ns0:lb /> the Indians,                    and we would have been glad<ns0:lb /> to have <ns0:del>mentioned to</ns0:del> told him, tho                    the Indians<ns0:lb /> could not read the Bible yet they were<ns0:lb /> not Wholy deprived                    of the benefits of the<ns0:lb /> coming of Christ, for that a manifestation <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_094" n="92" /> of his Spirit or measure of his Grace                    was<ns0:lb /> placed in each of their hearts, and would<ns0:lb /> if minded, or given way                    to reprove for<ns0:lb /> all wicked words, and Wicked actions,<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>an well</ns0:del> also produce peace for well do-<ns0:lb /> -ing, but this was too                    refined and deli-<ns0:lb /> -cate a Subject for our enterpretter to han-<ns0:lb /> -dle.                    -- I have not been able fully to<ns0:lb /> learn what number of Indians this                        <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Village</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb /> contains, but <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> informed us<ns0:lb /> that there were about                    400 persons<ns0:lb /> Young and Old under his Superentend-<ns0:lb /> -ency, much the                    larger half of whom are<ns0:lb /> in or near this <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Town</ns0:placeName>; he also informed<ns0:lb /> us, that in his whole district                    there were<ns0:lb /> three horses, 14 cow kind, besides one<ns0:lb /> Yoke of Oxen, and 12                    hogs. </ns0:p>

text.headline: May 31, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> About 9 OClock this morning <ns0:persName key="jpier1">John Peirce</ns0:persName><ns0:lb />                    and myself <ns0:del>to</ns0:del> took our last farewell of the<ns0:lb /> Indians in this                    place, and set of with<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName>, his son <ns0:persName key="habee1">Henry</ns0:persName>, and a Nephew<ns0:lb /> up the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> in a Canoe, to his sawmill<ns0:lb /> where we took leave of the                    Chief and his<ns0:lb /> son for the present, with a promise that<ns0:lb /> they would call                    on us at our house at <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_095" n="93" />                    <ns0:placeName key="genes1">Genesinguhta</ns0:placeName> in five days, for to go on<ns0:lb />                    with us to the mouth of <ns0:geogName key="buffr">Buffaloe</ns0:geogName> in order<ns0:lb />                    to attend a Council there, the Nephew and<ns0:lb /> a Son of the Dutchmans who tends                    the<ns0:lb /> Sawmill, took us up to our farm, were<ns0:lb /> we found our goods had                    safely arrived<ns0:lb /> about two hours before, and were all<ns0:lb /> unloaded and taken                    up to our <ns0:del>ho</ns0:del><ns0:del>u</ns0:del><ns0:del>se</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> House door. in about two                    hours, the<ns0:lb /> Boatmen having got their business ac-<ns0:lb /> -complished,                    respectfully bid us fare-<ns0:lb /> -well, and with Chearful Countenances<ns0:lb /> went                    merily down the lively Current<ns0:lb /> expecting in four days to arrive at<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pitts-Burgh</ns0:placeName>. -- This afternoon was spent<ns0:lb />                    in unpacking our goods, drying such<ns0:lb /> as were wet, and stow ing them away in                    our<ns0:lb /> Cabin, which proved too small for the<ns0:lb /> purpose, however we got them                    arranged<ns0:lb /> in such a manner, as to leave a pretty<ns0:lb /> good Conveniency for                    house keeping, we<ns0:lb /> now experienced a great Change, our<ns0:lb /> naked Walls,                    empty house, and bare cup-<ns0:lb /> -board, met with a rich supply; our hard<ns0:lb />                    and Cold beds, were warmed and softened <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_096" n="94" /> with blankets; we were now able to<ns0:lb />                    make a Cup of Tea, or Coffee, tho with-<ns0:lb /> out Milk; or Butter; and we have                    Bacon<ns0:lb /> or Cheese to eat with, our bread, our<ns0:lb /> Change being so great that                    one of our<ns0:lb /> Young Men says they want nothing but a<ns0:lb /> Cow to make their                    living equal to <ns0:placeName key="chest1">Chester Coun-<ns0:lb /> -ty.</ns0:placeName>                </ns0:p>

text.headline: June 03, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Our Young Men were<ns0:lb /> all engaged in writing letters home, so<ns0:lb /> that it                    fell to my lot to <ns0:del>do</ns0:del> cook and do<ns0:lb /> the Kitchen Work. -- we are                    visited<ns0:lb /> every day by more or less of the Indians<ns0:lb /> who are much pleased                    with viewing va-<ns0:lb /> -rious kinds of our goods, which satisfaction<ns0:lb /> is                    increased by our giving them some little <ns0:lb /> matters. Two Indians, one being a                    Chief paid<ns0:lb /> us a visit this Morning, and we <ns0:del>were</ns0:del> being                    employ-<ns0:lb /> -ed in Writing and reading, <ns0:del>and</ns0:del> endea-<ns0:lb /> -voured to                    let them know that we did not<ns0:lb /> work on first day, tho we found it                    difficult<ns0:lb /> to make them sensible of the reason<ns0:lb /> why we cease there from,                    -- We shewed<ns0:lb /> them Howells Map of Pennsylvania,<ns0:lb /> with which they were                    much diverted<ns0:lb /> and seemed to understand it pretty<ns0:lb /> well, particularly                    the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">Allegeny River</ns0:geogName>                    <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_99" n="97" /> and the large streams which run into<ns0:lb />                    it. -- Since our coming into these parts<ns0:lb /> we have kept meetings twice a                    week, our<ns0:lb /> opportunity to day <ns0:del>to</ns0:del> felt like a parting                    meeting,<ns0:lb /> and a travel was experienced for the pre-<ns0:lb /> -servation of our                    Young Men whom we<ns0:lb /> expect Shortly to leave, it was a time where-<ns0:lb /> -in we                    witnessed our Strength renewed ----</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Some days latterly has been warm yet the nights are<ns0:lb /> Cool, so that                    bedcloaths feels pleasant, since<ns0:lb /> our goods arrived <ns0:persName key="jpier1">John Pierce</ns0:persName> and myself,<ns0:lb /> who are Bedfellows, have steadily                    had four<ns0:lb /> Blankets under us, and the same number<ns0:lb /> above, yet none to                    many. -- We have<ns0:lb /> had much Wet weather for a Week past,<ns0:lb /> so that we have                    been prevented as yet, from<ns0:lb /> setting the Plough to go, but if the                    weather<ns0:lb /> suits, hope to start it tomorrow, having<ns0:lb /> two Acres of Ground                    dearly ready. ----</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> The <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName> has perhaps double the water in                    now<ns0:lb /> that it had some time ago, yet nearly as clear<ns0:lb /> as common. -- we                    have had to ad-<ns0:lb /> -mire the Quantity of fog that fills the<ns0:lb /> Atmosphere                    every morning, so that I do<ns0:lb /> not recollect seeing the Sun rise clear<ns0:lb />                    since we came her. -- And as it has<ns0:lb /> been a rainy damp time latterly, Clouds                    of<ns0:lb /> fog are frequently rising out of the <ns0:geogName key="alleg">River</ns0:geogName>. <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_100" n="98" /> the lower parts of some Mountains<ns0:lb />                    near our Settlement, which fog ascend s<ns0:lb /> said Mountains in thick Colums                    un-<ns0:lb /> -usual to what I have been acquainted<ns0:lb /> with.</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 05, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> The sun made its appearance <ns0:del><ns0:gap /></ns0:del><ns0:lb /> this Morning, and there is                    some pros- <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_101" n="99" /> -pect of a pretty pleasant day for                    traveling<ns0:lb /> and not knowing what Minute <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplan-<ns0:lb />                        -ter</ns0:persName> and his Company would call on us, we<ns0:lb /> felt our Minds                    baptized <ns0:del>at</ns0:del> with the prospect<ns0:lb /> of a seperation, and sat down                    together<ns0:lb /> to take a parting Oppertunity, it was an<ns0:lb /> endearing time of                    retirement, wherein<ns0:lb /> the Canopy of divine Love was spread over<ns0:lb /> us, to                    the Contriting of our Spirits, and<ns0:lb /> a living travel was experienced,                    that<ns0:lb /> as the time was <ns0:del>we</ns0:del> nearly approached when we ex-<ns0:lb />                    -pected to part, that Ancient good-<ns0:lb /> -ness might be near to them that                    stayed,<ns0:lb /> to Comfort, Strengthen, and preserve, in<ns0:lb /> their lonely Cottage,                    and ardious under-<ns0:lb /> -taking;
