which considering the many favours<ns0:lb /> we have                    experienced since we set out<ns0:lb /> on the presant business, there was<ns0:lb /> no                    Cause to doubt, but as they were tru-<ns0:lb /> -ly watchful, and attentive on their                    part,<ns0:lb /> would still be continued. -- And that<ns0:lb /> we who are going might                        <ns0:del>still</ns0:del> continue<ns0:lb /> to experience the Lords protecting Pow-<ns0:lb />                    -er through a Solatary Wilderness, and<ns0:lb /> tedious Journey. ----</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We have been holding ourselves in readiness<ns0:lb /> since six OClock this morning,                    having<ns0:lb /> our horses most of the time prepared <ns0:del>ready</ns0:del> to                        <ns0:del>mo</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> mount with a few minutes notice, ex-<ns0:lb /> -pecting                        <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> and his Company<ns0:lb /> to have                    called on us, but it is now<ns0:lb /> near sunset and the have not made<ns0:lb /> there                    appearance, nor sent any <ns0:del>no</ns0:del> reason<ns0:lb /> why, so that we continue to                    find patience<ns0:lb /> a necessary Virtue to have in possession<ns0:lb /> we have had a                    few <ns0:del>a</ns0:del> light showers to day, but<ns0:lb /> a prospect of a beautiful                    Evening, &<ns0:lb /> a clear setting sun. </ns0:p>

text.headline: June 09, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">This Morning went 4 miles on the Beach down<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="lakee">Lake</ns0:geogName> and the <ns0:geogName key="niagr">River Niagara</ns0:geogName>,                    which is<ns0:lb /> the outlet of said <ns0:geogName key="lakee">Lake</ns0:geogName>, to the                    Narrows, <ns0:del>wh</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> were we Crossed the <ns0:geogName key="niagr">River</ns0:geogName> into upper <ns0:placeName key="canad">Ca-<ns0:lb />                        -nada</ns0:placeName>, it was ¾ of a Mile wide about 16 feet<ns0:lb /> deep, and a                    rough Strong Current, our<ns0:lb /> boat was narrow and tottering, and one<ns0:lb /> of                    the horses a little unruly so that we felt<ns0:lb /> thankful when we got safely on                    shore, we<ns0:lb /> then turned square to our left, up the<ns0:lb /> side of the <ns0:geogName key="niagr">River</ns0:geogName> to the <ns0:geogName key="lakee">Lake</ns0:geogName>,                    passing<ns0:lb /> by <ns0:placeName key="ferie">Fort Erie</ns0:placeName>, then up the Margin                    of<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="lakee">Lake</ns0:geogName> on a fine firm beech that                    made<ns0:lb /> a beautiful Road 6 or 7 miles, then turning<ns0:lb /> square to our right                    in about 1 ½ miles ar-<ns0:lb /> -rived at <ns0:persName key="dpoun1">Daniel                        Pounds</ns0:persName>, where we were<ns0:lb /> kindly received, and felt thankful,                    we<ns0:lb /> were once more among our friends. In<ns0:lb /> the afternoon we paid a visit                    to <ns0:persName key="jmorr1">Joel Mor-<ns0:lb /> -reses</ns0:persName>, who were much                    pleased on seeing us,<ns0:lb /> and in the evening went to <ns0:del>our</ns0:del> my Old                    home<ns0:lb /> when here last fall, and kind friends<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="ascho1">Asa Schooly</ns0:persName> and Wife, who were truly<ns0:lb /> glad                    to see us, and we them, here we got<ns0:lb /> a clean good Bed, which was what we had <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_115" n="113" /> not experienced since we left <ns0:placeName key="pitts">Pittsburgh</ns0:placeName>, hav-<ns0:lb /> -ing for near four weeks slept                    on the ground<ns0:lb /> and on boards, in our blankets. 15 miles </ns0:p>

text.headline: June 14, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Having got our <ns0:del>linen</ns0:del> linen &c. Washed &<ns0:lb /> being ready to                    leave <ns0:placeName key="canad">Canada</ns0:placeName>, I feel easy<ns0:lb /> to make one                    general note of the face of the<ns0:lb /> Country, Timber &c. As far as I have                    been <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_122" n="120" /> through it, in the general it is a                    level<ns0:lb /> Country, while in a state of Woods, much<ns0:lb /> of it is Wet, with a                    black mud on the<ns0:lb /> top and a stiff Clay under, which<ns0:lb /> Clay prevents the                    Water from soaking<ns0:lb /> down, when cleared in a dry time<ns0:lb /> this Clay land                        <ns0:del>beakes</ns0:del> bakes very hard &<ns0:lb /> is difficult tilling, tho in                    other places the soil <ns0:del>it</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> is <ns0:del>a</ns0:del> loamy <ns0:del>soil</ns0:del>.                    The land in general is<ns0:lb /> of a good quality and a fine grass land,<ns0:lb /> good                    springs of water are scarce, as are<ns0:lb /> lively runing Streams: and the                    Waters<ns0:lb /> fail much in dry Weather. In places<ns0:lb /> there are a plenty of a                    coarse flinty<ns0:lb /> Limestone, but in the general few stones<ns0:lb /> are to be seen,                    Scarcely a spot to be met<ns0:lb /> with, except where it is cleaned, but what<ns0:lb />                    is very heavy, Timbered Land. I do<ns0:lb /> not recollect of ever passing through                    a<ns0:lb /> Country that has so large a proportion<ns0:lb /> of clean, straight, beautiful                    White lakes<ns0:lb /> as a considerable part of this has; there<ns0:lb /> are also a                    Considerable quantity of <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_123" n="121" /> White and Black Ash, Poplar, Chesnut,                    Elm,<ns0:lb /> Shellbark Hiccory, Bass Wood or Lyn, Sugar<ns0:lb /> Maple, Beech, White                    Pine &c. When the roads<ns0:lb /> are first opened and used they are mostly<ns0:lb />                    muddy, in places very deep, but after they<ns0:lb /> have been used 8 or 10 years and                    the Roots<ns0:lb /> rotten and gone, they get pretty good, tho<ns0:lb /> at present there                    are amany deep places.<ns0:lb /> as far as I can learn their Summers are plea-<ns0:lb />                    -sant tho nearly, in the daytime, as warm<ns0:lb /> as our own are, but the evenings                    and<ns0:lb /> nights mostly cool, so that a blanket & Cover-<ns0:lb /> -lit are not                    often unpleasant sleeping<ns0:lb /> under, -- there Winters are steady and more<ns0:lb />                    Snow lies on the ground than in our parts, but<ns0:lb /> in convesation with some who                    moved out of<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>these parts</ns0:del> the Jersyes and <ns0:placeName key="penns">Pennsylvania</ns0:placeName>, they were of the Mind we have<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>a</ns0:del> many days here, as cold as any they have there,<ns0:lb /> but we have                    more warm ones, their Win-<ns0:lb /> -ters mostly set in towards the middle of                    the<ns0:lb /> 12th Mo, and in the forepart of winter they<ns0:lb /> have frequent snows,                    until the ground<ns0:lb /> becomes 18, 20, or 24 Inches deep, but seldom<ns0:lb /> more,                    which snow continues without much additi-<ns0:lb /> -on until the Middle of the third                    Month, which <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_124" n="122" /> which is their pleasantest time for                    traveling in<ns0:lb /> the whole Year, they do their Carting and<ns0:lb /> traveling much                    with Sleds, the roads be-<ns0:lb /> -come smooth and good, there are no swam ps<ns0:lb />                    or mud in the way, neither is the snow<ns0:lb /> often softened with rain in the                    Winter,<ns0:lb /> some seasons they have had very little or no<ns0:lb /> frost in the                    Ground; and as far as they have<ns0:lb /> tryed Cover, they say it <ns0:del>does</ns0:del>                    answers very well, not<ns0:lb /> being hurt in the winter, with frost.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> About 9 O Clock this morning we took leave<ns0:lb /> of our kind, and Valued friends                        <ns0:persName key="ascho1">Asa Schooly</ns0:persName><ns0:lb /> and Wife, with their                    children, hav-<ns0:lb /> -ing their, and many friends, hearty<ns0:lb /> Wishes for our                    safe return, stoped at<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="dpoun1">Daniel Pounds</ns0:persName>, a little while, then tak-<ns0:lb />                    -ing our leave of them, <ns0:del>and</ns0:del> set of down<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="lakee">Lake</ns0:geogName> for <ns0:placeName key="buffa">Buffaloe</ns0:placeName>,                    & arrived at the fer-<ns0:lb /> -ry about 12 where we found the Chief fer-<ns0:lb />                    -ryman, so in Liquor as not to be fit to<ns0:lb /> take any Care, but a trusty Old                    man who<ns0:lb /> sometimes Assisted agreed to take us over,<ns0:lb /> the Wind was pretty                    high, and the <ns0:geogName key="niagr">River</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> ran swift, he                    concluded to lash two boats<ns0:lb /> together to keep the one our horse                        <ns0:del>was</ns0:del> were <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_125" n="123" /> in Studier, which was very acceptable                    to<ns0:lb /> us, having found when we Crossed before <ns0:del>were going</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>over,</ns0:del> that it was a dangerous ferry, and<ns0:lb /> rocking boat; but now                    on our return<ns0:lb /> we went over very steady, tho the Current beat<ns0:lb /> us down                    the <ns0:geogName key="niagr">River</ns0:geogName> ¾ of a Mile, shortly<ns0:lb /> after we                    had got on Shore, and mounted, we<ns0:lb /> saw a man at a great distance towards<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="buffa">Buffaloe</ns0:placeName>, coming riding towards us, whom<ns0:lb />                    we presently knew to be our <ns0:persName key="ijohn1">Indian John</ns0:persName><ns0:lb />                    who was coming to <ns0:del>meet</ns0:del> look for us, he appeared<ns0:lb /> much pleased to                        <ns0:del>see</ns0:del> meet us, as we did to see him,<ns0:lb /> and to find that our Mare                    was safe. ----</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We got to <ns0:placeName key="buffa">Buffoloe</ns0:placeName> about 2 OClock and<ns0:lb />                    tho a Day later than we agreed to meet<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> here, yet neither he nor any                    of<ns0:lb /> his company were come, -- about Sunset<ns0:lb /> his Son <ns0:persName key="habee1">Henry</ns0:persName>, and another Indian arrived<ns0:lb /> and informed                    us that <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName>, and<ns0:lb /> 10 or 12 more                    were on there way, and would<ns0:lb /> be here by 10 OClock tomorrow, 15 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 15, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> About 12 OClock <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> and his<ns0:lb />                    company arrived at the Opposite side of <ns0:placeName key="buffa">Buf-<ns0:lb />                        -faloe</ns0:placeName>, we walked down to the <ns0:geogName key="niagr">River</ns0:geogName> to recieve<ns0:lb /> them, when the <ns0:del>Landed</ns0:del> came                    across, they appeared please d <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_126" n="124" /> to see us, <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> enquiring after our<ns0:lb /> health since we left him,                    he gave us<ns0:lb /> a letter from our friends dated 5 days<ns0:lb /> after we came away,                    informing they<ns0:lb /> were well in health, and enjoyed a<ns0:lb /> peaceful Mind, that                    they had got their<ns0:lb /> Corn planted, and were preparing ground<ns0:lb /> for                    Popatoes, that there had been much<ns0:lb /> rain since we left them, and that                    the<ns0:lb /> gnats and Muschetoes were more trou-<ns0:lb /> blesome than heretofore.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">                    <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> having got some information                    that<ns0:lb /> we were a little uneasy about staying<ns0:lb /> as none of <ns0:persName key="rmorr1">Robert Morris</ns0:persName>'s Commissi-<ns0:lb /> -oners were arrived,                        <ns0:del>he</ns0:del> this Afternoon<ns0:lb /> >he took an Oppertunity with us,                    Observing<ns0:lb /> that he expected by this time we had seen<ns0:lb /> enough of the                    Wilderness to <ns0:del>form</ns0:del> know, that were<ns0:lb /> people were to be collected                    from diffi-<ns0:lb /> -rent parts to do publick business, it<ns0:lb /> required time, and                    he hoped if <ns0:persName key="ichap1">Cap-<ns0:lb /> -tain Chapin</ns0:persName> should not                    arrive this evening <ns0:del>to night</ns0:del>, <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_127" n="125" /> we would try to make ourselves as                    hap-<ns0:lb /> -py as we could, and stay a few days long<ns0:lb /> -er, for he had a great                    desire we should<ns0:lb /> be with them at the Council, and see<ns0:lb /> that all things                    were settled fairly, then we<ns0:lb /> would be able to inform our friends at                    home<ns0:lb /> and if they were not settled fairly <ns0:del>then</ns0:del> we<ns0:lb /> could also                    inform our friends. It brought<ns0:lb /> a close exercise over our Minds to know                    what<ns0:lb /> was best to do, a number of the Indians<ns0:lb /> were collected, yet it                    looked likely it <ns0:del>was</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> would be some time before all parties<ns0:lb />                    would get together, as none of the White<ns0:lb /> people immeadeately concerned                    were<ns0:lb /> come. We let him know we would have<ns0:lb /> been glad to have attended                    the Council, but<ns0:lb /> it was now drawing towards the latter end<ns0:lb /> of the                    Week, and <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> the White people did<ns0:lb /> not do business on first                    day, that it was<ns0:lb /> not very likely <ns0:del>that</ns0:del>                    <ns0:persName key="ichap1">Captain Chapin</ns0:persName> &c<ns0:lb /> would                        <ns0:del>not</ns0:del> leave <ns0:placeName key="canan">Canandarque</ns0:placeName>                    before<ns0:lb /> 2nd day Morning, and that it would be a<ns0:lb /> number of days before                    the Council<ns0:lb /> would meet, however we were willing <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_128" n="126" /> Closely to consider the subject                        <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> this Evening</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 16, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Having attended to <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanters</ns0:persName> re-<ns0:lb />                    -quest, of last evening, I felt my Mind<ns0:lb /> this Morning easy to move                    homewards, but<ns0:lb /> upon mentioning it to my Companion<ns0:lb /> he said he did not                    witness that clear-<ns0:lb /> -ness to set out he wished to experience<ns0:lb /> yet                    condescended if I thought best of<ns0:lb /> letting the Chief know, that upon<ns0:lb />                    weighing his request in the best man-<ns0:lb /> -ner we could, We felt easy to                    move<ns0:lb /> homewards this morning; this infor-<ns0:lb /> -mation was given him by                    walking<ns0:lb /> down to his encampment, he with a<ns0:lb /> number of others pretty soon                    came up to<ns0:lb /> our lodgings, and let us know, he was<ns0:lb /> sorry we could not                    make our Minds easy<ns0:lb /> to have stayed a few days longer, no ways<ns0:lb /> doubting                    but <ns0:persName key="ichap1">Captain Chapin</ns0:persName> and others concerned<ns0:lb />                    would be here to day; but perhaps<ns0:lb /> as we had been a considerable time                        <ns0:del>fr</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> from home, and living was expensive,<ns0:lb /> we might be                    much run out of the means <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_129" n="127" /> that enabled us to stay, which made<ns0:lb />                    us so anxious to return. I informed<ns0:lb /> him, when I left home, I expected to                    have<ns0:lb /> returned in about 40 days, that it was now<ns0:lb /> near 50 days, and if                    we went by <ns0:placeName key="oneid">Oneida</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb /> to see the Indians                    there, which we proposed,<ns0:lb /> it would take near 30 days more before we<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>got</ns0:del> could get home, that our Circumstances as<ns0:lb /> to money was not                    in the way, for we had<ns0:lb /> plenty. he said he had left home on pub-<ns0:lb /> -lic                    Business, expecting to have return-<ns0:lb /> -ed in 50 or 60 days, and it had taken                    him<ns0:lb /> near a Year before he had got back, and<ns0:lb /> that he had found it his                    duty to sacrafice<ns0:lb /> privet conveniency to public good;<ns0:lb /> and he would have                    us do so too:<ns0:lb /> we let him know, the business we came<ns0:lb /> about appeared to                    be agreeable settled<ns0:lb /> to both their and our Minds, that this o-<ns0:lb /> -ther                    business, was something we knew<ns0:lb /> nothing of <ns0:del>about</ns0:del> untill since                    among<ns0:lb /> them, that we would have been will-<ns0:lb /> -ing to have set with them                    in Coun-<ns0:lb /> -cil, tho did not know we could be of<ns0:lb /> any <ns0:del>use</ns0:del>                    service to them, and that the <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_130" n="128" /> business between him and <ns0:persName key="ichap1">Captain Cha-<ns0:lb /> -pin</ns0:persName> relating to a Mill, we                    thought<ns0:lb /> when he and the Captain conferred to<ns0:lb /> -gather on the Subject,                    we might be ful-<ns0:lb /> -ly informed of their result by letter.<ns0:lb /> he then                    informed us he was become per-<ns0:lb /> -fectly reconciled to our going, and as<ns0:lb />                    the Council was expected every<ns0:lb /> day to meet, he could not go with us<ns0:lb /> to                        <ns0:placeName key="canan">Canandargue</ns0:placeName>, as he had proposed,<ns0:lb /> but                    that <ns0:persName key="ijohn1">John</ns0:persName>, who had hitherto been<ns0:lb /> with us,                    would go through to the <ns0:geogName key="genes2">Che-<ns0:lb /> -nesee                    River</ns0:geogName>, and that he wished the<ns0:lb /> good Spirit who had hitherto                    pre-<ns0:lb /> -served us, would safely keep us on our<ns0:lb /> Journey, until we arrived                    at our own<ns0:lb /> homes, he further desired we would<ns0:lb /> make ourselves,                    perfectly easy about<ns0:lb /> our Young Men, who were left a-<ns0:lb /> mong his People,                    for he would take<ns0:lb /> the necessary care of them, and that they<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>and that</ns0:del> would be entirely safe.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We now took An affectionate farewell of<ns0:lb /> the Chief, and the Indians present,                    who<ns0:lb /> parted with us with much respect; and<ns0:lb /> I can truly say, the longer                    I have been<ns0:lb /> among that People, the more near and<ns0:lb /> united they have felt                    to me, and <ns0:del>that</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> now on parting, the felt like bretheren<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>like</ns0:del> with whom I <ns0:del>have</ns0:del> had been intamate<ns0:lb /> -ly                    acquainted, and for whose wellfare<ns0:lb /> I feel ardant Wishes. ----</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> About 8 O Clock we left <ns0:placeName key="buffa">Buffaloe</ns0:placeName>, hav-<ns0:lb />                    -ing a fine day to enter the Wilderness,<ns0:lb /> and there having been about a                    Week<ns0:lb /> of dry weather, the road was this day<ns0:lb /> pretty good, so that with                    industry we<ns0:lb /> traveled by computation 45 miles.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Much of this days ride was through a country<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>land of</ns0:del> very <ns0:del>little or no</ns0:del> thinly timbered, wich was<ns0:lb />                    grown over with plenty of pretty good grass,<ns0:lb /> so that I thought thousands of                    Cattle might<ns0:lb /> have fattened upon it, if it was not for a<ns0:lb /> certain                    species of large flies, and Musche-<ns0:lb /> -toes, we stoped twice to let our                    horses eat <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_132" n="130" /> grass, but they were so Worried with                    these<ns0:lb /> Animals, that the did little but run about<ns0:lb /> until we got bushes                    and kept them of.<ns0:lb /> If we stoped our horses one Minute in<ns0:lb /> some places in                    the Woods, the Musche-<ns0:lb /> -toes would be on them in such swarms<ns0:lb /> as almost                    to hide their natural Colour,<ns0:lb /> and none but those who have experienced<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> the trial can rightly form an Idea, how trou-<ns0:lb /> blesome the                    were to the Rider, I cou-<ns0:lb /> -vered my head, neck, and most of my<ns0:lb /> face                    with my Silk handkerchief, laped<ns0:lb /> my Pocket do: around one of my hands<ns0:lb />                    and with all the <ns0:del>other</ns0:del> defence I could<ns0:lb /> make was much bit and                    Swelled with<ns0:lb /> them, -- When Night came <ns0:del>an</ns0:del> we got<ns0:lb /> no relief,                    we took up our quarters, a-<ns0:lb /> -bout Sunset, beside a small stream<ns0:lb /> of                    good Water, under the Boughs of an<ns0:lb /> Oak, and erected fires, in                    diffirent<ns0:lb /> places around us in order to smoke<ns0:lb /> them of, but with all our                    defence we<ns0:lb /> were worried the whole night throug[h] <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_133" n="131" /> So that we slept but little, our                    horses,<ns0:lb /> as may readily be supposed, fared no<ns0:lb /> better, they would away                    out to eating,<ns0:lb /> and then in a little time return trot-<ns0:lb /> -ting back to                    the fire, and it was with with<ns0:lb /> much difficulty we got them sad-<ns0:lb /> -dled                    in the Morning. 45 miles </ns0:p>

text.headline: June 17, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Set of early this Morning, being willing<ns0:lb /> to leave Muschetoe Camp, the road                    not<ns0:lb /> so good as Yesterday, having a large<ns0:lb /> number, of deep Swamps, and                    about 20 miles of <ns0:del>a</ns0:del> thick<ns0:lb /> woods to pass through, wherein we                    found no diminution<ns0:lb /> of the Muschetoes, but about noon we ar-<ns0:lb /> -rived                        <ns0:del>in</ns0:del> at the plains within 8 miles of<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="genes2">Chenesee River</ns0:geogName>, where our horses<ns0:lb /> could eat                    grass without much molestati-<ns0:lb /> -on having left the big flys and the o-<ns0:lb />                    -ther tormenting insects chiefly behind us.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We crosed the <ns0:geogName key="genes2">River</ns0:geogName> about 4, on the flats<ns0:lb />                    of which there was a great burden of natu-<ns0:lb /> -ral grass, and about the Road                    Timothy &<ns0:lb /> Clover, the seed having droped from horses<ns0:lb /> as the                    traveled along, I lodged at Pearsons<ns0:lb /> 4½ Miles on this side the River,                    having left <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_134" n="132" /> my Companion a few miles behind on<ns0:lb />                    special business. 35 miles.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> The Richness of the Soil between <ns0:placeName key="buffa">Buf-<ns0:lb />                        -foloe</ns0:placeName> and the <ns0:geogName key="genes2">Chenesee River</ns0:geogName>                    <ns0:del>has</ns0:del> is no<ns0:lb /> way lessoned in my view by riding<ns0:lb /> through it at                    this time, but the first<ns0:lb /> Settlers will meet with a great trial<ns0:lb /> in the                    Summer Season from the In<ns0:lb /> -sects I have mentioned, but when the<ns0:lb />                    Country becomes Settled, the low places<ns0:lb /> Cleared, and dry, that affliction                    will<ns0:lb /> I believe cease, for I saw very little stag-<ns0:lb /> -nated Water, --                    much of this Country<ns0:lb /> is scarce of Springs, or streams of<ns0:lb /> Water, and                    what there is very much<ns0:lb /> fails in dry Seasons, so that its va-<ns0:lb />                    -luableness will be greatly lessened<ns0:lb /> thereby.</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 18, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> About noon <ns0:persName key="jpier1">John Peirce</ns0:persName> arrived at<ns0:lb /> my                    Quarters, he having since I left him<ns0:lb /> had a full interview with <ns0:persName key="ichap1">Captain<ns0:lb /> Chapin</ns0:persName>, who is the superintendant                    of<ns0:lb /> the Indians for the united States, <ns0:persName key="jpier1">John</ns0:persName><ns0:lb /> gave him a full information <ns0:del>with</ns0:del> of what <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_0135" n="133" /> we had been doing at <ns0:placeName key="cornp">Cornplanters set-<ns0:lb /> -tlement</ns0:placeName>, and an account of                    the Young<ns0:lb /> Men we had left there, the <ns0:persName key="ichap1">Captain</ns0:persName> ex-<ns0:lb /> pressed great satisfaction with our pro-<ns0:lb />                    ceedings, and thought there was encouragement<ns0:lb /> to extend labour towards that                    people, for<ns0:lb /> he had been sometime past through the<ns0:lb /> Oneida settlement                    and he apprehended he<ns0:lb /> saw considerable improvement since <ns0:del>o</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    friends extended care there.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> About 2 O Clock we sat of towards <ns0:placeName key="canan">Canan-<ns0:lb />                        -darque</ns0:placeName>, and for 9 or 10 miles we passed through<ns0:lb /> a thick                    settled, highly improved Country,<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>for</ns0:del> considering the settlement <ns0:del>to be</ns0:del> was no more than 10                    years<ns0:lb /> old, which to me was very animating,<ns0:lb /> having for 300 miles past                    been mostly in<ns0:lb /> the Wilderness where improvments were<ns0:lb /> not to be seen,                    here we had beautiful Timo-<ns0:lb /> -thy, and Clover fields almost Constantly<ns0:lb />                    in view, with a good appearance of wheat<ns0:lb /> Indian Corn, flax, Oates &c.                    these we shewed<ns0:lb /> to our <ns0:persName key="ijohn1">Indian guide</ns0:persName>, he                    alighted to examine<ns0:lb /> the heads of Wheat, we shewed him the flax                        <ns0:del>that</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> that Shirts &c. were made of, with which he<ns0:lb />                    appeared pleased, we saw four Men howing corn<ns0:lb /> these we pointed to, telling                    him they were not <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_136" n="134" /> Squas, or Women, and that was the                    way<ns0:lb /> the White People did their Work, he<ns0:lb /> knew our meaning, which he                    expressed<ns0:lb /> by a lively smile. We now parted with<ns0:lb /> him, having traveled                    together 170 miles<ns0:lb /> he going on for <ns0:placeName key="canan">Canandarque</ns0:placeName>, and<ns0:lb /> >we for <ns0:geogName key="mudcr">Mud                        Creek</ns0:geogName>, he was the same Indian<ns0:lb /> Chief who lives near by to                    where our Young<ns0:lb /> are Settled, whom <ns0:persName key="cornp2">Cornplanter</ns0:persName> said, as<ns0:lb /> heretofore noted, was a sober Man,                    like<ns0:lb /> ourselves, <ns0:del>he</ns0:del> would drink no Whiskey, we<ns0:lb /> have had some                    oppertunity of proving<ns0:lb /> this Assertion, being several days<ns0:lb /> with him at                    the Tavern, at <ns0:placeName key="buffa">Buffoloe</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb /> were the Indians                    were drinking Spirits<ns0:lb /> and I did not see him meddle with any                    <ns0:del>it</ns0:del>.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We now left the State road, turning to<ns0:lb /> our left through a Country but                    little in-<ns0:lb /> -habitted, an open Woods, and thin land<ns0:lb /> until within 2                    miles of <ns0:geogName key="mudcr">Mud Creek</ns0:geogName>, here<ns0:lb /> was heavy timber                    and good land, we<ns0:lb /> lodged at <ns0:persName key="jsmit1">Jacob Smiths</ns0:persName>                    who has a Mill<ns0:lb /> and Sawmill on Said <ns0:geogName key="mudcr">Creek</ns0:geogName>                    on a fine<ns0:lb /> natural fall. <ns0:gap /> 20 miles to day.</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 19, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Went to <ns0:persName key="ncoms1">Nathan Cornstalk</ns0:persName>s 6 miles<ns0:lb /> through                    good land, heavily Timber’d<ns0:lb /> part of which was very fine White Oaks,<ns0:lb />                    rested here untill after dinner, then<ns0:lb /> went to <ns0:persName key="alaph1">Abraham Lapham</ns0:persName>’s, 2 miles,<ns0:lb /> where I left my companion, and                    went<ns0:lb /> 2 miles to <ns0:persName key="cmacu1">Caleb Macumber</ns0:persName>’s,                    who<ns0:lb /> with his Wife are valuable young<ns0:lb /> friends, lately settled in these                    parts,<ns0:lb /> in the evening, they went with me<ns0:lb /> 1½ miles to there fathers,                        <ns0:persName key="jsmit2">Jeremiah – <ns0:lb /> Smiths</ns0:persName>, where we lodged,                    11 miles </ns0:p>

text.headline: June 20, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">                    <ns0:persName key="cmacu1">Caleb</ns0:persName> and his Wife went with me to <ns0:persName key="alaph1">Abra-<ns0:lb /> -ham Lapham’s</ns0:persName>, this Morning, where                    we<ns0:lb /> stayed until after dinner, being among<ns0:lb /> kind, valuable friends, and                    our hor-<ns0:lb /> -ses fareing very well, render’d it an agree-<ns0:lb /> -able time.                        <ns0:del>I</ns0:del> having in company with the Com-<ns0:lb /> -mittee that went to                        <ns0:placeName key="canad">Canada</ns0:placeName> last fall, <ns0:del>which <ns0:gap /></ns0:del>                    visit friend s<ns0:lb /> here in there families, and held several Meet-<ns0:lb /> -ings                    amongst them, I felt great satisfaction<ns0:lb /> in being once more amongst them,                    and the<ns0:lb /> company of a Friend to those Remotely situated<ns0:lb /> is very Joyous                    more specially when such love<ns0:lb /> the Truth and are concerned to support the <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_138" n="136" /> profession they are makeing, which                    I<ns0:lb /> trust is in a good degree the situation<ns0:lb /> of a few friends here, they                    having been<ns0:lb /> strengthd since we were here last fall<ns0:lb /> to hold Meetings                    twice a Week; often <ns0:del>m</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> more than 30 meeting on the fist day,                    and<ns0:lb /> half that <ns0:del>here</ns0:del> and set                    of for <ns0:placeName key="oneid">Oneida</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="cmacu1">Caleb Macumber</ns0:persName>
