text.headline: June 21, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Set of early this morning, passed throu gh<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>about</ns0:del> 13 miles, of a light soil, thinly timber-<ns0:lb /> -ed, some of                    which was pitch pine, being the<ns0:lb /> first we have seen for several hundred<ns0:lb />                    miles past, thence 8 or 9 miles through<ns0:lb /> a very rich beautiful limeston                    country all<ns0:lb /> thick Woods, we have now entred what<ns0:lb /> is called the                    Mililary Lands in <ns0:placeName key="onoco">Onanda-<ns0:lb /> -ga County</ns0:placeName>,                    and I do not recollect of ever<ns0:lb /> seeing 8 miles of Land more beautifull<ns0:lb />                    both for situation, and quality, and tim-<ns0:lb /> -ber than this, - As I rode over                    it I anticipated <ns0:del>contem-</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>-plated</ns0:del> the time, when this land will be<ns0:lb /> crouded with We althy                    Farmers, abound-<ns0:lb /> -ing with large stocks of Cattle &c. Vieing each<ns0:lb />                    other with their fields of Wheat, Corn, Grass &c<ns0:lb /> >& regaleing                    themselves around their Tables<ns0:lb /> richly loaded with provision. --- Here                    we<ns0:lb /> arrived at the outlet of <ns0:geogName key="senec">Seneca Lake</ns0:geogName>, a                    stream <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_140" n="138" /> perhaps <ns0:del>at</ns0:del> as large as three                    of <ns0:geogName key="brand">Brandywine</ns0:geogName>, when<ns0:lb /> we first came on the                    River it looked very deep<ns0:lb /> and glided along with an easy current,<ns0:lb /> but                    in a little time we came to a rapid a<ns0:lb /> Mile in length, on which are                    erected<ns0:lb /> an Elegant Merchant Mill, and a<ns0:lb /> Sawmill that appeared to do a                    great<ns0:lb /> deal of Business, the stand <ns0:del>appeared</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>to me</ns0:del> is very valuable, as the Co unt<ns0:unclear>ry</ns0:unclear><ns0:lb /> round                    is fertile, and suitable for<ns0:lb /> raising Wheat, salt and goods of va-<ns0:lb />                    -rious kinds are boated up this River<ns0:lb /> to a little below the Mill, then                    Cart-<ns0:lb /> -ed above the rapids, and from thence<ns0:lb /> taken by boat                        <ns0:del>up</ns0:del> into the <ns0:geogName key="senec">Seneca Lake</ns0:geogName>, which                    is<ns0:lb /> 40 miles in length and opens into<ns0:lb /> a very fine Country, we were                    informed<ns0:lb /> that this stream seldom rises more than<ns0:lb /> Six Inches with any                    fresh, the <ns0:geogName key="senec">Lake</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> forming a large bason                    which contains<ns0:lb /> the freshes, <ns0:del>and is</ns0:del>                    <ns0:del>which is let out gra-</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>-dually,</ns0:del> -- thence to <ns0:geogName key="cayug">Cyuga Lake</ns0:geogName>                    three<ns0:lb /> miles, here we fed our horses and cooked<ns0:lb /> our own Breakfast, we                    then crossed sd. La[ke] <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_141" n="139" /> in a Boat, a little above its outlet, it                    be-<ns0:lb /> -ing one mile <ns0:del>across</ns0:del> wide, and 13 or 14 feet deep<ns0:lb /> we                    were informed the <ns0:geogName key="cayug">Lake</ns0:geogName> was 45 miles<ns0:lb /> long,                    and in places four Miles Wide, we now<ns0:lb /> entred a pretty thick settled                    Country, consi-<ns0:lb /> -derably improved, the Land still very good<ns0:lb /> with                    plenty of Limestone, and in eight miles<ns0:lb /> crossed a large lively stream                        <ns0:del>which <ns0:gap /></ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>is formed</ns0:del> being <ns0:del>was</ns0:del> the outlet of <ns0:geogName key="owasc">Owasco Lake</ns0:geogName>, which<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>was</ns0:del>                    <ns0:geogName key="owasc">Lake</ns0:geogName> is 12 miles long and one broad; about 1 ½<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>miles</ns0:del> miles on this side we fed at <ns0:del>one</ns0:del> Good-<ns0:lb /> -riches,                    thence to Carpenters 10½ miles over<ns0:lb /> a very fine Country pretty well                    watered<ns0:lb /> which has not been the case <ns0:del>which has not been the case</ns0:del>                    for <ns0:del>until latterly</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> many miles back which Country was                    considerably settled, few of<ns0:lb /> the improvments older than four years,<ns0:lb /> I                    have been much delighted in the last 15<ns0:lb /> miles ride, in beholding the                    beautiful and<ns0:lb /> well grown fields of Wheat, Clover and Ti-<ns0:lb /> -mothy mixed,                    and lots of Corn, -- I thought<ns0:lb /> one half of the Cleared Land was in with                    grass<ns0:lb /> and that many farmers would cut from<ns0:lb /> 20 to 30 Tons of Hay. For                    thirty miles back<ns0:lb /> I think it is without exception the best body<ns0:lb /> of                    land I have seen since we left home. We<ns0:lb /> got a five O Clock dinner at                        <ns0:persName>Carpenters</ns0:persName>                    <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_142" n="140" /> and then rode 6 miles to                        <ns0:persName>Lindseys</ns0:persName> on <ns0:placeName key="9mile">9<ns0:lb /> Mile                        Creek</ns0:placeName> a pretty large stream, being<ns0:lb /> the outlet of the                        <ns0:geogName key="skane">Shaneatetes lake</ns0:geogName>, our<ns0:lb /> last stage                    mostly woods, here we Lodged<ns0:lb /> cutting Clover and Timothy <ns0:del>grass</ns0:del>                    for our horses with a sickle<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>he having no pasture.</ns0:del> The grass is so stout, I thought it would have                        <ns0:del><ns0:gap /></ns0:del> produce near three tons of hay to the Ac<ns0:gap />                </ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> The common practice of raising Corn,<ns0:lb /> wheat &c for many Miles past, is                    to clear a piece<ns0:lb /> Land, by cutting down nearly all<ns0:lb /> the timber which                    they heap and burn<ns0:lb /> on the Spot, and when made clean, <ns0:del>they</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    Harrow the ground several times over,<ns0:lb /> then they plant, and tend the Corn                    with<ns0:lb /> the Hoe never putting a plough in the<ns0:lb /> ground, when the Corn comes                    of, in the<ns0:lb /> fall, they again harrow the ground several<ns0:lb /> times, and then                    sow it with wheat and<ns0:lb /> Timothy, and often times some Clover seed, and when                    the Wheat comes<ns0:lb /> of, mow it for several years, by that time<ns0:lb /> many of the                    roots <ns0:del>get</ns0:del> are rotten, they then<ns0:lb /> Plough and farm it as suits                    best.<ns0:lb /> 49 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 22, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Went 13 miles to breakfast the first<ns0:lb /> 7 good limestone land, unsettled,                    being<ns0:lb /> lately purchased of the <ns0:orgName key="onondaga">Onadaga                        Indians</ns0:orgName>, <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_143" n="141" /> thence a few settlements: to <ns0:geogName key="onocr">Onadaga Creek</ns0:geogName>,<ns0:lb /> 3 miles in an uncommon Valley                    surround-<ns0:lb /> -ed with high hills, in said Valley a num-<ns0:lb /> -ber of good                    improvements,</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> From <ns0:geogName key="lakee">Lake Erie</ns0:geogName> to this place a level Coun-<ns0:lb />                    -try, not a Mountain in the Whole way, nor<ns0:lb /> very few hills that a Waggon                    need lock down,<ns0:lb /> but now for about 17 miles forward the Land is con-<ns0:lb />                    -siderably hilly, and in places stony, for the<ns0:lb /> first 9 or 10 miles pretty                    thick settled, with<ns0:lb /> good improvements, from thence to <ns0:geogName key="canas">Cana-<ns0:lb /> -soraga</ns0:geogName> a smart water that runs into <ns0:geogName key="oneil">Onei-<ns0:lb /> -da Lake</ns0:geogName>, about five miles mostly Woods,<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>as</ns0:del> here we fed our horses, and rested seve-<ns0:lb /> -ral hours the day                    being very Warm, as<ns0:lb /> we descended a long hill down to this<ns0:lb /> place we                    killed a Rattle Snake about<ns0:lb /> four feet long, as thick in the Middle                        <ns0:del>as</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> as a good pitchfork handle, but was<ns0:lb /> much smaller                    towards its head; it was<ns0:lb /> of a lively dark brown, conveying a mixed<ns0:lb />                    colour to the Eye, beautiful to appearance,<ns0:lb /> it lay still in the road,                    neither offered to<ns0:lb /> fight, or run. ---- In the coarse of this<ns0:lb /> days                    ride, we passed within a few miles to <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_144" n="142" /> the right of the <ns0:placeName key="onoss">Onadaga Salt Works</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb /> a place where there are a large                    number<ns0:lb /> of Salt Springs, in a Marshy, Boggy<ns0:lb /> bottom, we were informed                    500 men are at<ns0:lb /> times employed at these works, and that<ns0:lb /> Salt may be had                    there for 62 cents Per<ns0:lb /> Bushel, and that all the Northern and<ns0:lb /> Western                    Country, and much of upper Cana-<ns0:lb /> -da is pretty much Supplyed therefrom.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">                    <ns0:del>from</ns0:del> From this Stage to the <ns0:placeName key="oneid">Oneida Vil-<ns0:lb />                        -lage</ns0:placeName> 12 miles, in about one mile we<ns0:lb /> passed by a well                    improved farm, with<ns0:lb /> a good house, Barn, and other building[s]<ns0:lb /> and a                    large proportion of good Timo-<ns0:lb /> -thy Meadow belonging to, and in the<ns0:lb />                    possession of an <ns0:del>Idian</ns0:del> Indian, he keeps<ns0:lb /> Tavern, has his Sign                    hanging <ns0:del>up</ns0:del> out as<ns0:lb /> common at Public houses from thence to the                    Village<ns0:lb /> mostly Woods, the few settlement there were,<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>was,</ns0:del> one or two excepted, was put up this<ns0:lb /> Spring, being small,                    rough, and very open,<ns0:lb /> about 6 in the Evening, we arrived at our<ns0:lb />                    friends settlement, found them all well, &<ns0:lb /> very glad to see us.                        <ns0:persName key="wgreg1">William Gregory</ns0:persName>, his <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_145" n="143" /> Wife and <ns0:persName key="hjack2">Hannah                        Jackson</ns0:persName>, having got here<ns0:lb /> about three weeks ago, after a                    passage of 15 days.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">                    <ns0:persName key="wgreg1">William's</ns0:persName> Chief view in coming, was, to                        <ns0:del>set</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> set up the Smith trade, and to instruct<ns0:lb /> some of the                    Indian Lads in that art, and<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="hjack2">Hannah</ns0:persName>’s was to open a School, and                    besides<ns0:lb /> teaching Literature, to instruct the girls<ns0:lb /> in knitting,                    sewing, &c. neither of them<ns0:lb /> have yet opened their occupations, in                    part<ns0:lb /> occationed by some unsettlement or unea-<ns0:lb /> -siness in the Indians                    Minds, in regard<ns0:lb /> to the Sale of some of their lands, and the<ns0:lb /> runing of                    their lines, Commissioners hav-<ns0:lb /> -ing been <ns0:del>busy</ns0:del> engaged in the                    business since the<ns0:lb /> arrival of our friends.</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 23, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We went on foot this Morning, <ns0:persName key="jtayl1">Jacob                    Taylor</ns0:persName><ns0:lb /> bearing us Company, to see the <ns0:orgName key="tuscarora">Tuscorora</ns0:orgName> &<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:orgName key="stockbridge">Stockbridge</ns0:orgName> Indians, they Lay South from                    this<ns0:lb /> place up the <ns0:geogName key="onecr">Oneida Creek</ns0:geogName>, the                        <ns0:orgName key="tuscarora">Tuscorora</ns0:orgName>’s<ns0:lb /> two miles of, and the                        <ns0:orgName key="stockbridge">Stockbridge nation</ns0:orgName><ns0:lb /> four, the land                    is good, <ns0:del>and</ns0:del> with a considerable<ns0:lb /> bottom <ns0:del>of it</ns0:del> up the                        <ns0:geogName key="onecr">Creek</ns0:geogName>, on which the<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:orgName key="tuscarora">Tuscororas</ns0:orgName> are Scatteringly settled, most                    of<ns0:lb /> them having some enclosures of wheat, <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_146" n="144" /> Corn, Mowing ground &c. with a                    con-<ns0:lb /> -siderable number of Cattle, and some hor-<ns0:lb /> -ses, Sheep, and                    Swine, which made a<ns0:lb /> pretty Clever appearance: but on arriv-<ns0:lb /> -ing at                    the Stockbridge Settlement, the<ns0:lb /> prospect of their improvement was<ns0:lb /> more                    delightful, the have a large<ns0:lb /> Street between two and three miles in<ns0:lb />                    length, which Ascends up the middle of a valley<ns0:lb /> one mile or more in                        Wi<ns0:del><ns0:gap /></ns0:del>dth, on each<ns0:lb /> side of this street their houses are                    erect-<ns0:lb /> -ed 20 or 30 pearches from each other, the<ns0:lb /> Land on this Street                    is mostly cleared, and<ns0:lb /> fenced off in small Lots, which lots were in<ns0:lb />                    with Wheat, Corn, Grass for Mowing, or<ns0:lb /> for pasture: It is about nine                    years<ns0:lb /> since they settled here in the Woods,<ns0:lb /> their first houses are                    mostly small, and<ns0:lb /> poor, some of them have latterly put up<ns0:lb /> pretty good                    houses, and others are pre-<ns0:lb /> paring for it. The have pretty good<ns0:lb />                    Gardens near their doors, and consi-<ns0:lb /> -derable Stock, of horses, and Oxen,                    Cows, and<ns0:lb /> Swine, with some Sheep. On the East <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_147" n="145" /> near enough to supply themselves                    with<ns0:lb /> water runs the <ns0:geogName key="onecr">Oneida Creek</ns0:geogName>, and on                    the<ns0:lb /> West in the Same Valley a small stream,<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> so that they are well supplyed with<ns0:lb /> Water, and towards the                    South end<ns0:lb /> of their Village, they have a Grist Mill,<ns0:lb /> and a Sawmill,                    their Grist mill does<ns0:lb /> considerable work for the White People,<ns0:lb /> and                    their was a large quantity of logs<ns0:lb /> and Boards, at the Sawmill. We                    called<ns0:lb /> to see most of the families of note a<ns0:del>mo</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> mongst them,                    also a School kept by <ns0:del>an Indian</ns0:del> a religious Indian Man with whom I                    was much<ns0:lb /> pleased, <ns0:del>more particularily with the</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>Women</ns0:del>, many of the Women <ns0:del>whom</ns0:del>, were Solid,<ns0:lb /> Sensible,                    and engaging. there houses<ns0:lb /> were clean with Wooden floors and Glass<ns0:lb />                    Windows, themselves and Children mostly<ns0:lb /> clean, and neat, and the Men and                    Boys<ns0:lb /> were hoeing corn &c. I thought there was<ns0:lb /> as much diffirence                    between Cornplan-<ns0:lb /> -ters people, and this nation; as betwee n<ns0:lb /> these                    People, and the better livers amon g<ns0:lb /> the White People. We had a                    favoured<ns0:lb /> oppertunity with a number of the most <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_148" n="146" /> respectable Characters of both                    their<ns0:lb /> Men and Women, at the close of which,<ns0:lb /> a Chief on the behalf of                    the Men pre-<ns0:lb /> -sent made a pretty lengthy Speech, in<ns0:lb /> Substance;                    expressing their thankful-<ns0:lb /> -ness to the good Spirit who had put<ns0:lb /> it                    into our hearts to remember<ns0:lb /> them when at a great distance, and<ns0:lb /> had                    preserved us in our way thither;<ns0:lb /> that they felt themselves much                    Streng-<ns0:lb /> -thened by our good Words, that they<ns0:lb /> were sensible they had                    done that which<ns0:lb /> was not right, yet hoped by the help<ns0:lb /> of the good                    Spirit they would do better for<ns0:lb /> the future, and they Wished the Qua-<ns0:lb />                    -kers, would continue to remember<ns0:lb /> them, for they had found them to be<ns0:lb />                    true Men, and that the realy had<ns0:lb /> the poor Indians good at Heart, and<ns0:lb />                    wished <ns0:del>that</ns0:del> the good Spirit would safely pre-<ns0:lb /> -serve us on our                    way home to our fa-<ns0:lb /> milies and friends. Then after a short<ns0:lb /> pause, a                    Woman on behalf of the Wo- <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_149" n="147" /> men present delivered a speach much<ns0:lb />                    to the foregoing import, tho we thought it<ns0:lb /> more weighty, and nervious, we                    then re-<ns0:lb /> -turn’d to <ns0:persName key="haupa1">Captain Hendricks’s</ns0:persName>                    where<ns0:lb /> we lodged, in a good Clean bed.</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 24, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Returned this Morning to our friends at<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="oneid">Oneida</ns0:placeName>, and it being the first day of the                    week<ns0:lb /> we sat with them in their Meeting.</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 25, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Had a Council with the <ns0:orgName key="oneida">Oneida’s</ns0:orgName> this<ns0:lb />                    afternoon, on Business that our friends here<ns0:lb /> had been endeavouring to get                    them together<ns0:lb /> about for several Weeks past, but were<ns0:lb /> not able to                    accomplish it until we came,<ns0:lb /> we made some fresh proposals to them con-<ns0:lb />                    -cerning some of their young men coming to<ns0:lb /> work on the farm with our                    friends, they<ns0:lb /> having never complyed with the proposals<ns0:lb /> that were made,                    when the friends first were<ns0:lb /> there, as the consideration therein mentioned<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>they were to receive</ns0:del> for their labour, they<ns0:lb /> apprehended at too                    great a difference, it be-<ns0:lb /> -ing such a share of what was raised. There<ns0:lb />                    were also some proposials concerning one<ns0:lb /> or two of their Young Men coming                    to learn <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_150" n="148" /> the Smith trade, all which they                    said<ns0:lb /> they would take under consideration and<ns0:lb /> let us know tomorrow,                    then they were clos[e]<ns0:lb /> -ly expostulated with, concerning some Jea-<ns0:lb />                    -louses they had entertained, occationed by<ns0:lb /> some whisperings of evel Minded                    White<ns0:lb /> People, who told them the Quakers had<ns0:lb /> some deep rooted design,                    to <ns0:del>make</ns0:del> get pos-<ns0:lb /> -session of their Lands, for they                    certainly<ns0:lb /> would not have been at the great expence<ns0:lb /> they have, if they                    did not expect some<ns0:lb /> temporal advantage therefrom; they<ns0:lb /> acknowledged                    they had given too much place<ns0:lb /> in their Minds to such Whisperings, and<ns0:lb />                    that it had made them feel, to use there<ns0:lb /> own expressions, very ugly, we let                    them<ns0:lb /> know that we would not have their Land<ns0:lb /> if they would give it to                    us, and that it was<ns0:lb /> very unkind in them to have given place<ns0:lb /> to such                    surmisings without they had, had<ns0:lb /> some ground for it <ns0:del>them</ns0:del>, they                    acknow-<ns0:lb /> -ledged they had found us to be true Men,<ns0:lb /> that we Spoke the                    same words to them<ns0:lb /> now, we Spoke <ns0:del>two</ns0:del> too them two years ago <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_151" n="149" /> and that they would Shut their Ears to                    all<ns0:lb /> such Whisperings in future. Then said, they<ns0:lb /> had been trying to                    improve in farming, and<ns0:lb /> if they did not come forward as fast, and as<ns0:lb />                    well as <ns0:del>we desired</ns0:del> the Quakers desired,<ns0:lb /> they must not get                    discouraged, but conti-<ns0:lb /> -nue there care, and Assistance towards them.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Upon enquiring of our young Men here, they<ns0:lb /> informed us there was some                    improvment a-<ns0:lb /> -mong the <ns0:orgName key="oneida">Oneida’s</ns0:orgName> since they                    came, tho<ns0:lb /> not such as they wished to have seen, they<ns0:lb /> Plough more, and                    fence more, they sow more<ns0:lb /> Wheat, and have more lots of Meadow. They<ns0:lb />                    are computed young and old <ns0:del>to amount to</ns0:del> at<ns0:lb /> about 600, and are                    scattered 10 or more miles<ns0:lb /> distant, tho their largest number is with-<ns0:lb />                    -in two miles of this place. They have a<ns0:lb /> large enclosure here of perhaps                    200 Acres,<ns0:lb /> wherein the keep their horses, of which they<ns0:lb /> have more than                    necessary, their Cows, and<ns0:lb /> Swine; and in said enclosure are many of<ns0:lb />                    their Horses, and they plant their Corn, sow<ns0:lb /> their Wheat and Oates, and                    have their mea-<ns0:lb /> -dow lots without, but this mode of farm-<ns0:lb /> -ing, it                    looks likely they will have to change<ns0:lb /> before long, for the have sold their                    Lands, <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_152" n="150" /> particularly where the State road                    goe[s]<ns0:lb /> within 2 or 3 miles of this place, and the<ns0:lb /> White People are                    settleing on it fast,<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>and</ns0:del> they haveing put up several Houses both to the East, and                    West<ns0:lb /> of the Castle <ns0:del>have been put up</ns0:del> this Spring<ns0:lb /> and we saw                    a number Cattle in the Woods<ns0:lb /> within two Miles of their Corn &c.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> There are several good houses in the<ns0:lb /> Castle, with Glass Windows and                        <ns0:del>large</ns0:del> Piazza<ns0:lb /> or Portico’s before the door, one of the<ns0:lb />                    Chief’s House<ns0:del>s</ns0:del> is painted red, and looks<ns0:lb /> Showy, -- The main Road                    from <ns0:placeName key="alban">Albany</ns0:placeName> to<ns0:lb /> the Western Country goes                    through their<ns0:lb /> enclosure, there being a gate hung on<ns0:lb /> each side, many                    travellers stop and<ns0:lb /> Stay all night at the Red house, it is<ns0:lb /> called a                    Tavern. -- Their houses are ge-<ns0:lb /> nerally floored, with Chimneys at one                    end</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 26, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Part of this afternoon was spent in<ns0:lb /> Settleing with the <ns0:orgName key="stockbridge">Stockbridge Indians</ns0:orgName><ns0:lb /> concerning the Mill                    friends built them<ns0:lb /> and in the evening we had a Council<ns0:lb /> with the                        <ns0:orgName key="oneida">Oneida’s</ns0:orgName>, in order for them<ns0:lb /> to give us                    an Answer to the proposals<ns0:lb /> we made them Yesterday, they informed <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_153" n="151" /> us they had found one lad or Young Man,                    willing<ns0:lb /> to come and join in, on the farm, and one<ns0:lb /> to learn the smith                    trade, and the Chiefs<ns0:lb /> engaged to use their endeavours to get<ns0:lb /> more,                    they also agreed immeadiately to<ns0:lb /> Cover a shop, and burn some Coals,                    whic[h]<ns0:lb /> shop they accordingly covered next Mornin[g]<ns0:lb /> and went                    immeadiately to getting wood<ns0:lb /> home for Coal, and the oppertinity end-<ns0:lb />                    -ed to general satisfaction. --- <ns0:del>And</ns0:del> It now<ns0:lb /> looks likely we may                    set of homewards tomorro[w]<ns0:lb /> which feels very pleasant. My Mind                        <ns0:del>has</ns0:del> for<ns0:lb /> the most part, has been easy about my<ns0:lb /> family                    and concerns at home, ever since<ns0:lb /> I left them, but now our business                    appear-<ns0:lb /> -ing to be gone through, the draught hom[e]<ns0:lb /> feels strong: and                    it has been some exercise<ns0:lb /> to our Minds to fix on the best rout to<ns0:lb />                    take, down the <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">Mohocks River</ns0:geogName>, by <ns0:placeName key="alban">Al-<ns0:lb /> -bany</ns0:placeName>, and through the Jerseys, is the                    best<ns0:lb /> Road, the Oldest settled Country, and likel[y]<ns0:lb /> to <ns0:del>be</ns0:del>                    have the best accomodations, but down<ns0:lb /> the Waters of the <ns0:geogName key="susqu">Susquehanna</ns0:geogName>, near 100<ns0:lb /> miles neigher.</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 27, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Upon further Consideration we<ns0:lb /> felt most easy to return home down<ns0:lb /> the                        <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">Mohocks River</ns0:geogName>, And about one OClock<ns0:lb />                    >we took an affectionate farewell of our frd s,<ns0:lb /> having before taken leave                    of the Indians,<ns0:lb /> and set off, and passed through a thick<ns0:lb /> Woods much of                    it hemlock, for 7 or<ns0:lb /> 8 miles, <ns0:del>passed by</ns0:del> wherein there were a few                    settlements, lately<ns0:lb /> erected, but as we <ns0:del>passed</ns0:del> went on,                    improvment[s]<ns0:lb /> became more plenty, so that in a few miles<ns0:lb /> we got into a                    thick settled Country, with<ns0:lb /> Large frame houses many of which were<ns0:lb />                    painted; and good frame Barns, such as<ns0:lb /> would have been a Credit to an Old                    settled<ns0:lb /> Country, with fields loaded with Clover and<ns0:lb /> Timothy for                    Mowing, with some fields of Wheat,<ns0:lb /> and a very good appearance of Corn, and                    other Spring Crop[s]<ns0:lb /> in 17 miles we came to <ns0:placeName key="newha">new                        Hartford</ns0:placeName>, a<ns0:lb /> smart Town, <ns0:del>with</ns0:del> containing a number                    of good hou-<ns0:lb /> -ses, among which, was a large place of Wor-<ns0:lb /> -ship, then                    to the River of <ns0:placeName key="fschy">Fort Schuylar</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb /> 4 Miles,                    where we passed through another<ns0:lb /> Town as large as <ns0:placeName key="newha">Hartford</ns0:placeName>, and the build-<ns0:lb /> -ings good. here we crossed the                        <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">River</ns0:geogName>,<ns0:lb /> which I thought was not much                    larger than <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_155" n="153" />                    <ns0:geogName key="brand">Brandywine</ns0:geogName>, we then went down the<ns0:lb /> North                    side of said <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">River</ns0:geogName> through a Rich Coun-<ns0:lb />                    -try thick settled to Bratons 3 miles <ns0:del>where we</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>took up our quarters</ns0:del>, where we got good ac-<ns0:lb /> -comodations both                    for ourselves and horses.<ns0:lb /> Farmers busy Mowing and making hay today, the                    first<ns0:lb /> we have seen, Grass so stout, scarcely room<ns0:lb /> on the ground to dry                    it <ns0:gap /> 24 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 23, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> a<ns0:lb /> Violent hail storm passed through the coun-<ns0:lb /> -try a little to the                    North of us, its direction was<ns0:lb /> nearly East and its extenton 20 or more<ns0:lb />                    miles, and from one to two in breadth,<ns0:lb /> as we returned to <ns0:placeName key="oneid">Oneida</ns0:placeName> next Morning<ns0:lb /> We beheld its destructive                    effects, on the<ns0:lb /> corn, Oates, &c; and this day for more<ns0:lb /> than five                    miles, it was affecting to see<ns0:lb /> the destruction it made: whole fields<ns0:lb />                    of wheat were entirely cut off, so that<ns0:lb /> we could not see one head standing,                    corn,<ns0:lb /> Flax, and Oates fared but little better, Peas<ns0:lb /> in the Gardens and                    fields, Acres being<ns0:lb /> Sown here, were entirely <ns0:del>cut off,</ns0:del>                    destroy<ns0:lb /> -ed, large fields of Timothy were so bro- <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_156" n="154" /> broken down that they smelled like<ns0:lb />                    fresh hay, there being many Pokebushes<ns0:lb /> along the Road, <ns0:del>they</ns0:del>                    which were knocked all<ns0:lb /> to pices, the stalks which were as thick<ns0:lb /> as                    rake handles were broke, in short<ns0:lb /> all vegetation where the storm                    reched<ns0:lb /> suffered much; the fences, stumps, &<ns0:lb /> Old logs were much                    marked: the Win-<ns0:lb /> -dows of a number of houses were very<ns0:lb /> much destroyed,                    one place of Worshi[p]<ns0:lb /> we understood had more than 300<ns0:lb /> lights                    broke.</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 28, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> A fine Morning, and a pleasant day<ns0:lb /> for traveling: about 8 or 9 miles of a                    fine<ns0:lb /> Country down the <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">River</ns0:geogName>, the poorly                    farmed<ns0:lb /> buildings not near so good as further back,<ns0:lb /> thence 5 miles to                    Adridges where we got<ns0:lb /> our Breakfasts, through land equally<ns0:lb /> as good,                    and much better farmed, with<ns0:lb /> some large buildings; both spring and<ns0:lb />                    Winter Wheat good, also the Corn; and fine<ns0:lb /> meadows loaded with the best of                    Grass; the<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">River</ns0:geogName> at times close on our right, which<ns0:lb />                    flowed along with a gentle Current, appeard<ns0:lb /> pretty deep, tho not much wider                    than <ns0:geogName key="brand">Bar[n]</ns0:geogName>                    <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_157" n="155" />                    <ns0:geogName key="brand">dywine</ns0:geogName>, this was through what is called the<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="gefla">German flatts</ns0:placeName>. We passed through the                    County<ns0:lb /> Town of <ns0:placeName key="herki">Hackamack</ns0:placeName>, and so over                    the <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">River</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> on a Bridge to the southside one                    mile be-<ns0:lb /> -fore we fed. thence 14 miles to Teevendurfs<ns0:lb /> over high, dry,                    Stony Land, Buildings mostly<ns0:lb /> poor, as was allso the grass and other                    Crops;<ns0:lb /> we now left the <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">River</ns0:geogName> at some                    distance to our left.<ns0:lb /> About three miles back we went by a<ns0:lb /> pretty                    elegant House, now occupied by<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:orgName>prespeterians </ns0:orgName>, it                    was built by <ns0:persName key="wjohn3">William<ns0:lb /> Johnson</ns0:persName> before the                    French and Indian War<ns0:lb /> as a place of Worship for the Indians.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> In about one Mile <ns0:del>from</ns0:del> after we left Teevendurff’s<ns0:lb /> having passed                    through a fine flat, we rode<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">River</ns0:geogName>                    which had increased much in<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>weadth</ns0:del> Width, the flat still Continuing,<ns0:lb /> in one mile we left it,                    and passed over 6 or<ns0:lb /> 7 miles of a Stony, rough, poor Country,<ns0:lb /> except                    some bottoms on the <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">River</ns0:geogName>, the build-<ns0:lb />                    -ings also poor, then 7 or more miles, fine<ns0:lb /> bottoms loaded with grass, and                    various<ns0:lb /> sorts of grain; thicksettled near the <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">River</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> with many good Buildings, more particu-<ns0:lb /> -larly                    on the south side. the latter part <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_158" n="156" /> >part of this stage the Mountains, or                    high roc[ky]<ns0:lb /> Hills crouded near to the <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">River</ns0:geogName>, so that<ns0:lb /> inplaces there was scarcely room for a<ns0:lb />                    Road. Lodged at Connolly’s 17m <ns0:gap /> 41 miles </ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Peas are very commonly swon in this<ns0:lb /> Northern Country, from <ns0:placeName key="canad">Canada</ns0:placeName> to this place<ns0:lb /> 3, 4 or more Acres in a                    lot; they are used to<ns0:lb /> feed Horses, fatten swine, &c, the Bottoms<ns0:lb />                    on the <ns0:geogName key="mohaw">Mohocks</ns0:geogName>, contain a large quantity<ns0:lb />                    of them. --- Spring Crops of all sorts on<ns0:lb /> this River and for a many miles                    further Wes[t]<ns0:lb /> I have observed to be very much hurt with<ns0:lb /> a Yellow                    Blossomed Weed, it has the appear-<ns0:lb /> -ance of Mustard tho much smaller, it                    grows<ns0:lb /> so thick in places, that the Oates, Peas, spring<ns0:lb /> Wheat &c:                    are entirely hid.</ns0:p>

text.headline: June 30, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> In 1½ Miles we arrived at <ns0:placeName key="alban">Albany</ns0:placeName>, the<ns0:lb />                    Town stands on the West Side of the <ns0:geogName key="nrive">North<ns0:lb />                        River</ns0:geogName>, under a hill, so that we had but<ns0:lb /> little prospect of                    it until we <ns0:del>we</ns0:del> came close by,<ns0:lb /> we did not stop in the <ns0:placeName key="alban">Town</ns0:placeName>, riding<ns0:lb /> in at the West side, and out at                    the<ns0:lb /> South end; Shortly after we left the<ns0:lb /> City we passed by two                    beautiful country<ns0:lb /> seats on Commanding Eminances to our <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_162" n="160" /> Right, the fruit trees around them, the                    de-<ns0:lb /> -scending green meadows before their doors<ns0:lb /> and the <ns0:geogName key="nrive">River</ns0:geogName> which was in full view, rend-<ns0:lb /> -red                        <ns0:del>them desirable</ns0:del> their situation very en-<ns0:lb /> -chanting. We now                    pursued our Coarse down<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:geogName key="nrive">River</ns0:geogName> having                    it at times in view, to<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="coeym">Quemanstown</ns0:placeName> 15 miles, where we got a<ns0:lb />                    good Breakfast, a few miles on this side <ns0:placeName key="alban">Al-<ns0:lb />                        -bany</ns0:placeName>, the land was a Stony Gravel, with<ns0:lb /> a hard Clay; then                    sandy; the Whole of<ns0:lb /> the way poor; thinly settled; and buildings<ns0:lb /> mean;                    mostly a pitchpine Timber, ---</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Thence to <ns0:placeName key="catsk1">Catskill</ns0:placeName> 18 miles; the first<ns0:lb />                    3 or 4 rough and stony; then 8 or 10 miles<ns0:lb /> through an Old Settled Country;                    pretty<ns0:lb /> level fields; without pasture, meadows very light, Wheat,<ns0:lb /> Rye,                    Cheat, and some Cackle, mixed toga-<ns0:lb /> -ther made their Winter Crop; the                    land<ns0:lb /> a stiff Clay, in dry Weather it bakes very<ns0:lb /> hard; the Remainder of                    this stage full of<ns0:lb /> Limestone ridges, and so stony as not to be<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>arable</ns0:del> Arable <ns0:geogName key="catsk2">Catskill</ns0:geogName> a large                    stream with a<ns0:lb /> very Rocky bottom; from thence to Pear-<ns0:lb /> -sons a Dutch                    Tavern where we lodged 12½<ns0:lb /> miles. In about two miles we crossed the<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="kaate">Katters-kill</ns0:geogName> on a high Bridge, Just below<ns0:lb />                    which there was a remarkable fall of <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_163" n="161" /> 30 or more feet over a huge pile of                    Rocks,<ns0:lb /> which damed the Water for miles back, &<ns0:lb /> formed a very fine                    Millseat, on which were<ns0:lb /> erected a Merchant, and Sawmill; from thence<ns0:lb />                    to this place the Land continued very much<ns0:lb /> broken with high Limestone                    Ridges runing<ns0:lb /> in a Southern direction. Much highland<ns0:lb /> were to be seen                    in this days ride; we often<ns0:lb /> had a full view of many miles extent o-<ns0:lb />                    -ver the <ns0:geogName key="nrive">North River</ns0:geogName>; and on our right<ns0:lb /> at                    10 or miles distant, ran a chain of<ns0:lb /> high <ns0:geogName key="catmo">Mountains</ns0:geogName>. The latter part of this<ns0:lb /> stage the Land better                    than farther bac[k]<ns0:lb /> with pretty good buildings, some good<ns0:lb /> fields of                    wheat, mostly bearded. 47 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: July 01, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> We would have been glad<ns0:lb /> to have reached a friends meeting today, but<ns0:lb />                    found it impractable, therefore thought best<ns0:lb /> of traveling, tho not without                    some unplea-<ns0:lb /> -sant feelings, being in a Presbeterian Coun-<ns0:lb /> -try. ----                    Early this morning we passed<ns0:lb /> through two considerable red Cedar                    groves,<ns0:lb /> on Rocky, poor Land; then through pret-<ns0:lb /> -ty good land, and                    thick settled, tho very much <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_164" n="162" /> broken with limestone Ridges, in 10<ns0:lb />                    miles we Crossed <ns0:geogName key="esocr">Esopus Creek</ns0:geogName> a<ns0:lb /> Smart                    stream larger than <ns0:geogName key="brand">Brandywine</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> fine bottoms                    up the <ns0:geogName key="esocr">Creek</ns0:geogName> to the <ns0:placeName key="esopu">Town</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb /> which is a smart Village containing<ns0:lb /> a number of                    good buildings. we pass-<ns0:lb /> -ed through the skirts of the Town, &<ns0:lb /> in                    about 4 miles, of stony, Rough,<ns0:lb /> Land <ns0:del>we</ns0:del> got to <ns0:placeName key="green">greenskill</ns0:placeName>, here we<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>we</ns0:del>                    <ns0:del>got our</ns0:del> took Breakfast at <ns0:persName key="gdewi1">DeWitts</ns0:persName>,                    in<ns0:lb /> a Rocky country. He has a Merchant<ns0:lb /> Mill near by, on the most                    natural dam<ns0:lb /> and fall I think I ever saw. There<ns0:lb /> is a ridge of Rocks                    runs across the kill<ns0:lb /> on each side of Which is high firm land.<ns0:lb /> one end                    of the Mill head which conveys the<ns0:lb /> water on the Wheels, rests on these                    Rocks,<ns0:lb /> from which to the opposite Shore is but ten<ns0:lb /> feet; the Miller                    told me that by putting<ns0:lb /> an eighteen Inch board, on the top<ns0:lb /> of about 18                    Inches already raised, on<ns0:lb /> the ridge of Rocks, he could pen wa-<ns0:lb /> -ter                    enough, if it met with no supply, <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_165" n="163" /> to keep the Mill a going for three days,                        <ns0:del>there</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>being such a large, swampy, low piece of</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>ground above this natural dam.</ns0:del> Thence<ns0:lb /> through a Rough Country,                    the good roads,<ns0:lb /> in about 18 miles we arrived at <ns0:persName key="sbald1">Samuel Baldwin</ns0:persName>[‘s]<ns0:lb /> in 4 or more miles of the first part of                    this<ns0:lb /> stage we Crossed the <ns0:geogName key="rondo">Rosendell</ns0:geogName>, a                    lively<ns0:lb /> stream, nearly as large as <ns0:geogName key="esocr">Esopus</ns0:geogName>,                    the<ns0:lb /> Bridge over it was near fifty Yards long<ns0:lb /> and twenty feet from the                    Water, yet the<ns0:lb /> stream rose so high a few months ago as<ns0:lb /> to lie on the                    bridge, -- In perhaps four<ns0:lb /> Miles further we came to the <ns0:geogName key="wallk">Wallkill</ns0:geogName>,<ns0:lb /> which was as large as three of the                        <ns0:geogName key="rondo">Rosen-<ns0:lb /> -dall</ns0:geogName>, and into which the                        <ns0:geogName key="rondo">Rosendall</ns0:geogName> runs<ns0:lb /> a few Miles below. We                    went several miles<ns0:lb /> up the <ns0:geogName key="wallk">Wallkill</ns0:geogName> through                    a fine, level Coun-<ns0:lb /> -try, and Crossed it in a boat; it was perhaps<ns0:lb /> 60                    or 70 Yards wide, and 10 feet deep. There<ns0:lb /> appeared to be no Current in the                        <ns0:geogName key="wallk">River</ns0:geogName>, occa-<ns0:lb /> -tioned by a Ridge of                    Rocks that runs across <ns0:del>it</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> it 5 or 6 miles below, over which the                    Water<ns0:lb /> falls 20 or more feet. From what I have seen<ns0:lb /> as well as heard,                    falls of this kind are very <ns0:lb />                     common on most of the Water in this                    part<ns0:lb /> of the Country. --- As we advanced South-<ns0:lb /> -ward, the Land                    improved in quality, and<ns0:lb /> the Wonderful Ridges of Rocks, that were<ns0:lb /> so                    very common further back, grew fewer,<ns0:lb /> yet stones rather Increased; tho most                    of the<ns0:lb /> land in the latter part of this stage is<ns0:lb /> Arable, more                    especially after the Stones<ns0:lb /> are drawn of, which in divers places<ns0:lb /> have                    been done and put up in stone fen-<ns0:lb /> -ces. The Plaister of Paris has been                    latter<ns0:lb /> -ly introduced into these parts and answers<ns0:lb /> very well. We                    arrived at <ns0:persName key="sbald1">Samuel <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_166" n="164" /> Bald-<ns0:lb /> -wins</ns0:persName> about four                    Oclock, weary, and glad<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>glad</ns0:del> we were got to a friends house. The<ns0:lb /> weather latterly has                    been very warm, and we<ns0:lb /> having travelled hard from <ns0:placeName key="oneid">Oneida</ns0:placeName>, both<ns0:lb /> us and our horses wanted Rest, we                    conclud-<ns0:lb /> -ed to lay by here a day or two, in order to get<ns0:lb /> them Shod,                    and to help these backs which were<ns0:lb /> a little sore. -- <ns0:placeName key="jpier1">John Pierce</ns0:placeName>, having at times<ns0:lb /> >for some weeks                    past, hinted to me, that he had<ns0:lb /> some wish before we returned home, to                    go<ns0:lb /> over the <ns0:geogName key="nrive">North River</ns0:geogName> to see the school                    at<ns0:lb /> the <ns0:placeName key="9part">Nine partners</ns0:placeName>, but since we left                        <ns0:placeName key="oneid">Onei-<ns0:lb /> -da</ns0:placeName>, our draft homewards was                    such, that we <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_167" n="165" /> put it by. But on our arrival here,                    un-<ns0:lb /> -derstanding we <ns0:del>are</ns0:del> were within 28 miles of <ns0:del>it</ns0:del> sd.<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="9part">School</ns0:placeName>, and <ns0:persName key="sbald1">Samuel                        Baldwin</ns0:persName> kindly offer-<ns0:lb /> -ing to let us have fresh horses to go                    there<ns0:lb /> and to take good care of our own until<ns0:lb /> we returned: upon                    weighing the propos-<ns0:lb /> -al we felt easy in attempting to go. 36 miles </ns0:p>

text.headline: July 02, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Accordingly this morning we went 9 miles<ns0:lb /> nearly on an East direction to                        <ns0:persName key="ehall1"><ns0:persName key="ehall2">Edward Hal-<ns0:lb />                            -locks</ns0:persName></ns0:persName> near the <ns0:geogName key="nrive">North                        River</ns0:geogName>, over a very rough<ns0:lb /> Stony country; about one Mile                    before we<ns0:lb /> got to <ns0:persName key="ehall1"><ns0:persName key="ehall2">Edwards</ns0:persName></ns0:persName>, off some high land, we had<ns0:lb /> a very                    beautifull and extensive Prospect<ns0:lb /> for about 20 miles over the <ns0:geogName key="nrive">North River</ns0:geogName>, &<ns0:lb /> as far each way, up and down                    the Water. The<ns0:lb /> face of the country appearing to descend to-<ns0:lb /> -wards the                        <ns0:geogName key="nrive">River</ns0:geogName>, and being mostly improv-<ns0:lb /> -ed,                    the Wheat and Pasture fields, together<ns0:lb /> with large houses, Barns &c and                    some sheets<ns0:lb /> of the <ns0:geogName key="nrive">River</ns0:geogName> which presented                    in places, also<ns0:lb /> the Town of <ns0:placeName key="pough">Pocepsey</ns0:placeName>,                    which was four miles<ns0:lb /> up the <ns0:geogName key="nrive">River</ns0:geogName> on its                    Opposite Shore: made<ns0:lb /> the Landscape truly delightful. We dined<ns0:lb /> at                        <ns0:persName key="ehall1"><ns0:persName key="ehall2">Edward                        Hallocks</ns0:persName></ns0:persName>, but the day prov-<ns0:lb /> -ing very Warm, and                    our horses young, not<ns0:lb /> suitable for traveling such weather, we thought <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_168" n="166" /> it would be best not to proceed                    further,<ns0:lb /> therefore in the Evening returned to<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:persName key="sbald1">Samuels</ns0:persName>. <ns0:gap /> 18 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: July 03, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Got our horses Shod this Morning, and<ns0:lb /> intended to have set of homewards                    in<ns0:lb /> the Afternoon, but there coming up a hea-<ns0:lb /> -vy Gust of Rain and                    Hail, we put it by <ns0:del>of un</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> until next Morning.</ns0:p>

text.headline: July 04, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Set of early this Morning through<ns0:lb /> a pretty good Country, and fine                    Roads<ns0:lb /> to Jacksons, 18 miles, here we fed our hor-<ns0:lb /> -ses and got a                    second breakfast. We pass-<ns0:lb /> -ed by four large places of Worship this<ns0:lb />                    Morning; and a number of good houses<ns0:lb /> and Barns, the land level and                    pretty<ns0:lb /> clear of stones. A Chain of Mountains<ns0:lb /> were steadily in view on                    our right, at ten<ns0:lb /> or miles distant; and we left <ns0:placeName key="newbu">newburgh</ns0:placeName>,<ns0:lb /> and <ns0:placeName key="nwind">New                        Windsor</ns0:placeName> 8 or 10 miles to our left.<ns0:lb /> More Swamp Meadow for                    the last 14 miles<ns0:lb /> than for 100 before. A large proportion<ns0:lb /> of the land                    was sown with wheat, which<ns0:lb /> was mostly light. Not so much Rye as<ns0:lb />                    further back. Thence throug good land,<ns0:lb /> thick settled, and a beautiful                    country to<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:placeName key="goshe">Goshen</ns0:placeName>, the County Town of <ns0:placeName key="orang">Orange County</ns0:placeName>. </ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Off a commanding eminence, a few miles<ns0:lb /> before we got to this <ns0:placeName key="goshe">Village</ns0:placeName>, we had an<ns0:lb /> extensive Prospect, to the                    West, to the<ns0:lb /> South, and to the East, I expect the Eye<ns0:lb /> reached 20 miles                    each way, over a level<ns0:lb /> looking Country, much improved. In<ns0:lb /> the                    neighbourhood of this <ns0:placeName key="goshe">Village</ns0:placeName>, lies a                    large<ns0:lb /> proportion of valuable Meadows, and<ns0:lb /> shortly after we left the                        <ns0:placeName key="goshe">Town</ns0:placeName> I observed all<ns0:lb /> the fences, both                    Pot, and Rail, and Worm<ns0:lb /> fences, were made of nice Ceder Rails,<ns0:lb /> and                    upon enquiry I was informed, in what<ns0:lb /> is called the drowned Lands, there is                    a<ns0:lb /> Ceder Swamp of Several thousand Acres,<ns0:lb /> which supplys the country for                    several miles<ns0:lb /> round. A very valuable source. In 6 miles<ns0:lb /> over land more                    rough and hilly we got<ns0:lb /> to <ns0:placeName key="flori">Florida</ns0:placeName> a                    place of several good buildings<ns0:lb /> where we fed. Water for our horses to                    drink<ns0:lb /> at has been very scarce these two last stages.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Thence 12 miles to Doctor Cooes, where<ns0:lb /> we Lodged, over a hilly, Stony                    Country,<ns0:lb /> a great abundance of Limestone the <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_170" n="168" /> latter part of this stage. Rye the                    most<ns0:lb /> common Winter grain. We are now<ns0:lb /> in the Jerseys 3 or 4 miles South                    of the<ns0:lb /> New York line, having travelled in <ns0:del>sd</ns0:del><ns0:lb /> York State                    upwards of 500 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: July 05, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> This has been the worst stage for our<ns0:lb /> horses that we have met with since                    we<ns0:lb /> left <ns0:placeName key="oneid">Oneida</ns0:placeName>, and not very good for                    our<ns0:lb /> -selves. Went to Doctor Beeches 7 miles<ns0:lb /> to Breakfast. very good.                    Our last<ns0:lb /> 7 miles was through a rough Country,<ns0:lb /> a Considerable Mountain                    close on our<ns0:lb /> left, and a Valley on our right; most<ns0:lb /> of the Land very                    stony. Stone fences<ns0:lb /> pretty frequent. The farmers have<ns0:lb /> been very busy                    for this Week past, in<ns0:lb /> ploughing and hoeing their Corn, and<ns0:lb /> in                    ploughing for buckwheat; a large<ns0:lb /> Quantity of this Grain, being sown here                    away <ns0:del>in</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>this Country</ns0:del>. A few Crops of good Wheat<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>are</ns0:del> to be seen, but light crops of rye<ns0:lb /> are more                        <ns0:del>commonly</ns0:del> frequend. A Dutch<ns0:lb /> Plough with one handle which                    stands near-<ns0:lb /> -ly upright, with a very short beam an[d] <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_171" n="169" /> pan Share, is almost the only plough                        <ns0:del>such</ns0:del>, that<ns0:lb /> is used for 200 miles back; they appear to<ns0:lb />                    work easy both for the horses, and plough<ns0:lb /> -man, and does their business                    pretty neat.</ns0:p>                <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Shortly after we left this stage we Cross-<ns0:lb /> -ed the <ns0:geogName key="wallk">Wallkill</ns0:geogName>, fifty miles higher up than<ns0:lb /> where we crossed it                    firtday last, yet the<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="wallk">Stream</ns0:geogName> was so large, as to have a forge                    erect-<ns0:lb /> -ed on it a little above the fording place.<ns0:lb /> In about 7 miles                    further we Crossed the<ns0:lb />                    <ns0:geogName key="pauli">Pawlinskill</ns0:geogName>, which was the first Water<ns0:lb /> we                    met with that <ns0:del>runs</ns0:del> ran into the <ns0:geogName key="delaw">Delaware</ns0:geogName>,<ns0:lb /> having gone round all the head branches<ns0:lb /> of                    said River, as we did those of <ns0:geogName key="susqu">Susquehanna</ns0:geogName>,                    stopped and got our dinner<ns0:lb /> at <ns0:persName key="bscho1">Benjamin                        Schoolies</ns0:persName> 12 miles who, with his Wife<ns0:lb /> are examplary friends,                    thence one mile<ns0:lb /> to <ns0:placeName key="newto">Newtown</ns0:placeName> or <ns0:placeName key="susse">Sussex Courthouse</ns0:placeName> a smart<ns0:lb /> Village, thence to                        <ns0:persName key="jlund1">Jacob Lundys</ns0:persName>, through<ns0:lb /> a pretty good                    Country tho very much bro-<ns0:lb /> -ken with Limestone. As we advanced<ns0:lb /> towards                        <ns0:persName key="jlund1">Jacobs</ns0:persName>, the Land became more Ara-<ns0:lb />                    -ble, I believe no place that I have rode<ns0:lb /> through since I left home, had so                    kindly<ns0:lb /> and good a limestone as for 10 or 15 miles back<ns0:lb /> Ten thousands                    of loads may be collected with-<ns0:lb /> -out Quarying, or being under the                    necessitity <ns0:lb />                    <ns0:pb facs="SW_JS1798_Page_172" n="170" /> of breaking the stones <ns0:gap /> 34                    miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: July 06, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Set Off for <ns0:placeName key="kingw">Kingwood</ns0:placeName>, crossed the <ns0:geogName key="peque">Pequest</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> within one mile of our Quarters,                    thenc[e]<ns0:lb /> rode several miles with it near on our right<ns0:lb /> having the Large                        <ns0:geogName key="allam">allomoochy Mountain</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> close on our left,                    here we passed by what<ns0:lb /> is called the great Meadows, being seve-<ns0:lb /> -ral                    Thousand Acres, with very little timber<ns0:lb /> on it, and a large proportion                    without any,<ns0:lb /> it produces a valuable out let, and some<ns0:lb /> Coarse Hay. for                    want of more fall in the <ns0:geogName key="peque">Pequest</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> it cannot                    be drained. In a few miles<ns0:lb /> we passed through <ns0:placeName key="hacke">Hacketstown</ns0:placeName> a scatter-<ns0:lb /> -ing Village, thence 10 miles to                        <ns0:persName key="jstou1">James<ns0:lb /> Stouts</ns0:persName> on <ns0:geogName key="musco">Muskenecunk</ns0:geogName> where we fed, then<ns0:lb /> down sd. <ns0:geogName key="musco">Creek</ns0:geogName> 5 miles to <ns0:placeName key="south">Southhampton</ns0:placeName><ns0:lb /> a small Village, from thence to <ns0:persName key="hclift1">Henry<ns0:lb /> Cliftons</ns0:persName> of <ns0:placeName key="kingw">Kingwood</ns0:placeName> 12 miles. perhaps <ns0:del>Some</ns0:del> 7 miles<ns0:lb /> back of                    some hights, there are two delight<ns0:lb /> -ful prospects over a large extent of                    an<ns0:lb /> improved Country, down the Waters<ns0:lb /> of the <ns0:geogName key="rarit">Rariton</ns0:geogName>: several small branches<ns0:lb /> of said stream we having                    crossed on our way hither,<ns0:lb /> about one mile back we left <ns0:placeName key="pitts1">Pitts Town</ns0:placeName>,<ns0:lb /> a small Village, to our right.                    <ns0:gap /> 34 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: July 07, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Set of early this Morning, in about<ns0:lb /> 6 miles, off a bold commanding                    Eminance<ns0:lb /> we had an extensive and beautiful pros-<ns0:lb /> -pect, it was                    diversifyed by many im-<ns0:lb /> -proved Farms, over a great extent of Country.<ns0:lb />                    from thence to <ns0:geogName key="delaw">Delaware</ns0:geogName> 7 miles, the <ns0:geogName key="delaw">River</ns0:geogName><ns0:lb /> 400 Yards Wide. Then to <ns0:persName key="jadds1">Josiah Adds</ns0:persName>’s, a<ns0:lb /> Public house through a well                    improved Coun-<ns0:lb /> -try 7 miles, having two miles back passed<ns0:lb /> by                        <ns0:placeName key="buckm">Buckingham Meeting house</ns0:placeName>. Thence<ns0:lb /> 10                    miles to <ns0:persName key="jperr1">Jacob Perry</ns0:persName>’s a kind friend,<ns0:lb />                    here we got our Dinners, and rested a<ns0:lb /> few hours. Thence to <ns0:persName key="ecomf1">Ezra Comfort</ns0:persName>s<ns0:lb /> near <ns0:placeName key="plymo">Plymoth Meeting house</ns0:placeName> 12 miles were we<ns0:lb /> lodged, and were                    kindly entertained.<ns0:lb /> It is a beautifully Country from <ns0:placeName key="buckm">Bucking<ns0:lb /> -ham Meetinghouse</ns0:placeName> here, the Land thick<ns0:lb />                    settled; good Stone houses, and Barns;<ns0:lb /> Farms well improved. Many good                    fields<ns0:lb /> of Corn, and Oates, pretty good Rye, and<ns0:lb /> much of the ground                    under this Culture: but<ns0:lb /> little wheat sown, and that mostly very light.<ns0:lb />                    People all busy a harvesting; Cradleing the<ns0:lb /> manner of cutting grain <ns0:gap />                    42 miles</ns0:p>

text.headline: July 08, 1798
text.text: <ns0:p xmlns:ns0="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Set of soon this Morning for <ns0:placeName key="willm">Wil-<ns0:lb /> -listown                        Meeting</ns0:placeName>. Shortly after we crossed <ns0:geogName key="schri">Schuylkill</ns0:geogName> we passed a small lot of spring barley perhaps the                    first we had seen went to my Brother in-<ns0:lb /> -law <ns0:persName key="agarr1">Amos                        Garretts</ns0:persName>, before Meeting 15m & <ns0:del>where</ns0:del><ns0:lb />                    <ns0:del>we</ns0:del> left our horses, where I heard from<ns0:lb /> my dear Wife and family,                    being the<ns0:lb /> first account I had from them since I<ns0:lb /> left home. and I left                    truly thankfull<ns0:lb /> I was so near my own habitation, and<ns0:lb /> among my near                    relations, and inti<ns0:lb /> -mate friends. We returned here from<ns0:lb /> Meeting and                    got our dinners, and<ns0:lb /> set of homewards, our roads parting<ns0:lb /> on the way,                    we took an affectionate fare-<ns0:lb /> -well of each other, having been out                    toga-<ns0:lb /> -ther ten Weeks wanting one day, and<ns0:lb /> travelled more than 1200                    miles in near<ns0:lb /> unity, and Christian fellowship through<ns0:lb /> some proving                    dispensations. I got home<ns0:lb /> in the evening, and found my Dear<ns0:lb /> Wife and                    family all well, by whom<ns0:lb /> I was gladly recieved. and I felt thank<ns0:lb /> -full                    I was got once more amongst them</ns0:p>
